Two men battle in the center of the arena, fueled by the roar of the crowd. The midday sun beats down upon the combatants, bathing their skin in sweat, adding to the grime and dirt accrued. With each swing of the sword, or in one of their cases, a spear, sun glistens from the steel, sending golden rays to the sand beneath their feet. The sand, a sacred place to the warriors. The sand, soon to be painted red.

The one armed with a sword sweeps low, then high, searching for a break in his opponent’s defences. His attack finds nothing but air, save for a glancing blow on the other man’s bracer. The crowd cheers with the blow, despite its missed arc. They hunger for blood, and the close call excites them into a fury. Rotten vegetables, and items of similar aroma, fly from the arena’s seats. Curses accompany as well, directed at both members, safely shouted from their position some fifteen feet up.

Blood! A thrust of the spear lands home, spraying red onto the sand. The spearpoint, buried in the sword-wielder's gut, pauses for a moment, then emerges out the back in another crimson spread. As the pierced man drops to his knees, the crowd instantly forgets the insults directed at the apparent victor. Their favor lies with the strong, with those able to drop weak men to the dirt.

Suddenly, a hand appears at the spear’s shaft, caked in blood and sand. Its knuckles turn white, holding a steady grip, not allowing the spear to move. With both hands, the spear-wielder can’t jar it loose. His body erupts into movement, placing one foot in front of the other for leverage, attempting to gain ownership of his weapon.

Still, nothing.

Gritting his teeth, the man, impaled, rises from his knees, hand still on the spear. His opponent desperately tries to pull the spear from his gut, focused on the singular action. Horror spreads on his face at the sudden display of strength, highlighting his own weakness, overshadowed by resolve. How can this be? He should be dead.

The sword strikes high, its outcome delayed in arriving. A flash of steel, rush of air, and finally a head drops, the body shortly following. The man, still impaled by the spear, collapses, all his energy spent in the action. He doesn’t hear the crowd chant his name. He doesn’t see the dozens of women exposing themselves for him. He doesn’t even see the impressed look by his master. His vision turns a swirling black, filled with images of past glories, but more importantly, of her.

Your primary sight is a man’s back. Long have you been at sea, chained in the same seat, hands gripped at the same oar. Sure, you can look around, but what’s the point? You’ll just find other men’s backs. You sure as hell don’t want to make eye contact with the guards. They patrol below deck with whip in hand, daring the prisoners to test them. After a few hours from departure, no one bothered to let their pride guide them into action, even if that action was as little as meeting eye contact.

Weeks now, this has been your reality. In the morning, they give you a small piece of bread and tiny sips of water, then you row. You do not speak, you do not interact with your fellow prisoners. You row. You’re dispensable, only allowed to live if drawing breath is beneficial to your masters. You’re nothing but a warm body filling a chair, allowing a businessman miles away to receive compensation. The sooner you accept that fact, the better off you’ll be.

A wave crashes into the boat, showering your mostly exposed body in freezing droplets. Nearby, a whip cracks, warning you to row harder. The brewing storm doesn’t make rowing easy. Malnutrition and exhaustion doesn’t help either. Still, you row. It’s your reality. You see the man’s back, feel the smooth wooden oar at your grasp, even feeling a small dimple in the wood.

Each pull of the oar sends an intentional, sharp exhale from your mouth. Allowing the oar to travel forward, naturally, you take a deep breath in, preparing for the next burst of motion. Then, with another quick exhale, you engage through hardened back muscle, aiming to use as little arm as possible in order to avoid fatigue. Better to let your back, a larger muscle group, take the bulk. Those in shackles among you learned the same trick. Together, in a perfect rhythmic beat, the enclosed area of the ship fills with men’s breathing. Row, exhale. Prepare, inhale. Repeat. There are no other thoughts besides breathwork and your hands on the oar. Nothing else matters.

Another crack of the whip motivates you into movement. Simultaneously, thunder roars from the clouds above the boat in a slow, throaty rumble. Storm’s brewing. You row.

The steady volume of rainfall grows increasingly larger in density. Strong winds howl outside the narrow gap your oar sticks through. The gap isn’t big enough to see any sort of detail; it’s typically just a blue dot in the left side of your peripheral vision. Now, however, it’s black, occasionally flashing white with each lighting strike. Still, you row, the tumultuous water and gusts providing additional resistance. Above deck, you hear the captain shouting commands to the crew, preparing to guide the ship through the storm. Water splashes through cracks in the wood with rising volume. Each spray of icy water encourages you to row harder. Your rowing becomes the outlet in which you take your frustration out.

As if there’s nothing better to do, like helping the above deck crew, several guards patrol down the center of the room cracking their whips. Their fury has heightened with the storm's build. Normally, the whip is used on those slacking in their seat. Now, they use the weapon almost at random, snapping it on the exposed backs of men working their hardest, rowing with everything they’ve got. Twice, you are the victim of such prodding. The whip tears open your exposed flesh. Exposed flesh, which soon after gets stung with cold salt water.

Suddenly, a massive wave crashes into the side of the ship knocking those standing, just the guards, from their feet. Unfortunately for them, the blow knocks them into the rowing slaves, falling at shackled feet. Despite the raging storm, time seems to stand still for a moment, and silence ensues. From their position on the ground, the guards look up towards the lines of slaves sitting above them. Then, as one, the slaves burst into motion. Feet stomp on the guards, keeping them in their prone position, clutching at their sides and face in protection.

None have fallen near you, so you simply watch the scene unfolding before you. Small puddles of red join with the ever present thin layer of water on the floor, spreading out, slowly losing its color into the blue. A hand clasps your back, and you look up to find a ragged face behind an unkempt beard. Drops of water fall from the man’s beard as he moves. Hazel eyes meet yours, and no words are spoken. He places an item in your hand and motions for you to follow. It’s a small key. Free of your shackles, you quickly follow the man. Whoever he is, releasing you from your bonds is reason enough to do his bidding.

By now, almost the entire room is free from their chains. Several guards lie bleeding on the floor, strung over the same seats that held you in place. One by one, the freed prisoners scamper up the staircase, the only exit, to the main deck.

Wind and rain greet you. The crew, busy with keeping the ship afloat, don’t notice the herd of approaching slaves at first, not until several members get taken down, a few thrown overboard with strength built by the oar. Some of them shout for you to keep your distance. After all, their duty is to keep the ship above water. If it sinks, everyone goes down with it. The now-free slaves don’t care. Each sailor, guard, and deckhand are treated the same. Hands, shackled for many weeks, tighten into fists, fists which find their place on the crew.

The man who placed the key in your hand is leading the charge, no stranger to combat. His body is thin, but he fights with a fury far surpassing his peers. With each ship member felled, another slave arms himself with the fallen’s weapon. A few whips from below deck quickly turns into many swords and spears shared among free men.

Howling wind carries men’s screams overboard, losing them at sea, threatening to give their origin a similar treatment. The tide of slaves crashes into sailors, desperate to muster up a defense. Eventually, though, each is overwhelmed by sheer number. You’re met with a couple sailors along the way. Each, poorly trained for combat. Their skills lie elsewhere. The short sword you’ve armed yourself with makes quick work of their defense, finding gaping holes in their meager parries. The act brings a slight smile to your lips; it’s been awhile, but it’s good to see your skills haven’t deteriorated too much since the shackles were clasped around your wrists. Your mentor would have a field day if--

Your head instinctively ducks at the sudden movement in your vision. An axe plants itself in the side of the ship, not inches from where you just stood. A sailor, dressed in loose trousers and a simple shirt, unarmored, frantically tries to pry it loose, but it’s firmly in place. As you bring the short sword up to finish your opponent, a wave rocks into the boat, knocking everyone to the deck. Lightning sends a surge of brightness into the air. Upon subsiding, the sudden flash keeps lingering images, ghostly figures, in your eyes for several blinks.

“She’s going down! Hang on!” a voice carries over the wind. The storm encouragement enough, you grab onto a rope tied to the side of the ship and brace yourself. Contrasting lightning, the world slowly, gradually turns darker. As one, the deck’s combatants halt their skirmish, turning to face the looming darkness. A wave looms over the ship, building, rising higher and higher. Ominous it grows, flexing its size over the comparatively small vessel. Then, in a burst of motion, it crashes.

---

A lone wooden coffin sits on a pedestal, surrounded by bright colored flowers. Candles burn at four points around the coffin, shaped in an imaginary square. You’re lightless, floating above the pedestal as if a spirit. Simple stone blocks line the floor, and a small staircase leads up to the coffin.

The coffin calls to you. The lid is cracked slightly, daring you to peek inside. Taken by an impulse not known to you, you float closer. As you approach, the candle’s flames intensify as if oil was poured on top. The flowers, formally an array of shining yellow, red, and white, peel back at your approaching presence. They sink inside themselves, decaying and wilting on the spot. The air around you becomes heavy, filled with the moldy smell of spoiled meat.

Death follows you, child.

Your inner forearm suddenly ignites in flame. You scream, still floating in the air. The flame subsides, and left behind is the blackened image of a crow mid-flight. A woman appears at the pedestal’s steps, dressed in simple religious robes. Her face is unblemished and youthful, but her eyes speak another story; they’re black, piercing and born of experience. The woman’s long blonde hair falls perfectly past her shoulders, to a small degree like the way hair floats underwater, the loose strands never appearing to fall in front of her gaze.

Scratching softly appears from the coffin, like two rough stones rubbed against one another. The coffin, surrounded and filled with death, rumbles low, its vibrations filling the room. The woman watches silently, interested to see what you do. The scratching becomes louder, building to deafening levels. Following suit, the coffin’s vibration intensifies, shaking the wooden structure uncontrollably, the lid on top threatening, begging to be tossed from its cracked position. In a thunderous echo, the coffin falls from its position on the pedestal, tumbling down the stone steps stopping at the woman’s feet. Rolling from within--

You awaken to find a man staring at you from above, peering at you as one would over a ledge. It’s the same hazel-eyed man who released you. A burning feeling draws your attention to your arm: the image of the crow is tattooed on your forearm, aged as if it’s been there for many years, yet your arm was void of ink mere hours ago. You start to say something, but immediately water rushes from within your throat in a coughing fit. After releasing the excess sea water, you speak.

“Made it through the storm, I see.”

You see a slight grin from behind the man’s beard. “An understatement, but true all the same. Are you well to rise?”

Taking stock of your being, you nod. Swallowing sea water seems to be the worst injury inflicted, no broken bones or cracked ribs. When a ship goes down, it’s not uncommon for stray parts to land on sailors, especially when brought about by a storm’s wind. You find yourself on a beach. The sand glints in the morning sunlight, contrasting with light blue waves lightly touching the shore. Men lie scattered on the beach, along with broken pieces from the ship. The few unscathed like you, help those nursing their wounds.

“I am Ulris Joren, but you can call me Joren,” the man says, offering a hand to help you up. “A holy man from the west.”

“Which lands? The Helswith Desert?” you ask.

“Farther. Into the rolling plains.”

The plains are not unknown to you. Commonly referred to as “barbarian” land, many different tribes roam the plains waging war with one another. Conquering brings glory to their god, or something like that. You really should have remembered more from your studies. The tribesmen are looked upon as simple barbarians to city-dwelling citizens, although they would likely place that label on anyone who hunts their own food and doesn’t live within four walls.

“You’re a long way from home. Where is this place?” you ask.

Joren scratches his head in thought. “Not sure, exactly. There are many lesser-known islands such as this in King Tristrand’s land...his waters to be more accurate. With his entire nation a series of islands, it’s hard to tell.”

“We’d better move away from the beach then,” you say. “Tristrand’s ships likely patrol these waters. No doubt they’ll be searching for survivors after finding the wreckage.”

“Find a path in the jungle. I’ll work on speeding up the others’ recovery,” Joren says, emanating the green glow of healing magic from his palm.

Holy man indeed. “Neat trick,” you answer, heading for the tree line.

The jungle is dense. Vines hang from unseen, covered branches, twisting and growing around one another. Critters, out of sight, chirp, croak, and whistle as you meander through the trees. With Joren’s healing magic, all the shipwrecked prisoners walk mostly free of injury. More importantly, no injury slows down the pack. There are twenty-two of you total, a fraction of the number chained to the oar.

With no food and no water, your main priority is finding just that. Fortunately, you’re all used to eating very little, which is, perhaps, the only benefit to being under the whip. Still, you needed to find something, otherwise the miracle of surviving the shipwreck would be short-lived.

Single file, you lead the survivors, Joren behind you, through the thicket, knocking down stray foliage in your path with a walking staff picked up from the shore. It’s not nearly as efficient as a blade, but you’d rather not go out of your way to touch your exposed flesh on the plants. It’s bad enough wearing a simple loincloth and no shoes. Who knows might happen if an unidentified plant pricks your skin? You sure as hell don’t want to find out, especially if Joren’s magic doesn’t extend to toxins.

The jungle suddenly opens up into a clearing, giving you a full view of the surrounding hillside. Large stones scatter in lush grass like freckles on a spotted egg. That’s not what draws your attention, though. A single stream of smoke, emanating from a lone smokestack immediately attracts your gaze. The smokestack comes from one of three huts arranged in a semicircle, a farm at their backs.

“Smells like fuckin’ dinnertime,” one of the survivors bellows, his low voice unfitting for the thin body it originates from.

“I wouldn’t be too quick to raid,” Joren answers. “We know nothing about the island’s inhabitants.”

“Don’t your people live for raiding, priest? The Great Warlord of legend would be disappointed.”

Before the man can react, Joren grabs him by the hair and pulls his neck back, exposing it into the open air. Joren holds his pointer finger out, igniting the tip with holy flame, and holds it mere inches from his neck. “Do not mistake my caution for cowardice. You know nothing of the Great Warlord.”

Joren doesn’t wait for the man’s response before tossing him to the ground. Several other survivors help the man to his feet. He spits on the ground upon standing upright. “Stay here and starve then. We’re gettin’ ourselves some food.”

“I’m with you,” you say. Despite the circumstances, you desperately need food and water. The huts below offer both. Joren shakes his head, disapproving of the choice. You, along with most of the survivors, creep down the hillside using the scattered stones as cover. It’s not much, but it’s better than nothing. You move slowly, rather than swift, in order to blend in with the environment. Sudden movements have a way of drawing attention. You hope that moving deliberately will come across unseen over such a large span of land.

No movement emanates from the huts, the same for the farm behind. Collectively, the group decides that making for the hut with the smokestack is the best bet. Who knows? Maybe food is being prepared on the fire already. The group surrounds the hut and bursts through the front and back door simultaneously. Surprised, a woman inside drops a pan she’s holding, sending its contents scattered on the floorboards.

“We’ll be taking that food now,” the survivor leading the group says. “Among other things,” he adds with a wink and glance downward.

Expecting the woman to continue her frightened state, you’re caught off-guard when she places her hands on her hips and narrows her brow. “Now you just went and done the stupidest, motherfucking thing of your life,” she says, bending down to scoop up the pan. She shovels the food back onto the cast iron, nonchalantly as if she doesn’t notice the mob of half-naked men who barged into her hut.

“You little bitch…” the man curses as he walks forward, removing his loincloth to make good on his promise. Whirling through the air, a flash of steel appears suddenly. At the same time, the man screams and clutches his groin area. You can’t see, since his hands cover the area, but streaks of red spill from beneath. Then, you catch sight of it: a throwing dagger lies buried in the wall, pinning the man’s appendage along with it. Several more whirls of air later, you lie bleeding out on the floor, two sizable throwing knives sticking from your torso. You bleed out, half-naked and unarmed, but at least with your manhood still attached. Your assailants, unseen. The woman begins mopping up the floor.

“I’m with Joren,” you say. “We are in no position to stumble into any surprises.”

“Fine. You’ll not have any of my share,” the man answers. Most of the other survivors join with him. Maybe they are right, but with no clothes, weapons, or supplies, you’d rather not come face to face with equipped warriors or worse yet, roaming mages. The island is a perfect spot for a spellcaster to experiment without fear of collateral damage. If it’s truly uncharted in Tristrand’s waters, it also possesses, or rather lacks, law enforcement. From the 22 of you, only less than ten decide to stay with you and Joren.

You watch the man take off with most of the survivors. They creep down the hillside, making use of the scattered boulders for cover. It’s not exactly the most hidden pathway, but it’s the best they’ve got. No movement is visible from the huts, though the rising smoke means someone’s home; the only issue is finding out who exactly. Hooking a shark on the end of a fishing pole isn’t exactly ideal. They surround and enter the hut. Still, the lone stream of smoke rises.

“Why did you not join them?”

You turn around towards the direction of the voice. No one’s there. Joren and the others apparently heard it too as they’re scanning for the source as well.

“Was it wisdom? Compassion?”

The voice fades in and out, differing in volume levels, starting loud in your right ear and finishing soft in your left.

“Reveal yourself, spirit!” you shout.

There is no response to your command, save for a low chuckle that could have just been your imagination. Glass shatters, distracting your focus from seeking the voice. Smoke begins to rise at your feet, spreading too rapidly to simply be normal smoke. It fills your vision in mere seconds, preventing you from seeing the others standing next to you. Then, a sluggishness draws over your body, like a great weight is placed upon you. You collapse to one knee, refusing to fall completely. Eventually, though, it overtakes you.

---

Your body is conscious, but your vision is still black. A dark canvas hood covers your head, disallowing you to see your environment. Your wrists are bound together in front of your body, the rope, scratchy on your bare skin. Your knees ache, but you know any attempt to stand would be dealt with swiftly. The flooring beneath you is firm and unpadded. You hear breathing next to you, likely the others are next to you, hooded and bound the same.

“The settlers on this island are under our protection,” a voice speaks. It’s not the same voice as before, but a woman’s. “Your allies’ savagery have been dealt with. You did not follow in their ways. Why?”

After a moment of silence, you answer for the survivors. “We know nothing of this place. Our ship crashed on the shore.”

The woman utters half a laugh. “And here I thought you were wandering around naked for the fun of it.” Turning serious, she adds on. “Still, there’s a small matter of secrecy. You see, we can’t let our location be known to outsiders such as yourself, shipwreck or no. It’s nothing personal, really. We will make it swift. Make peace with your gods.”

A few feet away, you hear a sharp pierce and gurgle soon followed by a dull thud as a body drops to the floor. Several more times, piercing, gurgling, and thudding. Footsteps draw closer to you. They pause for a moment, allowing you to “make your peace.” Sensing motion, you reactively bring your arms up in defense.

Whirling in the air, steel clashes against steel. Light blinds you for a moment as the dark hood around your head is ripped off. A woman stands above you, dagger in hand, looking just as surprised as you are. Dark strands of hair tucked behind her ear toy with falling from their position, dark strands which appear to be unnaturally black. To your left, a throwing dagger lies buried in a wood column.

“That tattoo. Where did you get it?” the same voice from earlier rings.

Caught off guard, you attempt to explain it, but then realize you can’t really explain it. “It just...sort of appeared,” you answer with complete honesty. Next to you, Joren makes eye contact, his hood removed as well. On the other side of you, the remaining survivors can no longer be called as such.

“He bears the mark. Bring him to me. Kill the other.”

The woman raises her weapon high. Light flashes from the finely sharpened point. She thrusts forward. Vision restored, you react to the strike doing the only thing you can. Your bound hands catch the blade, slicing open your exposed palms. Steel tears into your flesh. Pressure added by the woman only deepens the fresh wounds on your hands. Fresh wounds, which still hold the originating cause. The woman attempts to press the blade into Joren, but still you hold fast stopping the point from entering his chest.

“So be it. Bring them both,” the voice appears.

The woman withdraws her attempt with a displeased look on her face.

The woman with unnaturally dark hair leads you from the room, keeping the binds around your wrists. Your hands sting due to the cuts; however, she offers no effort to mend them. Joren motions to heal with magic, but you instantly wave him off. Your new captors aren’t afraid to execute a man, and summoning magic might put them in a “stab first, ask questions later” type mood.

Expecting a low-lit basement or similar setting, you’re a bit surprised when she leads you outside into open air. You’re in a clearing, surrounded by trees. You have no doubt finding the clearing would be a tricky task, guarded by more than a few nasty traps along the way. Your destination is a single willow tree, a green chandelier sitting atop a hill. You find a man standing, facing the trunk, his back towards you. He’s dressed in a simple black robe, which serves to highlight his snow-white hair.

He turns, and you catch sight of a tattoo on the lower section of his neck. “So this is the one who bears the mark,” he comments. “Very interesting, indeed.”

“What is this place? Who are you?” you question.

“What I am about to share with you has not been spoken to outsiders in many years. That seal on your arm will be your undoing if you betray us. We live to serve the vengeful spirit, justice in the night, the woman flocked by crows, the Lady.”

“I don’t understand,” you say.

“I do,” Joren interjects. “They’re zealots, cultists. Assassins following a fairytale.”

“It’s no children’s story, I assure you,” the man speaks. “Count yourself lucky to still draw breath.”

“Why do we still draw breath?” you ask.

“For some reason unknown to me, our lady has marked you, labeling you as her own. Thus, you require training. I’ll not allow the marked to wander defenseless, not with the war happening. Your future is uncertain to me, but one thing is certain, you must be equipped to do the lady’s work.”

The training pit is an area of dirt arranged loosely in a circle. There’s a slight decline into the circle’s center, which is where the “pit” comes from. The center creates an area on level ground as well as different slopes, allowing the trainees to train on different height levels, something that one normally takes for granted. At this point, you’re unsure what to call the members of the organization. Assassins? They don’t seem particularly devoted, solely, to the shadow arts. You suppose, perhaps, their deity is, which is why they align themselves to the night.

The woman with unnaturally black hair stands your opposite. She’s armed with a dagger in either hand. You’re given a longsword and dagger. No steel is used here, the weapons are simply made from wood. Solidly built, they strike a firm blow, though not a deadly one. The woman, Morgan, weaves her two “blades” in the air as she strikes. You manage to block the attack, save for one that sneaks in stinging your ribs.

“The fact that you’re marked is beyond me,” she comments.

Her taunting words don’t land, but the blow sure does, beyond the literal sense. Feeling the pain in your ribs, you take the offensive with a series of overhead swipes and complimentary prodding with the dagger. She evades and lands two more hits on the same exact spot on your ribs.

“Yeesh,” she jabs at your wincing, the result of getting hit in the same exact place.

Ignoring Morgan’s second comment, you throw the dagger and follow up closely behind it to catch her off-guard. She knocks the projectile aside, and meets your charge with a kick to the gut, simultaneously swiping her weapons at your lower back, sending you sprawling to the ground.

She squats down over your body, resting her forearms on her knees, peering at you like a kid studying insects.

“It might be hard for a big dumb ol’ brute like yourself, but try to use smaller, quicker movements. Sharpened steel doesn’t take much force to cut.”

Morgan leaves you to ponder her words, but not before “accidentally” kicking a pile of dust into your face.

“So you’re our newest member. I’m Nathan. Come along, then. I’ll show you my preferred curriculum of texts.”

Unlike the few members you’ve actually seen, Nathan is visibly portly, even through his robes. With the high focus on combat training, you’re a bit surprised by the large figure, although spending time with your nose in books is time lost training for combat. Following behind Nathan, he leads you through aisles of scrolls carrying a lantern, which he seems to swing dangerously close, care-free, to the rolled paper parchments. One in particular catches your eye. It’s not exactly the same mark on your arm, but it’s close -- like a rustic, block version of the crow in flight. As you instinctively reach for the scroll, Nathan suddenly stops and slaps your hand away.

“Careful with those!” he scolds, spinning back around in a whirl of lantern flame. You manage a “sorry” and continue following at his back. Your destination is a dusty table stacked high with leather-bounds and scrolls.

“Knowledge equips us to do the Lady’s bidding,” Nathan explains. Seeing your face slightly curl, he adds, “Believe it or not, it’s saved my ass more than a few times. Do you know what a grema is?”

“Hunters of prey,” you answer.

“A vague answer, but you’re not technically wrong. Your answer would still get you killed, though. Survival is not simply avoiding the wrong answer; it’s about having the right one at any given moment.”

“I am not accustomed to study. My mentor--”

“Forget the customs of your past. You serve the vengeful spirit now and best learn her ways,” Nathan answers, stacking another book to the pile. Your hand reaches for the nearest book, one titled Count Otto and the Ways of Being. You find a comfortable position in the desk chair, as you’ll likely be here awhile, and flip open the cover.

The man from the willow tree unsurprisingly is the spiritual leader of the organization. You find him sitting under the same rainfall of leaves facing the trunk. His snow-colored hair gently rises and falls with his breath, the inhales expanding up, and the exhales contracting down. Sensing your presence, he turns back, making eye contact with you over his right shoulder. It’s then that you notice his eyes; they’re gray, like a blind person’s, drained of color. His head gestures to a spot next to him, so you take a seat to the side of him.

“You have been sent to us at our most desperate hour,” he speaks, still staring forward at the willow trunk.

“I wouldn’t say I was ‘sent’ exactly,” you answer. “Chained, dragged, and stumbled sound more accurate.”

A slight laugh escapes the man’s lips. “I might’ve said the same thing when I joined. The Lady acts in mysterious ways. Do you know her story?”

You shake your head and then realize the man’s eyes are still on the willow tree. As you open your mouth to answer, he continues.

“Unlike most deities, she was not born immortal. Born isn’t the right word...she wasn’t created like the others. She was once human, like you and me. She was beautiful, extremely so. Beauty has a way of turning from boon to curse during wartime, exponentially so if you’re a woman.”

You start to see where the story is going.

“At the time, a great army was assembled by a single warlord. He found a way to bring together tribes, tribes that had spent years fighting against one another, and convinced them to unite under a single banner: His. Together, he explained, they could sweep through the surrounding nations taking gold, glory, and of course, women, as they please.”

“And the lady was captured by this warlord?” you ask.

“Not just captured.”

The story hangs heavy in the air, sobering. You ponder a moment then ask, “Then how did she become immortal?”

The man rises and places a hand on your shoulder. “All in due time. But first, meditate on her capture, something that shouldn’t be hard for you to imagine.”

“Absorb the impact with your legs, lightlessly. Transfer the energy through your body instead of the floor.”

You stand at the edge of a makeshift hallway built from floorboard. It’s a simple platform, a typical floor built on springs. Putting too much pressure on one point of the floor results in a sharp creak, which are tallied up on your journey across. Morgan, the woman who was your would-be executioner, patiently waits at the end, leather flog in hand, looking eager to use it.

Your feet move on the smooth wooden “floor,” muscles flexing in your leg to absorb each step. You move slow and crouched, deliberately stepping with the balls of your feet in order to limit the surface area of your feet. Several times you’ve done the journey, each time resulting in at least three creaks. Three creaks which turn into three red marks on your back. A bead of sweat runs down the side of your face in concentration and muscular engagement. You’re almost to the end, no creaks and then--

Sharp pain rings from your feet, the result of Morgan’s mid-journey flog. Several creaks hang in the air as the sudden pain causes you to lose focus.

“Oops,” Morgan comments, nonchalantly.

Unable to control yourself, you hop down from the makeshift hallway and charge towards Morgan. The previous whipping was born of consequence: you do wrong, you pay for it. Your mind understands that. But here, mid-trial with everything running perfectly, it’s uncalled for. The device used for punishing wrong-doing is used, even though you’ve performed masterfully. That cannot be allowed to happen.

Morgan side-steps from your advance, not before sticking a foot out and spraying the leather tendrils of the flog at the back of your head. Some of the leather wraps around your head, leaving behind red cuts on your face. Sharp, sudden pain stings your face as you collapse to the ground.

After a few swings of the whip to your fallen body, causing you to curl in defense, she speaks. “Be prepared for anything. And learn to control that nasty temper of yours. It’ll get you killed.”

She emphasizes the point with a final blow and allows the lesson to sink in as she leaves.

Much time has passed since the ship crashed on the shore. In that time, you’ve devoted yourself to your training. Both food and water are in abundance, and you’re able to recover the body weight lost when the shackles clamped your wrist. The visions of the woman, this vengeful spirit, haven’t appeared since the initial visits. You haven’t mentioned either appearance to the organization. Some things are better held close to the chest. The organization’s purpose is still unclear to you. Hell, they haven’t even told you what their aspirations are. When you ask, you receive the same answer. “We do the Lady’s bidding.” In your experience, there’s always ulterior motives with religious types, even more so when strict combat training is canon.

You stand on stone steps leading into the organization’s temple, Joren next to you. You’re both dressed in ceremonial white robes, two bright spots in the dark night. You walk forward, stepping in unison, into the temple. Torches line the walls, softly illuminating a single path to the altar. Statues of past heroes fill the temple with their dancing shadows, spurred on by torchlight. The man with snow-white hair, Morgan at his side, patiently waits for you next to the altar, dressed in black. You and Joren stop just before hitting the altar’s steps.

“You have both demonstrated yourselves worthy to be brought into the family,” the man speaks. “You have shown great faith, building up your body and mind to do the Lady’s work, despite the questions lingering in your mind. Questions, that will be answered tonight.”

Joren turns slightly, making eye contact with you, excitement showing in the hazel.

Morgan steps forward. “Count yourselves lucky. The ritual will open a pathway to the Lady’s power...if you survive. You’ve perhaps seen minor glimpses of it.” Her voice fades in and out of existence, starting soft then finishing near deafening levels. It’s still her voice, yet it’s mixed with a deeper one, speaking the same words simultaneously. You feel the hairs on your neck stand up as she readies a mixing bowl, tossing in different elements and liquids.

Morgan peers at you, her gaze unflinching while at work. Contrasted with her unnaturally black hair, her green eyes seem extra bright, although the color is slightly cloudy, two hazy emeralds. Her eyes grow bigger, transitioning into a single glowing center. Light and surrounding color flow into the viridian center as if a waterfall rushing into a pit. Your mind slowly loses focus, your body numb and lightless. The world spins out of control in a swirl of shadowy green. A single white light shines in the distance, emanating from the center of the swirl. Like a ship with full wind in its sails, you fly towards the light at increasing speed.

Suddenly, the world stops. You’re so close to the white light, from where the source is, that it forces you to shut your eyes completely. Still, it shines through, and you cover your hands over your eyelids and fall to your knees, angling your face in the ground to escape the brightness. Despite your attempts to shield, it’s like someone is forcing your eyelids open staring directly at the sun. Warmth rushes over your body, lessing the pain slightly, or at least distracting you from it momentarily. It soothes your skin like a mother’s touch, letting you know everything is going to be ok.

You must be made to see.

An unseen power pulls you from your fallen state and floats your body in the air. You can’t move your limbs; a great weight is placed upon them. The power pries your eyelids open, fixing them on the source of light. Stiff and suspended in the air, white rays rush into your eyes and mouth. You attempt to scream, but nothing comes out. You can’t breathe, despite clawing and trying to suck in air. Panic sets in as if you’re underwater, losing air, and can’t reach the surface. Face to face, the woman reaches out with an ethereal hand in comfort and--

You’re back meeting Morgan’s gaze.She holds the mixing bowl out for you to drink. Something’s different. You’re different. A feeling of restlessness rushes into your mind. Morgan looks at you expectantly, still holding the bowl out. Inside, black liquid sits waiting for you to consume.

Dark storm clouds fill the sky, a steady drizzle falling through the air. Ahead several fires burn, the result of the battle won. A horde of men stand circling the Warlord, dressed in scraps of leather and animal skin. The Warlord wears an armored crown of antlers, rising in jagged streaks of lightning. His back holds a warhammer, one that an average man would have difficulty swinging. The Warlord has no such trouble.

The Warlord raises his arms in victory and bellows a warcry. Thunder booms in the heavens simultaneously, spurring the horde into greater levels of their echoed cries. Metal clashes against metal, feet stomp the ground as the horde passionately allows the world to hear their victory.

As if waves receding on the shore, the horde parts, allowing a pathway to the Warlord. Several high ranking members, commanders of the Warlord’s legions, walk the path with tribute in hand. They kneel before the man, placing priceless artifacts, jewelry, and gems. Ceremonial, golden weapons are offered at the Warlord’s feet. With each offering, the Warlord places a hand on the commander’s shoulder in gratitude.

Then you see her.

She’s bound at the wrists, clothes ripped into tattered cloth hanging loosely from her shoulders. Her blonde hair, normally lightless, hangs heavy, matted with dirt and blood, matching the rest of her body. She’s led by a collar at her neck, connected by a leash of chain. She’s led down the pathway, surrounded by the horde, to the Great Warlord. She’s tossed to the ground, briefly exposing sections of her body meant to be kept private. The Great Warlord eyes the woman, a creeping smile slowly expanding on his lips, his lips which he freshly licks in anticipation. The woman looks up, past the warlord, past the horde even, to you, floating above the scene.

Desperation glints, yet she utters not a word. It’s then that you see the man holding the chain, the leash fastened to the collar around her neck. Joren.

“Well,” Morgan says. “Will you partake?”

Your eyes turn to Joren. His face is expressionless and somber.

“I won’t ask again.”

Your hands grip the bowl, and you take it from Morgan’s grasp. Behind you, dancing shadows from the statues fill the room. The bowl is cold to the touch, despite being in Morgan’s hands. It’s the feeling of cold steel early in the morning. You take a deep breath and drink from the bowl’s contents. Out of the corner of your eye, you see a pleasing look from the man with white hair, the man from the willow tree. It tastes like liquid fire, smoky, a burning far more severe than any brandy. It’s tar-like and thick with unknown ingredients, most of which aren’t liquid, floating at the top.

Dizziness overtakes your body, and you struggle to stand upright. The world starts to spin as if you were hanging upside down. Movement flashes to your left. A figure of a man explodes into motion. Suddenly, the shadowy room is filled with blue light. Cold electricity fires from the man’s fingertips -- from Joren’s fingertips. The blast knocks the snow-haired man and Morgan from their feet, falling over the other side of the altar.

Instinctively, you swing at Joren. He easily evades the strike, hooking your arm and tossing you over his hip. Fire rises up around you, the blue light replaced with orange flame. Sections of the ceiling start to collapse, the structure unable to remain upright with the flames eating at its support columns. In small explosions of fire, wood, and stone, debris crashes to the floor around you. Joren takes a look at you, debating internally, and then snatches you by the collar of your robe. He drags you from the burning temple, marking your white robe with blood and dirt.

Joren leaves you several feet from the burning remains of the temple. Still disoriented, you barely decipher the words he leaves you with. “Consider my debt paid. You saved my life, and now I saved yours.” He escapes into the surrounding forest, leaving you behind to witness the destruction of the Lady’s temple.

His wounds healed, Paxson’s return to training wasn’t easy. Weeks of being bed-ridden had deteriorated his muscles. The broad-shouldered gladiator who rose to the top of the school, was replaced with a lanky, easily-gassed dreg for the others to climb over. And climb over him, they did. You don’t survive in a gladiatorial school without stepping on others for position. While they share the same training areas and living spaces (cages), there is no loyalty between gladiators. It’s every man for himself, all in search of the most treasured prize: freedom.

Men who he had embarrassed in sparring sessions, return the favor sevenfold upon his return. Their previous lessons, learned from the sharp sting of the practice sword, were enacted back on their “teacher.” Paxson gladly took each lesson, after all, he did start in their position once upon a time. This time, however, his mind is sharp with victory in the arena. Wisdom guides his ferocity, tempering it into a sharpened weapon with deadly purpose.

Slowly, day by day, improvement was made. His sword arm grew strong again, no longer weighted by the weapon. The sword, an extension of his arm, was now raised as easily as pointing a finger. Hardened muscle built back into his shield arm, absorbing blows that would deaden most into abandoning the protective weapon. With her on his mind, Paxson holds an unstoppable will. No amount of beatings, bruises, or cuts will stop his determination to see her again. She was taken from him, and he will make them pay.

Late one evening as he practices his form, a guard summons him across the training sand. Planting the wooden tip of the training sword into the sand, he runs over to the leather armored wearing house guard.

“Master Arroden wants to see you, slave.”

Paxson is used to such jabs and is aware of the punishment for defending one’s honor. Despite felling tens of men in the arena, his ego isn’t at a level where verbal provocation sends him into a fury. He saves that fury for the arena.

Arroden waits for the gladiator in his study. A large map rests on the center table. In the top eastern corner of the map, Paxson sees King Tristrand’s islands, some uncharted and unexplored, but all lie within the might of Tristrand’s fleet. The islands lie just opposite of the Breckenridge Channel, a small body of water connecting the Helswith Desert to Tristrand’s “land.” To the western edge of the Helswith border, a large land body is colored red and is sweeping towards the desert.

“You were military before arriving here,” Arroden speaks flatly. “What do you make of it?”

Paxson eyes the map once more, well aware of the guards behind him keeping a steady hand on their hilts. “The lands to the west are being overrun. Who does the red represent? I do not see a sigil or coat of arms associated.”

“They do not have a unifying banner. The barbarian tribes in the west have banded together on a warpath,” Arroden says as if one explaining soft notes in a red wine.

“Impossible. There is too much infighting between tribes to organize anything, especially something of this magnitude. The tribes have only unified once, under the Great Warlord of old. And we all know how that turned out,” Paxson answers, drawing attention to the wave of red expanding east.

“Oh but they have,” Arroden says, pouring a goblet of his favored honeyed wine. He offers a glass to Paxson, who takes it. You don’t say no to the master. “Copies of this map have been dispersed to all nobility within Helswith. High Lord Ursa is offering substantial reward for any warriors that can be ‘volunteered’ into service, seasoned gladiators highly sought after. The High Lord’s already conscripted those he can into his ranks.”

Paxson glances down at the map again. The wave of red, the barbarian horde, is mere miles away from entering the desert. To his knowledge, the High Lord’s army isn’t vastly numberable, but their chariots are deadly to face in open ground. Between the chariots and extreme conditions of the desert, High Lord Ursa’s land seems well-defended. Still, in war, sheer number can overtake the most disciplined of armies defending key positions. It all depends on how many bodies are thrown at accomplishing the goal. Paxson has no doubt the horde is willing to throw as many as necessary.

“The battleground is vastly different from the arena,” Paxson says. “There’s too many factors that a gladiator is untrained for. I fear you might lose some good men if you sell our services to the High Lord. Besides, half the men would desert, you know that.”

“Of course I know that,” Arroden sharply says. “Which is why I’m only sending you. Your wife's return is tethered to my efforts. I hold nothing over the other men; you can only beat a dog so much. But you, I know you’d never betray me. If you did, your precious woman’s return might not be such a favorable change.”

“When am I to depart?”

“Five days. Try not to injure yourself in the meantime.”

You awaken to find a pair of angry green eyes staring back at you, framed with unnaturally black hair. As you attempt to sit up, your face eats a punch from the woman, knocking you back down.

“Did I say you could move, betrayer?” Morgan breathes. You quickly glance at your surroundings. The burned remains of the temple sit quietly behind her, charred, cold and ominous.

“Joren?” you ask. Bringing up the man’s name earns you another blow, this one, a kick to the gut. Morgan squats back down to peer at you closer.

“Gone.”

“And the others?”

Morgan utters half a laugh. “What others? There are no others. There’s never been.”

The news causes you to sit up again, and this time, you don’t get knocked back down. “But I saw other members about. Nathan, the portly librarian for one.”

“Tricks of the trade,” Morgan answers. “Killian’s specialty. ‘Projecting,’ he called it. In fact, your other ‘friends’ got to witness it first-hand when they visited the farm. This entire island is abandoned, save for Killian and I… well, now it’s you and me.” The sudden mention of Killian and her distracts Morgan for a few seconds, but you’re soon sure to be the object of her wrath again. So that’s his name, the man with the white hair meditating at the willow tree: Killian. Strange how you never learned that until now.

“He’s gone then?” you ask.

“A lightning blast to the chest will do that.”

“So where does this leave us?” you question. “If you wanted me dead, you could have just slit my throat while I was out.”

“The thought did pass my mind, I assure you that,” Morgan answers. She peers into your eyes still, sparkling green pupils locked with your dark brown. “But Killian saw something in you. In his memory, I will spare your life.”

Morgan not-so-gently steps on your chest with a black boot, standing fully upright. She towers over your prone body as if a lighthouse over a cliff. “I’m going after him,” she says. “The spirit of vengeance guides me. Are you coming?”

“I’m with you."

You imagine there might be a time when you disclose your visions to Morgan. After all, she’s the only one, at least that you know of, that serves the woman who visits you. And there’s the small matter of the “sight” given to you just before the ritual. It was almost as if you knew what was going to happen. Not specifically, of course, but the scene in your mind played out eerily similar. Killian might have been the one to help you understand as he was in the master’s role. It dawns on you that your relationship with Morgan might turn out the same: a teacher and learner, one to instruct, and the other to follow.

“Let’s not delay, then. Our prey was picked up by one of Tristrand’s ships,” Morgan says, offering a hand to help you up. At the last second, the open palm clenches into a fist, a fist which kindly re-introduces itself to your face. “You deserve that and more,” she spits.

As you rise on your own accord, Morgan walks to a nearby tree. Two travel packs are already filled with supplies and sitting at the base of the trunk. She picks up both and tosses one behind her, almost taking your head off. One of your hands catches the leather straps mid-flight, and you swing the entire thing onto your back.

Still unspeaking, she leads you from the ruined remains of the temple and into the surrounding forest. Twisting through several scarcely visible trails, taking a couple of hours, the dense forest opens into the edge of a cliff overlooking the sea. Scattered like stones on a hill, islands mark the water, creating spots of green in the ocean blue.

Morgan scans through the bushes, searching for something, and finally she pulls two large coils of rope securely fastened, or rather, welded, to a large boulder. Two packs, two coils of rope, she knew this day was coming, but somehow you didn’t imagine she imagined it’d be you. Killian, most likely. She throws you a coil and begins to suspend herself over the cliff’s edge. You glance down at the sheer mountainside, taking note of the jagged, spear-like rocks waiting for you in the water. Taking a deep breath, you follow suit.

Instantly, cold misty air hits you, built from the crashing waves below. You take extra care to keep a firm grasp on the rope as the going gets slippery the further down you are, a result of being closer to the water. Like rowing on the slave transport, your eyes remained focused on what’s in front of you, in this case, a rocky cliff, layered with strands of vine and your straw-colored rope. No sense in looking down. There’s a small beach at the bottom, which is off to the side, enclosed, in an underhang of rock. Moored where the water and sand meet is a small, two-person fishing vessel.

“Come,” Morgan says. “Tristrand will know the whereabouts of our target.” Shipmasters, they’re all the same, keeping charts and logs of voyage details. If anyone has a record of Joren’s passage, it’s the man with access to the entire fleet. King Tristrand.

Ships and smaller sea vessels fill the water, traveling closely together like schools of fish. The island, crescent-mooned in shape, is one large harbor on the concave side. Countless docks stick out from the land, some mixing with one another creating a puzzle-like shape. Large galleons and warships have their own dock, while civilian fishing boats and barges fight for open space. As luck would have it, one angry-looking fisherman sets sail when you float near, allowing you and Morgan to steal the space while others are left waiting in the water.

Behind the row of docks is a city with winding streets and closely packed buildings. The buildings are a tan color with red, tile rooftops. Further up beyond the city sits a massage stronghold.. From your view you count five walls, a pentagon. Heavy cannons line the walls, and you have no doubt it’s hiding more firepower within.

Morgan drops two coins into the hand of an approaching bean counter and motions for you to follow.

“I’m unfamiliar with this area of the world,” you say, walking briskly to catch up to her pace. Damn does she walk fast. “What name does the city go by?”

“Le’lune Aethas. It means ‘the scythe of the seas’ in the ancient tongue. Though most people just call it Lune,” Morgan answers, eyes forward, walking briskly. Passing through the winding streets, ignoring peddlers, street vendors, and some very direct and rather vulgar “companions,” you head straight for the keep.

Soldiers patrol the five walls. More are posted outside. Their uniform is naval, prioritizing movement with cloth pants and leather boots. Royal blue, no less. The vast majority only wear light leather protection, although you do see some with shiny steel breastplates. The officers, if you had to guess. While the keep’s gate is raised, a guard stops you from entering.

“Halt,” he commands, holding a tanned hand up, palm facing toward you. “What business do you have in the Crow’s Nest?”

A fitting name for a keep overlooking the entire island. You know it’s based on a ship, but the mention of “crow” is oddly fitting, like a quiet confirmation you’re on the correct path.

“We’re searching for a man. A man picked up by one of your lord’s ships,” Morgan explains.

“And you think we just give out records to anyone who walks up demanding it?” the guard questions, raising an eyebrow for emphasis.

You intervene. “No, of course not. Not to just ‘anyone.’ My father is Arroden Scholhart. Heard of him? The man we pursue is of great interest to my father, and he is willing to pay well should the information from the records pan out.”

Morgan’s face darkens for a moment, then returns back to its blank state. No doubt she’s gauging if you’re lying or not. The guard does the same, but isn’t willing to risk offending the son of a renown gladiator school, even if the house does lie in another nation. Along with wealth, that profession is typically paired with a short fuse.

“Right this way then, young master,” the guard answers, motioning to the open gate. You stride ahead, first, in front of Morgan.

The sight, your new-found power from the temple, tingles. It’s the feeling on your skin when static energy is in the air, like the hairs on your arm are standing up. Something about the man calls to you. A secret that wants to be shared, but is too afraid to be spoken. For the second time in your life, you draw on that power.

Your vision darkens, transitioning to a dark purple, then to a deep black. Wind, clouds, smoke. At once, they rush through your sight as if you’re falling from a clifftop, only in a horizontal direction. Your body isn’t physically moving, but your mind races through...wherever this is at an alarming pace. You pick up speed, rushing to a level where your eyes begin to dry, causing a build-up of tears in response. As the tears roll down your cheeks, your movement is suddenly halted.

The man, the guard floats next to you, unseen by the people before you. Like previous visions, you’re able to survey the scene before you from above, lightlessly floating. This time, however, the guard is the same as you. A child, the younger version of the guard sits at a crudely constructed table, an older man next to him. His father, if you had to guess.

The man addresses the child. “Son, we need money, and the navy is willing to pay it. I know things have been difficult since your mother...left us, but this is the best thing for us. Can you be a good boy and tend to the horses for me?”

The kid nods. “Yes, Father. Do you really have to go?”

“You can’t serve in the navy from the comfort of your living room. I’ll be back. Promise. Six months tops.”

With that, the older man gets up and places a kiss on the child’s, the guard’s, forehead. After a reassuring squeeze of the shoulder, he exits the home. You get the feeling that’s the last time the child saw him.

Another guard meets you inside the gate, wearing royal blue and carrying a longspear. He doesn’t speak, but a quick head motion signals follow me. The keep’s courtyard is lined with a sandy brick, the stones closely aligned as to create a smooth floor. Tristrand’s men don’t show it, but you know every eye is on you and Morgan. The Crow’s Nest doesn’t seem to get many visitors. A quick march takes you to the keep’s main doors, a pair of sturdy wooden things reinforced with cross beams of steel. The march takes you inside.

Deep blue greets you upon entering. The floor is dyed a dark, ocean blue like the color of water with low depth, the color of water where unseen, undocumented predators swim, where few explore and survive. Instead of being taken directly to the throne room where you can speak to the king, you’re brought to a separate chamber, not far off from the main doors.

It’s a small room. Only enough room for two rickety chairs behind a desk assembled from driftwood. The desktop is mostly flat, although different colored and shaped driftwood sometimes jut out in weird spots, one of which is directly in the center like an antler was nailed to the desk.

“I get the feeling we’re not about to meet the king,” you whisper to Morgan. She silently agrees with what looks like a borderline pout.

The door to the room opens and slams just as quickly. A portly man enters, red beard running down at the edges of his face, though not quite completing the connection to a thin moustache. Despite his loose clothing, rolls of fat move with each movement, which are surprisingly dexterous for someone of his size. He slams down a massive leather book on the table, creating a similar sound to the door shutting. The book narrowly misses the desk antler, or in this case, pike.

“So you’re searching for a man. What makes you think we give out records to the public?” the man says, fashioning a pair of tiny glasses to his nose, the frames barely wider than his pupils.

“Justice,” Morgan answers. “The man we seek is a murderer. He killed our...teacher. One of your vessels picked him up from an unnamed island.”

“And just who do you think you are? Taking the law into your own hands. The punishment for murder is a death at sea,” the portly man replies. Seeing your confusion, he continues. “Why bother the hangman when a heavy rock, rope, and deep waters are at your disposal?

“No arguments here,” you answer. “But still, in order to uphold the king’s law, you need to locate the murderer first. Think of it as our civic duty, helping to locate a criminal.”

“Alas, no,” the man says, readjusting his glasses. “I’m afraid we cannot allow every vengeance-seeker to carry out his deeds, no matter how ‘righteous.’ Leave me a description of the man, and I will make sure our men are on the look-out. There are two of you claiming witness to his crime. That’s good. Along with a description, leave your names and residence. We’ll contact you once he’s brought in. Now I’m done here, unless you have further questions?”

“What are the chances you’ll find the man we seek?” you ask.

The man stands, heading towards the door, obviously thinking that you had no further questions. “Hard to say. We’ll know more once you leave a description of the man. My lord’s waters are vast, spanning the majority of the sea. There are many unnamed islands such as the one you claim to have come from.”

“It’s not some fairy tale,” Morgan answers. “We can show you the evidence.”

“Unfortunately, that will not do either. If you have the coordinates of the island along with the date you think one of my lord’s ships picked up this man, then that will narrow our search. I really must be going. Leave the information on the parchment I left on the table, and see yourselves out. Good day.”

The portly man slips out of the small room, making it seem less small. As you sit up to write on the parchment, Morgan stops you. “He’s hiding something.”

“People in his position are always hiding something,” you answer.

“Yes, but he knows something about Joren.” Morgan spits the man’s name with obvious distaste. “He couldn’t wait to get out of here.”

“Just because he doesn’t want to spend his time with us doesn’t mean he’s actively aiding Joren’s escape...but he did seem rather shifty, didn’t he?”

“Exactly. And I plan to find out what he knows.”

Somehow you don’t think Morgan’s decision involves holding to King Tristrand’s laws.

You and Morgan leave the Crow’s Nest and journey back to the main hub of Lune. Part of you knew it wouldn’t be easy to waltz into a king’s keep and demand information, but the other part naively believed you would find the information you sought after. Back to the winding streets you go, searching for a place to reconvene and plan your next steps.

The streets are packed with citizens and shops. A place such as this relies heavily on importing and exporting goods to survive. While King Tristrand’s territory may be large, the amount of land mass is on the smaller side. Food, clothing, even jewelry needs to be brought in from other lands. It’s no wonder that the streets are constantly abuzz with sale. The same street vendors and peddlers yell towards you as you walk past, promising their goods will change your life. One comment about “sprucing up the bedroom” with their product earns a nasty look from Morgan.

Suddenly, the crowd seems to move as one, parting down the center like the crease of a leather-bound book. Blue uniforms appear. Soldiers from King Tristrand’s navy rush past in a thunderous stomping of boots and heavy breathing. The climb from the docks isn’t a short one, and, well, it’s a climb to reach the Crow’s Nest.

Unlike a coordinated march, the soldiers in royal blue run scattered, allowing for the faster ones to not be held back by the slower. Still, none are slow, just some slower than others. A mix between soldier and sailor, Tristrand’s naval men are built with lean muscle from manning their vessels. A ship can only hold a limited amount of food, so the soldiers need to condition their body to work without an excess of nutrition.

“What do you think that’s about?” you ask Morgan shortly after the final blue uniform passes.

“I’m sure we’ll find out soon enough,” she answers. “In the meantime, we have work to do. I don’t intend to leave this place without answers. We need to find an inn and gather some equipment.”

“Equipment for what?” you question, fully knowing the answer.

“Like I said, I’m not leaving here without answers, and they’re sitting behind lock and key in the Crow’s Nest. Ready to put your training to the test?”

“I made it through your instruction. This should be easy in comparison.”

Your reply earns you a smirk from Morgan. The first one you’ve witnessed unharmed.

“I’ll find us a decent place to rest. You’d better get the equipment as you obviously have something in mind,” you say. “Meet back here in three hours?”

Morgan nods, sending a few loose strands of black hair bobbing. She takes off down the street, walking with purpose. That’s not normally the way you’d describe a person’s steps, but hers are intentional, deliberate, straight-forward. There’s no swaying of the arms or casually glance side-to-side with her head. She’s heading towards a destination as if wearing blinders, ignoring the noise around her. Strange woman. Beautiful woman. Deadly woman.

Finally, you’re alone. Somehow it feels relaxing without the constant eyes of Morgan upon you. Not that you’re at odds, it’s just that you don’t quite feel like allies yet. You’re thrust together by necessity. A man lies dead, a temple destroyed in the process, and the blame lies mostly with you, at least according to Morgan. The crow on your arm, the tattoo burned into your skin signifying the Lady’s mark: it’s the only reason why you’re still breathing. Joren was to be executed when Morgan and Killian first captured you, and what happened? You saved his life. You wonder what would have been, should you have stood back and let Joren die.

No. That’s not who you are. Weak men stand idly, too afraid to act. True, your act may have, in a sense, doomed Killian and the order, but the blame lies with Joren and his decision. You can’t be at fault for that, despite what Morgan may think. If she needs to view you as the object of her blame, so be it. You can’t change that.

Walking in thought, you end up staring at a sign post marked SEA BREEZE. Showing signs of blue and white paint, it’s almost completely void of its original color.
