Small skirmishes such as this one became a common occurrence. Squadleader Pralthar stands at the center of the V, issuing commands and dropping approaching barbarians with his greatbow. His open helm allows for a full view of the battlefield, the back of the helm sporting animal hair which travels down his mid-back. His greatbow, something that many would have difficulty drawing full-length, is handled with ease as he nocks another arrow.

“Hold steady! They’re testing our position for a weakness. Give them nothing,” Pralthar shouts, loosing an arrow flying not ten feet above Paxson’s head. Normally the gladiator would be uncomfortable with someone firing so close, but he’s come to trust in the squadleader’s aim.
Three barbarians gather around Paxson, meaning to punch through the Reapers’ formation head-on. Paxson readies himself, crouching low, ready to explode into movement. The two men at his side do the same, raising their tower shields high and bringing their spears to attack position.

The barbarians attack.

Paxson meets their offense, stepping forward from the formation, to the angry outburst of the hulking man at his left. Instantly, the man slides up, taking point, while the line behind him follow to close the gap. Paxson, exposed, separate from the V formation, engages the barbarians. His buckler knocks a wild axe swing aside, creating an opening for his spear. Before he can take advantage, Paxson’s instincts urge him to dodge to the right. In a roll, a short throwing spear flies harmlessly through the air where Paxson once stood, bouncing from a Reaper’s tower shield behind Paxson.

As the thrower struggles to draw his weapon, Paxson lunges forward, thrusting the point of his spear through the man’s chest. His spear, firmly stuck in the man’s chest is abandoned. Paxson draws his short sword to meet the remaining two. The Reapers, at Squadleader Pralthar’s command, switch their tactic, organizing into a marching, offensive formation. Paxson redirects another incoming axe, and slashes his sword at the man’s throat, causing a gurgle and instantly dropping the man. Before his body hits the ground, Paxson raises his buckler high and thrusts his short sword underneath, simultaneously, at the remaining barbarian’s assault. Another gurgle. Another body to the dirt.

The Reapers, now caught up to Paxson, stop a moment behind him.

“You know the drill, slave,” the hulking man from earlier, K’rell speaks. Paxson nods, jogging to put some distance between him and the soldiers.

“Forward march!” Pralthar yells. The Reapers take the offensive.

Strange to be back. After many years, you’re finally returning to your homeland. The Helswith Desert. Part of you wonders the state of your father’s house, while another part seeks to block it from your mind. No sense in living in the past, even if your curiosity is piqued.

The boat ride took several days. Morgan spent most of her time at the ship’s bow, overlooking the water, free from interacting with the sailors. You spent your time above deck as well, subconsciously finding new places to pass the time: a result of your latest boat journey and the shackles that accompanied. The captain, a man that rode the border between jolly and social ineptitude, gave you both space, something that you and Morgan both needed.

The warm air of the Helswith greets you upon landing. After dropping payment off with the captain, you step onto the dock, one built from stone, and journey towards the central hub of the city. According to your findings in Lune, this is where the Tristrandian captain ported, the place where his mysterious guest disappeared.

As far as cities go, it feels empty. Sure, the streets aren’t vacant. Shops line both sides. Servants and slaves alike carry goods for their masters, some holding the reigns of pack animals. Still, the population seems low, like the crowd of a traveling circus after a few performances in the same town.

“Something about this place is off,” Morgan comments, striding next to you holding her pack with one hand, slung over her shoulder.

“Yeah, where are all the people?” you wonder aloud.

“What’re you new? They’re all at the western front.” The voice answering your question comes from a man sitting on the ground, leaning against a post, one that is meant for tying animals to. A beggar.

“Ursa has mobilized that many?” you ask.

“That’s High Lord Ursa. You better get used to stating his title, otherwise his guards might have some fun with you. Then again, they’re all at the border! Ha-ha!” the beggar says with a widening grin.

“We know of the tribesman horde in the west,” Morgan steps in. “We know they have banded together, somehow. The fact those savages can even stand next to one another without slaughtering each other is a miracle.”

“Ahh, apparently you think you know of the horde. Then why did you ask where all the people were?” the beggar retorts, scratching at a beard far past the regular grooming stage.

“Enough of this. I have no time for games,” Morgan answers, starting to walk down the street. As you turn to follow, a strong grip wraps around your wrist twisting your forearm open. In a blink, your sleeve is rolled up to expose the tattoo, the one placed by the Lady herself.

“Interesting ink you have there, traveler,” the beggar says, articulating his speech much clearer than before. “Some would call it a blessing, others a curse.”

“And what do you call it?” you ask, allowing the man to keep his grip. If he turns violent, you are ready, but you won’t be the first to escalate things. What’s the honor in striking a beggar, especially landing the first blow?

“Depends on who bears it,” he answers. “A blessing to some, a curse to others. It’s relative, depending on who you ask.”

“You speak in circular riddles. We’ve come back to the very beginning. I don’t know what you’re after, but you’ll not make a jest of me,” you say, twisting your arm from his hold.

“I’m not surprised one bound by shackles is uncomfortable with a firm grip on the arm. I grow tired of your presence. Leave me be,” the beggar replies, waving his hand at you as if batting a fly, a nuisance away.

Strange way to end a conversation, even more so when you remember he was the one initiating it. Your past is no secret to those with the ability to interpret, not just with a seer’s sight either. Scars at your wrist point to either slavery or incarceration. The tattoo, while mysteriously appearing, draws eyes as most markings do, self-imposed or otherwise. See. The words spoken by the Lady resonate in your mind. You must be made to see. Still, you have little experience in the matter. “Seeing” goes both ways. You aren’t sure what happens if your new-found power is noticed...and used against you.

The world flashes a bright light. A streak of blue reaches down from the sky, crackling with electric energy, the heavens otherwise dark, filled with black storm clouds. Wind sweeps by, pulling bits of dust from the ground, swirling them into miniature tornadoes. You’re on a hill, a familiar one, only it’s hardly recognizable. It’s the place of your training.

Around you, the landscape lies dead. Where a green treeline once surrounded, black, jagged trunks stand, void of leaves. Their bark is blackened, burned. Silent they stand, surrounding you, no sign of life. The largest one stands directly in front of you. Its scarred remains bear a resemblance to the willow tree.

You begin to approach the willow tree. Then you discover a man squatting beneath it. He’s crouched low on the balls of his feet, resting his arms on his knees. His body has a slight sway to it, like leaves in the wind. As you draw closer, the dark hair on the man slowly fades from color, transitioning to a snowy white. You realize his hair wasn’t actually black; it was dyed and filled with soot.

The man turns at your presence, motioning for you to sit next to him. You take a seat beneath the scarred tree. Still staring forward, the man speaks.

“Death. The death of our home, the death of the order, the death of me. All caused by you.”

Killian.

“Caused by Joren,” you correct.

“Who rescued his life? From that moment, his actions were your responsibility. The burden of death lies with you.”

“His actions are his own, separate from mine. Blame me all you want, but there’s no mistaking that fact. Does a parent take responsibility for the sins of their children? I may have stopped the blade, but he was always at your mercy. You could have finished the job. And I’m not shifting the blame. It all lies on Joren.”

Your words don’t seem to sit well with the man, with the image of Killian. His head slowly turns your direction, moving focus away from the dead willow. As his eyes meet yours, you realize the man, while he may look like Killian, is not the man. His eyes, primal, appear not to blink, continuing to stare into yours.

“You’re not him,” you state.

A grin appears at the false Killian’s mouth, spreading wide, revealing a set of decaying teeth within his mouth. “No. And his work will never be fulfilled through you. You should have trusted your instinct not to come here.” He lunges forward with a snarl, hitting your body to the ground, landing on top with your arms pinned at your sides. You try to struggle, to kick him off, but he’s too strong. You might as well be bound to the ground. His eyes, a pair of primal senses, find your neck. His teeth closely follow.

You turn to leave. After taking a few steps, you stop, looking to address the beggar one final time. He’s gone. The place where he once sat is empty, well, of him it’s empty. A passing citizen struggles to tie his pack animal to the post. The animal, a mirshka, is carrying more than its weight on its carapace-like back and struggles in defiance at its owner’s direction, firmly stomping its six hooves into the ground. Strange. There are not many who can slip from your detection, especially after training on the island.

“Gods,” Morgan curses. “That must have been a member of the Dreamwalkers.”

“The who?” you ask.

“The Dreamwalkers, or Walkers. Rivals of sorts. No, ‘rival’ implies some level of shared ground. They are enemies of the Lady, seeking to disrupt her work. Killian must have mentioned the war with you. Well, it’s with them.”

She continues explaining as you approach a horse trader. The man stands behind a row of horses, displaying the individual animals, each with their own small stable. His curved hat, made of straw, curls down to his shoulders, protecting him from the Helswith heat. He calmly twirls one end of his dark moustache as you approach. Ignoring the man, you listen to Morgan.

“The war is not a traditional one. Not in the sense of simply killing one another. There’s a much deeper goal. Killing is easy. Walkers seek to harvest our power…one they share to a degree, but not like ours. Theirs is a watered-down version, attained with magical artifacts. To the commoner, it’s the same, but to us it’s an abomination.”

“Why not just kill them?” you ask, watching Morgan place coins into the horse trader’s palm. “What do you seek from them?”

“Knowledge,” she answers. “Imagine if we could enhance the Lady’s work with the artifacts they bear. Our few numbers would mean nothing. And I know your next question. No, using the artifacts isn’t the abomination. It’s using the Lady’s gifts against her will that’s the true sin.”

“Again, I’ll ask: Why not just kill them? You could take the artifacts from their bodies.”

Morgan sighs, casually directing the horse trader to throw saddles on the newly-purchased animals. “That’s the problem. Each is somehow tied to the user. When the body dies, the artifact crumbles to dust. There’s a reason why the order keeps a low number. Certainly there would be strength if more were trained, but that’s a double-edged sword.”

“More numbers means more potentially harvested by the Dreamwalkers,” you comment. “Aiding the order could mean directly aiding the Walkers.”

Morgan nods. “Exactly. Killian is fond of keeping it at two. It used to be much higher, tens, even hundreds of members at one point. With a population that high, it’s hard to truly know each one. Where do you think the Dreamwalkers came from? A tainted sect of the order, only they didn’t master the initiation rite. It’s more than a ceremonial graduation. It’s when the Lady blesses us with her power. Two is where Killian liked to keep it. We’ve had up to five at one point. That’s still a manageable number. But the order has thrived the best when only holding two.”

“It’s less of an order, and more like a couple,” you say, intending to point at the quantity, rather than the relational meaning of the word.

“Don’t get any ideas,” Morgan says, pulling herself on her horse. You do the same next to her.

“Wouldn’t dream of it,” you answer.

After visiting a few taverns, watering holes where gossip is exchanged for coin, you discovered a recent tale of a mysterious man arriving into town. Hazel eyes with a tendency to burn those in his path. Sounds familiar. The story, according to one heavyset barkeep with thick sideburns, is that the man, Joren, you’re sure, got into a disagreement with several of his patrons. All were more than a few deep at that point, the hazel-eyed man more than the rest. It wasn’t anything too unfamiliar, although the lesser amount of guards have resulted in alteration escalation on a few occasions, this being one of them. “Without none of them shiny spears, men got nothin’ to fear,” the barkeep said.

Everything was running smoothly. Sure, the night’s patrons were a little more indulged than normal, but that’s good for business. Talk of the war overtook the place. It started as mere rumblings, men discussing the most recent news from the western border.

“That topic is always on everyone’s tongue,” according to the barkeep. “Hard not to think of it with the streets bein’ this empty. The men left behind, that weren’t recruited for the High Lord’s army, are all essential to the economic well-being of the nation. They’re craftsmen, mostly. Possessing skills above the commoner. Too important to allow their brains to spill from their skull on the western front. Me? I’m the most important of them all. Their well-being relies on me!”

You had to politely get the man back on track.

“One night, the boys were getting a little patriotic. The hazel-eyed man had been here before. More than a few times, actually. He never speaks to anyone. Just drinks silently at the end of the bar, back in the corner. Normal discussion of the war effort took place. Soon, it built into a love for king and country. All were getting in on it, except the hazel-eyed man of course. He soon joined, though. Just not in the same way as the others. In fact, it was the exact opposite. Insults started being hurled at the ‘New Great Warlord,’ the one who united all the tribes. Reports say he’s a direct descendant of the one of old. Well, at least they say he claims that. Soon as that started,” the barkeep shook his head. “All hell broke loose.”

The tavern was lively and filled with more patrons than usual. It’s near the end of the week, approaching on the holy day. That and Hedges closed shop early this week. Maven, proud owner and the tavern’s sole employee, somehow avoided being pulled into the High Lord’s army, the thought causing him to scratch at his lengthy sideburns. Hedges, who the place was appropriately named after, wasn’t quite as lucky. And so, all of the regulars at Hedges became regulars at Tankard and Cheer.

Tankard and Cheer wasn’t fancy by any means. The interior was filled with pine and similar light wooden furniture. Several pillars, looking too thin to handle structural weight, were spread out over the floor, seven of them total. Maven always got nervous when larger folk leaned on them. Whoever designed the building must have thought they looked regal. Maven can’t think of another reason for the inefficient beams.

A man in the corner, one with distinguished hazel eyes, raised a finger up, signaling for Maven. The barkeep strode over to the man, two tankards in his hand. Part of keeping regulars was to learn their mannerisms, to learn their consumption methods. You needed to anticipate their requests. This man in particular had come in every day for the past three, always ordering the same. First, something strong. Then, two ales. He tipped well, which is why Maven was extra certain to serve the man with a high level of service.

Two tankards landed with a thud in front of the man, hazel eyes falling upon them with thirst, hands closely following.

“Good to see you again, friend,” Maven said.

“Good to be seen,” the man answered, reaching for the closest ale. A little froth spilled down the side of the tankard onto the bar top.

Maven pulled a rag from his apron pocket and began wiping. “New in town? I don’t mean to pry. We rarely see travelers now, you know. With the border disputes going on.”

“I’m sure that won’t go on for much longer,” the man replied between sips. Behind Maven, a pair of loud voices rose above the noise of the tavern. After a few ale-induced insults are thrown towards the “savages from the western plains,” ale-induced laughter closely follows.

“They’re just blowin’ off steam,” Maven said. “The war’s putting pressure on their work. Even more so with most of their help recruited into the High Lord’s army. They’re decent folk, just feeling the burden of the conflict.”

“HA HA HA! I would give the ‘Great’ Warlord some of this!” Again, their shouts broke through the typical tavern noise. The man who raised his opinion so subtly, gestured towards his codpiece in a manner of equal subtlety.

“They bring dishonor on themselves,” the hazel-eyed man spoke, more to his tankard than Maven, who assumed it was directed at him. “They’re not warriors; they’re the children left behind at war, while true men fight.”

Another gesture is shown, this one having to do with flipping around an imaginary Great Warlord and riding him from behind, one hand swaying in the air as if trying to tame a wild horse.

“They’re just--” Maven started to explain, before the hazel-eyed man slammed down his second tankard. A hand, gently, but with enough force, pushed Maven out of the man’s walking path. The hand transitioned the message well as any words could. Maven knew the man held no grudge against him, but an attempt to get in way would instantly ally himself with the shouting men. Holy flame appeared at the hazel-eyed man’s fingertips, a ring of blue searing into the open air.

Calmly, he walked towards the pair of men, a blank expression on his face. His hand curled into a fist, save for the pointer and middle finger. The blue flame swirled around the two outstretched fingers like clouds at the top of a mountain. As if a sword thrusting in and out from a victim, two fingers, lit by holy flame, slid in and out from one of the men’s temples, dropping him to the floor.

The tavern noise grinded to a halt, all the inhabitants turning to the hazel-eyed man. The blue flame spreaded to both palms, one outstretching to grip the remaining man’s throat, fingers clamped around the throat, holy flame burning the skin. Screaming, the man tried to release the hazel-eyed man’s grip, only to burn his hands on the holy flame. He collapsed next to his drinking partner.

“Now,” the hazel-eyed man, Joren, spoke with a low tone. “Any other ‘patriots’ feel like voicing their opinions?”

Maven thought it meant to be rhetorical, especially with two bodies at the hazel-eyed man’s feet. That wasn’t the case. Several other patrons, nodding grimly towards one another started to surround the hazel-eyed man. Maven gulped nervously. All hell broke loose.

“This place doesn’t look like the chaotic mess you’re describing,” Morgan comments, looking around. While the place couldn’t be described as clean, it definitely wasn’t in the realm of natural disaster, like the barkeep, Maven, made it sound. A few chairs lie on their sides, some bottles are broken on the floor, but besides that, the place is standing well enough. Several black marks on an otherwise light-colored wooden beams are really the only indication of destructive magic.

Maven nods, his thick sideburns bobbing up and down. “The blue-flamed man was very...courteous to avoid catching the Tankard on fire. Most of the damage was done to the patrons.”

“How very kind of him,” Morgan absently says.

“And after?” you ask. “Where did this man go once his dispute was over?”

“Where do you think?” Maven asks with too much attitude for Morgan’s liking. “A man like that, so quickly to jump to the Warlord’s defense, despite being in enemy territory. He’s heading to the western plains, no doubt about it. I know what he is. Men share stories. Words flow as easily as drinks in the Tankard.”

“And what exactly is he?” Morgan asks.
Maven leans in close, making his sideburns appear even larger. “A priest. A shaman from the plains. What he’s doing here, in Helswith, I know not.”

“I do,” you say. “We were on the same boat, one that crashed in a storm in Tristrand’s waters. Your tavern is one of many stops along the way to the western plains.”

“Careful what you seek, traveler,” Maven warns. “I’ve heard many stories with adventurer’s quests ending poorly. Sometimes what you search for isn’t what you need.”

“We don’t need your warning, innkeeper,” Morgan sharply answers.

“It’s appreciated though,” you tag on.

“It’s ‘proud owner,’ Miss. And you’re welcome,” Maven says, ending the conversation.

You both exit Tankard and Cheer, arriving to where your horses are tied up. The warm Helswith air meets you as the journey takes you from the shady overhang of the Tankard. It reminds you of your childhood, growing up with the hot, dusty air all around. Yet, you don’t miss it. Who would? The mountains you fled to were certainly more harsh, and still, you prefer the sharpness of the cold opposed to the heat.

“Well?” Morgan says, meeting your eyes expectantly.

“What, did you say something?” you ask.

Her eyes narrow. Bright green peer through her eyelids. “I said our hunt will likely take us through not one, but two armies. Are you prepared for that?”

“The Lady will give us strength,” you answer, knowing it will satisfy her.

“That she will.”

The Helswith Desert, while holding the namesake of something barren, isn’t as lifeless as one would think. Many centuries have the people of the Helswith navigated the desert, learning where underground water flowed. Navigational maps are common. There aren’t many who find themselves lost in the desert. While there are certainly rolling hills of sand, extending as far as the eye can see, the majority of the Helswith is dry rock, dust, gravel stamped into the earth forming a flat surface. Legends say the flatness is from the Eternal Father’s footprint. Scholars say otherwise.

Due to the terrain, High Lord Ursa’s army is supported with deadly chariots. The High Lord may not have an unmatched navy or unbreakable fortress, but he does possess the finest cavalry led by horse and armored cart. No invader had been able to march through the Helswith, even reaching the capital city; they’re all run down on the Helswith path.

The path, the one in which you ride, is almost a direct shot to the western edge of the Helswith. Along the way, you encounter many military transports and battalions rushing to reach their destination. As far as travelers go, you’re one of the few trekking the Helswith, and the only pair heading towards the plains.

Several weeks pass…

Off in the distance, tents, lining the horizon, appear, their golden flags flying in the wind like tiny flames dancing from the tip of a candle. As you continue towards them, more and more show up, continuing to rise from the edge of your vision. Before you reach the outer one, a small squad of soldiers stop you.

There’s ten of them total, each dressed in their silver and gold uniform, glinting the Helswith sun from their chainmail sticking through. You’re greeted with a spear to your nose; the man behind it speaks.

“No civilians in the High Lord’s camp. Turn around and leave the way you came.”

“The High Lord is here?” you question. To your knowledge, he only marched when the enemy threat was high. His days of fighting in border skirmishes were over.

“High Lord Ursa is personally addressing the gathering barbarians. He will lead us to ultimate victory. I’m sure of that.” Behind the soldier speaking, his fellows nod their head and murmur in agreement. “Listen,” the soldier begins, lowering his voice. “It’s unsafe for you to be here. Traveling this far west, you must be determined, but I assure you, you don’t want to keep going. We are miles from the border, but there is no safety beyond this camp.”

“So which is it,” Morgan says. “Unsafe here or beyond the camp?”

“Listen, lass,” the soldier answers, getting Morgan to raise an eyebrow at being called “lass.” “There’s no reason to risk your lives over a simple honeymoon. That’s what I’m assuming this is, right? No matter. This is where your journey ends. Turn back, please, otherwise we’ll be required to force you back.”

Honesty being your course of action, you say, “We’re seeking a man. Hazel eyes. Tendency to leave behind burning victims in his path. Has he crossed through here?”

The soldiers glance at one another, obviously betraying the fact that they recognize the description.

“And just what’s your business with the man?” the soldier asks.

“A debt of blood,” Morgan replies. “A ruined temple, a murdered teacher, and many bodies left in wake of the man. We’re seeking collection on payment due.”

“We may have had a run-in with such a fellow,” the soldier says, finally removing his spear from staring you in the face. “This is above my station, though. Yarln, see these two to the councilor. He’ll know what to do with them.”

A man from the back of the soldiers steps forward, dressed in the same uniform and spear. His face is shaved, except for a sizable braid from his chin, which hangs down a few inches, neatly tied at the end with red string. “This way, then.” He starts walking towards the camp, not glancing back to see if you’re following. You are.

You’re escorted into a rectangular tent filled with bright colors and extravagantly embroidered furniture. The very center holds a pile of pillows, silk by the looks of them. Most are bright red stitched with gold. Others are blue of a similar brightness, still stitched with gold. Beyond the pillows, a large desk is at one end of the tent, two green plants on either side, small trees, planted in transportable pots. Behind the desk, several bookcases stand, filled to entirety, some holding message scrolls similar to the ones found in the Crow’s Nest.

A man, sitting behind the desk, wearing red silk matching the pillows, looks up. Light flashes from his eyes, a pair of glasses resting on the bridge of his nose. His face is mature. Lines of worry starting to show on his skin, coupled with short blonde hair that is starting to gray at the edges.

“I’m told you have news of our fugitive.” His voice, while not demanding, speaks with authority. Strong, firm, confident.

“Your fugitive,” Morgan answers. “Started his wake of destruction in our home. He is ours.”

“Not so,” the councilor replies. “Do your shackles hold him? Do your soldiers stand guard? No, my dear, he is our fugitive.”

Learning that Morgan’s direct approach isn’t always effective, especially with people of authority, you interject. You’ve found Morgan’s tactics to be a bit too threatening to their position. “We’re allies seeking the same goal. It’s no secret the man we search for has harmed the High Lord’s army in some way. What exactly did he do?”

“Damn near tried burning the entire warcamp down,” the councilor says, loosening up a bit at your calm approach. “We refused his request to pass through into the plains. We can’t allow just anyone to waltz through. There could be spies in Helswith. My job is to protect the High Lord and his armies.”

“We are no enemies of Helswith,” you reply.

“Interesting comment to be made. I don’t see you fighting to protect her either. You are of Helswith, are you not?”

“I am.”

“Clearly, you are. This woman, however, does not look to be a direct descendant. And somehow you escaped service, yet preach that you have your interests aligned with Helswith. You see, that doesn’t give me confidence at the statement. You speak with much expectation. I imagine privilege accompanies your namesake?”

“It accompanies my father’s, yes.”

“But not you?”

You hesitate, unsure if revealing your father’s house would help or hurt. The name carries weight, but also the responsibility to aid country. While given leadership roles, ones that view combat safely from afar, dignified families are still expected to serve. “I am from the southern mountains. Of the Nameless.”

“Interesting,” the councilor starts, “and you just spoke of being of Helswith. Which is it then?”

You answer, choosing your words with care. “Helswith may be my place of birth, but it is no longer my home. I was once of the house of Scholhart. My name, title, even inheritance was made forfeit with my departure, which was many years ago. I am of the Nameless.”

“I see,” the councilor comments. “I am well aware of the sudden departure of young Master Scholhart. It’s not every day a great house’s firstborn disappears. So that’s where you went. The Mountains of the Nameless. Your actions put your father, and his house, in a precarious situation.”

“Which is?”

“Don’t tell me you’re that naive. An heir. You left your father without an heir. Who would continue his work after his death? Who would manage his business, take care of his employees?”

“There is no shortage of ambition in Helswith. I’m sure finding a replacement is easy,” you say.

“Sure, it’s easy. Harder so, to find one that shares the same vision as your father. The house of Scholhart was put in jeopardy by your decision, and all the lives that associate with it. Luckily, you made your decision early enough before Arroden grew too old.”

The implication of the statement is known to you.

“There is a new heir?” you ask.

The councilor nods. “You, my Nameless friend, have a younger brother. He’s here in the camp, too. At least the house of Scholhart bore one worthwhile son to bring glory to the High Lord.”

“I’ve proven we are no enemies to Helswith. Our debt must be settled with this ‘fugitive’ as you call him. I’m sure he’s awaiting execution, is he not? Allow us to finish the deed for you. Then, we’ll be on our way.”

“I’m afraid I can’t do that,” the councilor answers. “You see, there is a level of order I must maintain throughout the camp. I can’t let just anyone demand to be executioner, striking down men in the name of vengeance. Chaos would ensue. The good news is you’ll be reunited with your fire-loving friend very soon.”

“What is your meaning?” Morgan asks.

“You’ll be kept here until I decide what to do with you. If you are Nameless, then I can’t conscript you, legally, into the High Lord’s army. Then again, your previous familial ties are no small matter. Likely, I will send a message to Arroden and inquire for his thoughts. Perhaps he has one last lesson to teach his firstborn son.” The councilor finishes by rapping his knuckles on his desk.

The knock causes soldiers to rush into the tent’s interior. These ones are unlike the ones encountered at the camp’s outskirts. Their plate armor is a shiny silver, trimmed with gold. While the mainhand of each carries various weapons, they all bear a sizable shield. The royal guard, if you had to guess. Elites.

“Now, will you kindly escort these two to their quarters?” the councilor asks.

Your hand reaches for your sword, but then is stopped. Morgan’s hand rests at your wrist, keeping you from drawing the blade. She shakes her head, and you understand her thoughts. You may not be arriving as expected, but you’ve finally found Joren. Shackles clamp around your wrists, bringing back memories of the past. You’re meeting Joren the same way as you did originally. Bound by chain.

The familiar feeling of cold steel around your wrists. The Helswith elite guard escorts you from the councilor’s tent. Back into the hot Helswith air, they lead you through several makeshift streets lined with collapsible structures to a large open area. A simple wooden fence as the perimeter, many cages fill the entire space, pressed against one another. By your estimate, each cage is holding eight to ten prisoners inside, although the proximity of each jail cell makes it look as if it’s one huge enclosure. Luckily, the Helswith soldiers don’t seem too hell-bent on separating prisoners by male and female, so both you and Morgan are “politely” placed into the same cell.

Stripped of your weapons and armor, you wear a simple loose tunic and trousers, Morgan the same. The other prisoners in the cell glance at you as you’re thrown in, then quickly avoid making eye contact. Conditioned not to stare. You’re accustomed to such behavior by those in shackles. Hell, you experienced the same thing on the boat that eventually crashed into the island. Eye contact is seen as a threat. One that is punished severely by those holding the whip, often extending between prisoners themselves. The result is a frightened bunch, hardly capable of mustering a revolt. Or so the slavers on the boat thought. Still, you recognize the storm created more of an opening than the prisoners did themselves. If the storm never hit, you’d probably still be chained to that damn oar.

“Why did you have us surrender like that?” you whisper once the cell door slams shut.

“Surrender?” Morgan asks. “I had that pomous man place us exactly where our prey lies. Even more, he’s locked in a cage unable to run from us any longer.”

“Yeah, but in case you didn’t notice, so are we,” you reply.

“Are we?” Morgan, again, asks a question she obviously knows the answer to.

Instead of audibly responding, you raise your hands in a questioning manner, gesturing to the cell walls around you as well.

A small laugh escapes Morgan’s lips. “Please. It only looks that way. Now to locate our man…” She scans the sea of prisoners around you. After a few seconds, she speaks again. “There. Five cells over.”

Sure enough, five cells to your right, a man with brown curls, far longer than you remember, sits on the ground, leaning against the cell wall for back support. You can almost see a twinkle in his hazel eye as he winks in your direction, noticing who his two newest fellow prisoners are.

“If our plan was to surprise him, I don’t think it’s working,” you comment.

“Surprise?” Morgan asks. You groan inwardly at a third rhetorical question, reminding you of her teaching style on the island. “I’d rather him peer into my eyes as I slide my dagger into his heart.”

“Very well. Might be hard to do so from your position. Not only would you need to break free from our cell, you’d have to sneak into Joren’s without alerting the guards or having the other inmates create a scene. He may be within sight, but he’s just outside of our grasp,” you say.

“We’ll see about that,” Morgan says. If there’s something she knows, she isn’t sharing it with you. Another sigh escapes your lips. What else were you expecting? As it seems her plan isn’t to act right away, you might as well make yourself comfortable.

As far as prison cells go, it’s not the worst one you’ve found yourself in. However, that’s not saying much. The other prisoners in your cell haven’t addressed either you or Morgan yet, at least not with words. When a passing guard came to drop off rations, one of the prisoners, a man with stringy hair at his sides while balding on top, pointed to the opposite end of the cell. Only once the entire cell’s inmates stood on the far end did the guard place the food down.

The thing often not shared about prison cells is how dreadfully boring it is. You’ve got nothing but time. Sure, it depends who’s holding you. Violent wardens definitely make one’s stay...interesting. High Lord Ursa’s prison is more the “civilized” variety. Regular meals are given. The food may taste like dirt, but it’s filling enough. Using the latrine bucket may be an assault on your dignity; at least it’s not an actual physical assault like other places you’ve been.

You’ve got plenty of time to think. Joren doesn’t seem to be going anywhere. Morgan is content for the time being. Did your father really birth another son? The councilor didn’t appear to be the lying type. There wouldn’t be much reasoning behind a lie of that variety. No, he’s got to be telling the truth. You have a little brother, and he’s in the war camp.

There’s also the small matter of war. The horde, biding their time, testing the western frontier for weak points, has not engaged on a full-scale attack quite yet. Whatever they’re waiting for hasn’t happened yet. More troops? Supplies? It can’t be additional troops; they’ve already assembled the largest number since the Great Warlord of old, according to the reports. Suddenly, in the grand scheme of things, your quest for revenge feels very insignificant.

A nation, your place of birth, the Helswith, on the verge of destruction, its impact already being felt by military recruitment. Better not tell Morgan that, though. Her mind, as always, is singular, focused on the task. Focused on the Lady. Deviating from that path may end up with the knifepoint pointed at you after tasting Joren’s blood. Part of you doesn’t think so, but still, you think it safe to hold such thoughts to yourself. With Joren’s death, you’ll have a better grasp of the state of things.

They don’t place torches near you. There’s no sort of light for the prisoners, unless you count the moon. Tonight, however, it hides behind a thick cloud layer. Darkness surrounds, not even allowing you to see two cells over. Your cellmates, along with Morgan, are dark forms in the foreground of blackness. For days you’ve sat, imprisoned, Morgan still content where you both are for the time being.

That’s about to change.

A cold hand lands across your mouth, the face behind it shrouded in black. Morgan. Her other hand motions towards her face, and you barely make out her finger gesturing in front of her lips, the sign to be quiet. You nod, slowly rising from your prone state. Morgan’s finger, still in front of her mouth, pulls an object from underneath her tongue. A small pin, not longer than an inch, rests between her forefinger and thumb, likely something she snagged in the councilor's tent. No wonder she was content. She was biding her time for the perfect moment. A night like this, moonlight hidden, is that exact thing.

She creeps to the cell door, you closely behind, and maneuvers the pin into the lock, taking care not to jumble it around and alert the others. With a satisfying click, the mechanism releases. You both pause, listening to see if there’s a response from the other prisoners. It’s silent. The two of you slip from your cell into the Helswith air, free.

Suddenly, a burst of light emerges from one end of the camp. A group of soldiers appear, five in total, carrying torches, marching straight for you. How did they know you escaped so quickly? Before the torchlight can land on you, you make a break for the nearest makeshift barracks, a canvas tent designed in a long, rectangular position. In the safety between two of them, you watch the soldiers pass you by. They aren’t coming for you. And you have a good idea who they are coming for. The sentries did say Joren tried burning the camp down. Bound to be some angry Helswith soldiers as a result of that.

They head straight for Joren’s cell, their torchlight interrupting nearby sleeping prisoners, which react by moving to the end of their cells, obviously wanting no trouble from the soldiers. The leader of the group fumbles with placing his key into Joren’s lock, a likely sign that they’ve been indulging in a few drinks.

You catch one of the soldiers muttering something. “These shackles better work. I don’t want to end up like Fetts.”

“You’ll be fine. You really think the High Lord would not take the proper precautions against someone like this?”

Joren, chained at the wrists, is pulled from his cell. They toss him to the ground in the center of the soldiers. From your vantage point, you notice the soldier’s uniforms aren’t neatly pressed and fastened like the others you’ve seen. A few wrinkles lie on their tunics, and they aren’t tied tight. After throwing a few kicks into Joren’s prone body, they address him again, sure that he’s not going anywhere.

“Come on, gentlemen. You take things too personally. Your friend, Fetts, was it? He should be thanking me for rearranging his face. Nasty thing it was,” Joren says once the kicking stops, which of course causes it to begin again.

“You damn near burned the skin from his face, savage!”

Joren curls up as more blows hit his body. In the mad rush of feet stomping and occasional fist, you can tell not many blows are actually causing damage. To an untrained eye, it would look as if Joren is beaten half to death. To yours, on the other hand, you notice most of the strikes are absorbed through his arms, often just glancing off to the ground as Joren twists his body in a subtle defensive pattern. The soldiers, intoxicated as they are, simply think he’s squirming in pain. There’s no doubt Morgan is catching it as well.

Then Joren strikes.

He explodes into a burst of motion, twisting on the ground, sweeping the feet out from under two of the soldiers. His fists, using his shackles as blunt weapons, rain down on them, stopping any sort of movement in their bodies.

“You really think I need the Divine’s power to handle the likes of a few drunks?” Joren flatly states, more as a fact than threat. “You’re brutes, cruel masters taking up arms against a ‘defenseless’ prisoner. I know your kind, never willing to take a fair fight. There’s three of you left. I’ll try to take it easy in fairness.”

Joren engages them in a fury of chained fists. With both hands closely bound, he uses his arms as a single weapon, a mace put together with fist and steel. He blocks left, then right, kicking his leg out to keep the other soldier at distance. The soldiers, slow with drink, are more helpless than Joren was in the center of them. One drops, then another. Then, Joren takes his time with the final one, slamming his fists into the man’s gut doubling him over. A quick knee sends the man sprawling to the ground, where Joren takes a position standing over the man in a mad frenzy of hammer fists. As the man’s face caves in, turning into an unrecognizable mess, only then does Joren quit, taking the man’s key and unlocking the shackles at his wrists.

Five soldiers at his feet, his cell door open, Joren takes off into the night.

He takes off west, traveling towards the barbarian plains. You follow his trail, keeping in the shadows, hunters stalking their prey. He’s finally within your grasp. Part of you thinks intervening Joren’s minor skirmish with the soldiers would have been the better choice. After all, he was at their mercy for the time being. It probably wouldn’t have been too hard to catch them unawares. Still, though you find yourself here. There’s a man to kill.

Joren quickly ducks into a nearby tent, a barracks of sorts, likely to search for supplies. Better do the same if you’re going to chase him into the plains. Then, the thought comes across your mind. Why would you chase him into the western plains when he’s in a building not 50 feet away? You’re within striking distance. Might as well go for the kill now, instead of tracking him into barbarian land.

“It’s time to end this,” you whisper to Morgan, heading for the tent.

“Let’s make it swift,” she answers.

Leading the way, you slip into the makeshift barracks. It’s dark. The cloud layer is still hiding the moonlight, which only makes the inside of a tent even darker. Without being able to see, you pause a moment, sensing for Joren. No sign. Then, darkness takes form. A shadow soon turning into bright blue, Joren’s holy flame. Fire ignites, a blast hitting your face searing your flesh.

As you scream and drop, Morgan engages Joren with a flurry of unarmed blows. His fists still emanate flame, the disadvantage clearly on her as one clean strike would ignite her body as well. A few stray blows miss Morgan, setting the entire tent aflame. Low blue light creeps up the canvas, a beacon in the middle of an otherwise black night.

Prone, clutching your face, more holy flame from the canvas catches on your pant leg, soon traveling up igniting your torso as well. Unable to hold in your pain, you continue screaming until smoke blocks air from traveling into your lungs. As your vision turns black, surrounded in a ring of blue, you see Morgan land a clean hit, sending Joren sprawling to the ground. Your lips mumble a silent prayer, no sound escaping, for Morgan’s success. It all turns dark.

You decide to intervene, although it’s probably best to wait until the proper moment. Morgan may have her smuggled pin to open the lock, but these soldiers no doubt have a key. If they’re willing to open the door for you, might as well let them. They head straight for Joren, the light from their torches interrupting the prisoners of each cell that they pass. The soldier in front of the others reaches in his pocket for a key, digging around for a bit and missing the lock twice before swinging open the cell door. Most likely has been spending his night drinking until now. The soldiers pull Joren from the cell and toss him to the ground in front of them.

“These shackles better work. I don’t want to end up like Fetts,” one of the soldiers mutters under his breath.

Another one answers. “You’ll be fine. You really think the High Lord would not take the proper precautions against someone like this?”

To ensure he won’t escape, the soldiers start to kick at Joren in his prone state. He covers up, attempting to block as many blows as possible with his arms, redirecting the bulk of the force to the ground beneath him. Now’s your chance. Joren occupied, the soldiers busy, there wouldn’t be a better time to attack.

Morgan, agreeing with you, silently creeps forward at your heels. You are unarmed, but the soldiers aren’t. As you approach the closest, still undetected, you pull a knife from the soldier’s belt. He turns, only to have his own knife cut his throat. Blood splashes in the air then down to Joren’s prone body, too much for one man. To your right, Morgan has done the same maneuver, and she’s working on the next one. You do the same, making quick work of the drunken soldiers.

“You’ll not get away this time,” Morgan speaks to the man before her, the very man who burned the temple and killed her mentor.

Joren looks up from the ground. Some of the soldiers’ blood splattered across his face. “I was doing the work of your Lady. That old man of yours was a traitor to your cause.”

“Your lies mean nothing,” Morgan answers. “I only wish I could make it slower.” Morgan thrusts the dagger down, sending the tip piercing Joren’s chest. A small gurgle escapes his mouth. His hands, still chained, half-heartedly reach towards the blade in his chest, unsure whether to try pulling it out. Either way, he’s doomed. Morgan takes a deep breath and looks up to the night sky, as if in contemplation or looking for divine direction. You stand back a few feet, allowing her to savor the moment. What does this mean for the two of you now?

Men’s voices begin to ring into the night, still a way’s off. Your skirmish must have alerted other soldiers, who are now making their way to your very location. You drop down, searching the leader of the now-dead Helswith men and pull a key from his belt.

“Good luck. You’re better off traveling west, just steer clear of any tribesmen,” you say, tossing the key into the nearest cell. The prisoners inside nod and immediately unlock their door, passing the key to the next and so on. Not many would likely make it, but at least some will. It’s a better chance than you ever received. Deep down, not a prideful thought, but you also know they will cover your own escape, distracting the soldiers away from you.

With Joren dead, your mission completed, Morgan and you escape into the night.

Louder and louder the camp gets, coming alive in the middle of the night. Prisoner escape. Not that the soldiers would have noticed you and Morgan sneaking through, but the chaotic circumstance makes for a nice cover. Men rush past your various hiding positions, all heading straight for the prison area. Soldiers lie dead, prisoners breaking free, they’re more concerned with stopping a revolt than searching for lone escapees.

You take the opportunity to snag some equipment on the way out. After finding a soldier your height and build, you’re now armed with simple protective leather and sword at your hip. Morgan’s only able to pick up a sword, as the soldiers you came across wore armor much too big for her. Just as you suggested to the prisoners, you head west into the barbarian plains. Now that you’ve put some distance between you and the camp, you see it’s littered with fires. The prisoners who seemed docile enough, must have made more of an impact than you were expecting. They likely know it’s their one chance at escape and are making the most of it.

It’s still dark, although the first sign of morning light is starting to appear. A thick cloud layer still hangs in the air, doing its best effort to shield the approaching sunlight.

“Finally. It is finished,” you break the silence as both you and Morgan gaze out on the camp to the east. The rolling hills of the rocky plains offer a substantial viewpoint over the Helswith war camp.

“Our task is, yes. The Lady’s vengeance is complete. There is still much work to be done. Rebuilding, you see, is no small thing,” Morgan answers.

“You plan to rebuild the temple?”

“Not on the island. But yes. Perhaps your home would be a suitable place, your second home. I hear the Mountains of the Nameless are welcoming to outsiders.”

For some reason, that doesn’t sit with you well. Something you can’t explain just doesn’t feel right. The Mountains are a place of escape, for those to find themselves. “It’s not a refugee camp,” you say. “The Mountains bring their own obstacles and challenges.”

“Good thing we are not refugees. What do you say, will you take part in reestablishing the order?” Morgan asks.

“Yes,” you answer. “It’s a new era for the Lady’s followers, one born from vengeance, true to her nature. Not to downplay Killian’s death, but it’s paved the way for a new beginning.”

Morgan replies. “I know what you’re intending to say. That’s just a poor way to state it. It’s almost as if you’re saying Killian’s death was necessary.”

“That’s not--”

“I know,” Morgan cuts you off. “I foresee an order with many devoted followers, ones that are loyal and won’t give in to the Walkers’ lies. We’ll travel far away from this place. We’ll forget the conflict between Helswith and the horde. There are more important things to do than get involved with petty border disputes. As the Lady’s herald, I name you second-in-command and grant you the title of Elder.”

Morgan is the Lady’s herald. When did that happen? It doesn’t matter now. You’re certainly not going to dispute the claim. That word brings a small sense of longing in your mind. It’s been silent since your last vision with the Lady. Where did she go? You quietly say a prayer, hoping that you didn’t fail her in some way.

It’s strange, but you always assumed straying from the proper path would have major implications, like you’d instantly know when a wrong turn was made. Perhaps you’re reading into it too much. Joren is dead, and you will start over with Morgan. Things could have ended up worse. Still, though, a tiny part of you doesn’t imagine this is how it was all supposed to end. You’ve only just learned that you have a little brother. And he’s here. Whatever reunion you were to have is all for nought now.

“Elder, you’re quiet. Everything alright?” Morgan asks.

“Yes, Herald,” you answer. “I’m only reflecting on the path that brought us here.”

“You’ll have plenty of time for that. We have a long journey ahead of us.”

And so you do.

Morgan turns again, posturing like she’s about to leave. “Then your absence is even more of a betrayal. Though I dare not raise arms against one the Lady’s marked. “What is it that you aren’t telling me?” you ask Morgan.

“Many things,” Morgan answers. “Oh you mean as it relates to our current situation?”

You nod, not playing into the game.

You answer choosing your words carefully. “I was of Helswith. House Scholhart. But I left for the southern mountains at a young age.”

Recognition appears on the councilor's face. “I know of Arroden’s runaway son. So that’s where you went to? The Mountains of the Nameless.” His eyes travel over to Morgan. “And I can tell you must have had quite the adventure.”

“As I said, we’re no enemies of Helswith,” you say.

“That you’re not,” the councilor replies, absent-mindedly. “Still, there is a little rule that we must adhere to.”

“Which is?” Morgan asks.

“Conscription. There are no exceptions for runaways. And I’m afraid abandonment of one’s house means your military responsibilities will be low. After all, if your own family can’t even trust you, how can the High Lord put you in command of others?”

You know where this is going.

The councilor continues. “For your actions, you will not be placed at a station befitting your family’s position. Instead, you will be assigned to the outer front -- the first line of defense against the horde of the west. You are hereby now part of the High Lord’s army, young Master Scholhart.”

With his final words, the councilor slams his hand down on a sheet of paper, stamping the bottom with his seal. No doubt he had that prepared ahead of time. How he knew beforehand, you know not. The sound of his stamp causes soldiers to rush in through the tent flaps. These ones are not like the ones encountered at first. Their towering bodies are in shiny silver plate, trimmed with gold. Each carries a sizable shield, although the accompanying weapon in their main hand varies. Some hold swords, others maces and battle axes. Only one holds a spear.

“We’ll not give up so easily,” Morgan says, drawing her sword.

“Alive, please. He’s of a great house of Helswith,” the councilor commands the soldiers, the elite royal guard if you had to guess. “Kill the woman if you must.”

The elite guard surrounds you, standing tall like masts of a ship, their helms carved to the likeness of animals, hunters of the wilderness. You draw both sword and dagger, searching for weaknesses in their armor. The usual weak points have been addressed. As the elite guard move, you scan their underarms, neck, and knees, places that commonly have a break in defense. This armor, however, was forged with such places in mind. Small chain, connecting tiny plates, fills the gaps between sections in armor. You’ll have to figure something else out.

Whispers, incoherent words form at Morgan’s mouth. Is she praying to the Lady? You’ve never seen her begin battle this way. She finishes speaking and looks up. Her eyes, once a sparkling green, are pure black, two onyx beads. Light flickers for a moment, sending shadows bouncing from the tent walls. As the light returns to stationary, no longer flickering, something is off. It’s more dim, like standing in the shade. Then, you see the result of Morgan’s work.

Next to Morgan are six images, six shadows, six perfect illusions of her. They attack.

You follow suit, weaving your weapons into an attack pattern with a series of thrusts. Any sort of slashing, arcing technique will have no effect on the heavily-armored guards. You need to find small openings in the armor with the point of your weapons. Your opponent, an elite member with a standard sword and shield, easily blocks your attacks. With a shield covering half his body, and plate armor behind said shield, finding any sort of opening will be difficult. Still, you search, poking, prodding with your weapons, looking for an area to exploit. Behind you, a shadow is consumed. A battle axe tears through the illusion, sending a flicker of light back into the room.

You continue your attack, throwing the heel of your boot into the guard’s shield, pushing him off-balanced. You thrust forward, lunging onto one knee, changing levels. Your sword strikes true, piercing just above the waist, between the breastplate and greaves, angled up from your low lunge. More light flickers.

“Urgh,” a voice, muted by the closed helm, murmurs, sounding more surprised than distressed. The back of the man’s gauntlet slams into your face, sending you sprawling backward, hand released from your sword hilt. Your back meets Morgan’s, the remaining illusion dispelled with a swing of a battle axe.

Morgan turns, resting her hand on your cheek, lightly touching her forehead against yours. “The Lady will reunite us. Stay true to the path. We’ll meet again.” Before you can react, the guard’s spear thrusts forward, landing true in Morgan’s back. The light flickers. A blow to the back of your head extinguishes it completely.

You are close, a voice whispers, awakening you from sleep. It’s dark. You’re back in the place where you originally met the Lady, the woman flocked by crows, the vengeful spirit. Resting peacefully, the coffin sits atop a small staircase, an altar to the dead. The candles are lit, the flowers remain vibrant and full of life.

This time, however, you aren’t floating above. You lie at the bottom step. As you rise, sharpness of pain greets your head, whether that’s a result of a blow or the hard surface you know not. Perhaps a bit of both.

The woman is next to you, hair lightlessly floating just above her bare shoulders. Her dress is of a similar nature, the bottom hem like a passing cloud in the wind.

“Why do you bring me here?” you ask. “What is the meaning of this place?”

You must be made to see. Your conflict goes much deeper than a simple battle between armies.

“What is it that I need to see? I saw Joren’s motives, but it was too late. Your temple lies ruined because of it.”

The woman smiles, turning towards you. What is the purpose of a temple?

“A place of worship. A sacred house to dwell.”

Do I appear to be without a place of dwelling?

“For your worshippers, maybe. I doubt you appear to them like this, even to your most devout member.”

True. I have chosen you as my herald.

“Morgan would serve as a better choice.”

She has guided you this far. But she is not my herald. I have chosen you, of the Nameless, to battle the return of Uralan. All this has happened before and is happening again.

“I know the stories. I’ve seen it in my dreams. You speak of the Great Warlord of old...the one who captured you, the one who the horde leader claims to be a descendant of.”

The Lady’s bare feet float mere inches above the stone steps. She travels up two, placing herself between you and the coffin. Perfect features meet your flaws, highlighting them in your mind, despite not visually seeing them. A wave rushes over your body, a feeling of longing, desire, an impulse to do her work. If you were at all unsure before, all is washed away.

Unseen battles are happening around you. I appear to you during small breaks in conflict, though it takes a toll on my strength. The Eternal Father has tasked me with stopping the return of his disobedient son, something that you, a lost son are familiar with. Yet, you are different. You seek redemption. Your rebellious nature is born from a noble cause, unlike Uralan’s. He will manifest his power in the new warlord, and the world will be under his tyranny. I cannot win the battle in my realm alone. I need help in the physical. I need my herald.

“How can I stop him?” you ask. “He’s united all the tribes of the plains. He has thousands upon thousands of warriors at his disposal. Despite my training on the island, the task is near impossible.”

You have more allies than you think, the Lady answers. The vision starts to blink from existence, images fading in and out, blurry as if under the effects of intoxication. Do not let past doctrine limit your actions. Rumbling starts from the coffin, small scratching echoes from the interior. The candles at each corner flicker, shining bright for a moment, then becoming dimmer and dimmer. Stay true to the path. I will appear when you need me most.

The vision fades to black.

You are stripped of all equipment and clothing, replacing your equipment with standard Helswith infantryman gear. Simple leather, flying the Helswith silver and gold, protects your body. It allows for movement at the cost of protection. Still, that is your preference. Mobility over encumberment, speed over raw strength, options over the direct approach. To your surprise, you’re allowed to keep your sword and dagger, ones that have grown familiar over the long journey to the western border. The implication is not lost on you, though. A low investment into a soldier only speaks to his expendability.

As the councilor said, you’re placed on the western front. The first line of defense against the horde. The Helswith doesn’t possess walls against barbarian raiders. Instead, squads line the border. A single squad would not hold an invasion force, but they would slow down the force long enough for the High Lord’s chariots to mobilize. You know exactly where the councilor placed you: in a death camp.

You stand in front of the squadleader in his tent. Squadleader Pralthar scans a parchment in his hand, no doubt explaining your arrival to his unit. Below his neatly-trimmed beard, you see his jaw clench in thought. Finished, he rolls up the parchment and addresses you. “You’re not the first add-on to arrive here. Funny you both come from the same origin. No matter. Have you military experience before?”

“No, sir,” you answer.

Squadleader Pralthar laughs, displaying a set of teeth far whiter than the common soldier’s. “Ha, that’s the spirit. I see you wear non-issued weapons. They don’t look brand new either. That’s a good sign.”

“True, I have no military experience, but I have been trained in battle,” you say, honestly. “First by a mentor in House Scholhart. Then, by…” You pause, unsure how to describe Morgan’s teachings. “...other, untraditional methods.”

Pralthar nods. “As long as you can fight, you’ll fit in here. The tribesmen have grown more bold. Each day more of them appear. Our scouts have been unable to determine why the entire horde hasn’t marched, though. They’re waiting for something. What that is, I know not. You’ll need to learn our tactics, formations to give our small number an advantage over the undisciplined barbarians.”

“I have some small knowledge,” you say, thinking back to your studies. “Smaller numbers are better deployed as a tight-knit force, like a nail hammering into a broad piece of lumber.”

“That’s right.” You’re flashed another bright smile. “It’s somewhat refreshing to be sent a soldier who actually knows what they’re doing. Out here,” the smile disappears. “We’ve mostly been reinforced with untrained slaves. Warm bodies to distract the horde’s axes long enough for the real army to mobilize. Most don’t last a month. Only one’s survived. I’m sure you’ll be interested to meet him. You two have quite a lot in common.”

Suddenly, a man bursts into the tent. His hulking frame just barely fits through the tent flaps. He speaks, arms crossing at his chest. “Squadleader,” he salutes. “Contact.”

“Get the men ready,” Pralthar answers. Turning to you he adds, “Looks like you’ve arrived at the right time, Nameless.”

The familiar tingle appears, like static energy is in the air, buzzing, wanting you to control it. You do, giving it structure, giving it purpose. It bends to your will, allowing you to see. To truly see. The sensation of falling fills your body, like jumping from a high cliff into a body of water. Your body flies through the air in a swirl of air, dark smoke as your tunnel. As quick as the motion appears, it stops, as if water hitting a dam.

A younger Pralthar sits in front of you. His neat beard is gone. Instead, bare skin shows at his face, an attribute of his youth. He’s at a desk, loose pages scattered all over, lit by a single candle. Exhaustion is clear on his face, uninhibited by facial hair. Despite the vigor of youth, a toll has been taken on his body. Slouching shoulders only highlight that fact.

You float above, watching the scene play out in front of you. Pralthar reads one page in front of him, shakes his head, then picks up another. He’s searching for something, a secret of the past. The pages have signs of aging, a yellow tint to each scattered on the desk. In the top corner of the desk, a volume sits, bound in a dark leather album meant to house and protect the pages. You float closer to read the title. It’s blank. Curious, you start to scan the pages along with Pralthar.

In the seventh era, the era of chaos, how is it that the Eternal Father’s disobedient son was able to run rampant throughout the land? Where was the Eternal Father? We pray to him. We devote our lives, sacrificing our finest to the divine being. Yet, he never appeared. At the time we most needed him, he remained silent.

Do gods grow old? I wonder if the Eternal Father’s silence is simply a result of incapacitation. His other sons and daughters answer. Since the death of the Life Mother, no new deities are born. Did she die of old age? Will the Father be next? Ironic, for the name we call him. My thoughts are blasphemous in nature. Still, they must be voiced. If not me, then who? We are at their mercy. Humanity is but playthings, toys to be used at their disposal. We owe them nothing.

Pralthar looks up. Somehow his eyes meet yours. He turns the page over, doing the same for the rest of the scattered pages, stuffing them back into the leather album. As his breath blows out the candle, your sight is, too, placed in darkness.

You follow the hulking man, K’rell, from the tent as Pralthar stays to gather his equipment. It’s a short jog to the main barracks. Along the way, K’rell speaks through short huffs of breath. “Stay close to the others. I’m sure Squadleader will put you next to me. You may want to chase kills. Don’t. Stay in line if you want to survive. There’s only one man who’s allowed, expected really, to break rank. Ignore him.”

K’rell leads you inside, and you can’t help but notice a lone man standing outside, kicking at the dirt, waiting for the others. Inside the barracks, soldiers help one another tie their leather armor to their chests. An older man, smaller in frame, stands near the entrance handing out spears to soldiers exiting.

“Boys, we have a newcomer. Great timing, eh? Do me a favor and help keep an eye on him.” K’rell’s voice overshadows the noise of preparation. Several men, wearing the same uniform, nod and murmur their agreement. “Grab a spear from Caius. You’ll need a shield too. You won’t be much good to us with a dagger in your off-hand.”

Figuring Caius is the man handing out spears, you approach the older man, passing along K’rell’s words.

“Welcome to the front,” Caius says with a grin, handing you the requested weapons.
You join the others outside, finding a spot in line next to K’rell. The Squadleader is already waiting, battle helm donned, two tiny horns sticking out from the sides, animal hair extending down his back.

At his command, the squad of thirty, plus you and the other “add-on,” march west at a quick pace. It’s more jog than run, something that you weren’t expecting. The squad seems to hold the same preference with mobility. Due to their numbers, victory can’t be won through pure strength, so any advantage is taken. Reaching a defendable spot first is part of that.

They appear almost instantly, spanning across the horizon. Gods, there must be hundreds of them. Rolling hills are to the west, guarding much of the warm desert air from reaching the plains. Small figures rise just over the nearest hill’s peak, marching toward the Helswith border. More and more appear, like ants spilling from within their hill.

“You know the drill, Reapers! Form up!” Pralthar’s voice is direct, sure of himself. The trajectory of your jog takes you towards a series of stones scattered in the plains. The unit rearranges itself into an upside down V, like the point of a spear. Except for one man. One man, separate from the others, travels ten-twenty feet in front of the formation, exposed, alone. He seems to not mind the position, though. It must be a normal part of the formation, as untraditional as it might be.

You do as you’re told, standing next to K’rell, his hulking frame overshadowing your lean. Despite the large frame, the jogging doesn’t appear to bother him, something that usually would affect one of his size. Near the series of stones, Pralthar calls for a cease in motion, and you halt position, still in the V formation.

“Think you’ll leave some for the rest of us, Champion?” K’rell shouts towards the lone man, a haggard, resonating shout.

The man glances back, stoic, fitting for the current situation. “I may let one or two filter through, unless you’d like to join me up here.”

K’rell laughs, a similar resonating sound as his shouting. Then, the barbarians attack.

Their strategy is uncoordinated. It’s singular, each tribesman attacking on his own terms, abandoning the strength that they possess together. While the Great Warlord may have somehow united the tribes, he definitely hasn’t united their battle tactics. At least not for these barbarians in particular. They crash into the formation, a scattered mess. The Reapers brace themselves for impact, raising their shields high, protecting themselves and the soldier next to them. Retaliation is a swift thrust of the spear. You notice the formation doesn’t stay still. It slowly creeps forward, not allowing the numerous barbarians to surround. Each wave of undisciplined tribesmen results in more bodies to step over as the unit continuously moves forward.

In the center of the V, Squadleader Pralther looses another arrow from his greatbow. You notice most of his attention is focused on the lone man, the “champion.” With expert aim, the barbarians who try to surround the man are picked off one by one. You realize the similarity between Pralthar’s efforts and the V formation. It’s about taking the fight directly ahead, keeping your strength compact, ready to press forward. It would fall apart if sheer numbers were allowed to encircle. The man on his own is a one-man squad, supported with Pralthar’s aim.

The series of stones that the Reapers choose to fight in only aid their strategy. Without a direct path to overwhelm the small squad, the attacking barbarians are forced into reducing their number engaging. Next to K’rell, it’s clear his words were simple over exaggeration, confident words meant to put the men at ease. More than a few, most actually, make it past the champion, crashing into the V formation. You imitate the others, raising your shield, then moving on the offensive. It’s not a difficult maneuver, but it’s damn effective.

An axe clashes against your shield, sending a shock through your arm, the strength and sturdiness not built up for handling such blows. It only entices you for battle, waiting the appropriate amount of time, then thrusting your spear forward, finding a home for the point. The act brings an audible laugh from K’rell next to you. He’s obviously enjoying himself. Still, more tribesmen are there to replace the fallen, always one behind the other. More appear, starting to surround the lone man, the arrows from Pralthar not enough to drop them all. Soon, he’ll be overwhelmed.

Despite K’rell’s warning ahead of time, you break rank and sprint towards the lone man’s location, dodging axes and sword swings along the way. K’rell cries out, cursing at your actions, but remains in line with the others. Good. You’re used to fighting on your own. And apparently, so is the champion. Your plan is to aid him. Once finishing off the barbarians surrounding him, you’ll return back to your position in the V formation.

The champion stands, spear in hand, buckler in the other, scanning the scene in front of him. He charges forward, thrusting the spearpoint into the nearest barbarian, causing a burst of red. Before removing the spear, the champion blocks two attacks with his buckler. One from the right, and the other from behind. Instead of pulling the spear, he draws a short sword from his hip, engaging the surrounding tribesmen.

You reach his position, abandoning your spear as well, throwing it into a nearby barbarian’s chest, drawing your sword and dagger. The champion eyes you, surprised at the fact someone is next to him.

“This is not your place, newcomer,” he states.

“And I’m here all the same,” you answer with a slight shrug. The enclosing barbarians attack. Wide sweeps with their axes deflect from your dagger, parrying the strikes off-target. Once an opening presents itself, which doesn’t take long, your sword lands true in a series of slashes and cuts. You move swiftly, not standing in one location, always taking the fight towards the nearest tribesman. Something flies by your ear. An arrow. A body drops behind you, the result of Pralthar’s aim.

More appear. Your constant movement is starting to wear on your strength. While your training is far more than the soldiers around you, your endurance is lacking. Such strength is only built during battle, the constant swinging of the sword, the constant blocking of blows. Your breath becomes heavy, breathing through an open mouth rather than nose, the first sign of fatigue. Staying in motion is using up all your energy, although standing still would result in being overwhelmed. You need to decide a course of action, and both don’t bring confidence.

Victory will only be achieved with your superior technique. There are too many barbarians to stand in one spot. They will overwhelm and wear you down. You’re better off with your fluid-motion attack, even if it does use a lot of energy.

Labored by battle, you continue to swing your sword, always keeping your feet moving. Your breath is now struggling to keep up with the energy expenditure. Once each strike, each blow was paired with a sharp exhale. Now, you’re finding it hard to keep a normal cadence. Suddenly thirsty, your tongue sticks to the top of your mouth, your body using up most of its stored resources. Stubborn, though, you continue attacking.

The champion does the same beside you, although he looks to be hardly breathing. This type of fighting is normal for him, endurance built up over countless skirmishes. The shield and sword in his hands are simply extensions of his limbs; they aren’t added weight to carry.

An exhausting swing of your sword brings you off-balanced. The champion steps in front of you, blocking a blow that would have been your death.

“Are you mad? Get back with the others!” he shouts.

Your distraction causes an axe to land true in the champion’s chest. He falls next to you squirming, a fatal cavity pouring red from his chest, a few white bones sticking through the blood, caved in by the blow. He attempts to rise, and a spear meets his calf, pinning him to the ground. Horrified, you try to help, only to receive a similar treatment. Soon, you’re overwhelmed and die to a series of ravaging strikes.

You simply can’t keep up your preferred method of attack. Not for a prolonged battle. The technique you possess is meant for one-on-one battles, not for engagements over a long period of time, especially when you’re fighting against superior numbers. A warrior must adapt to the situation in front of him, and you do just that.

Instead of charging the barbarian ahead of you, your feet remain still. You place a slight bend in your knees in order to absorb the impact of the impending blows. Your sudden shift in tactic causes a slight confused look from underneath the man’s unshaved beard. He takes the offensive, rushing with powerful overhand blows.

Each one is absorbed and redirected, but you can’t stand in one place very long, not without a shield. Yours lies a few feet behind you. You dive back, rolling underneath the swing of an axe, throwing your dagger simultaneously, sticking it in a nearby barbarian’s neck. Shield in hand, you rise to meet the attacking barbarian. More blows are defended, this time absorbed through the shield and subsequently, your unconditioned arm.

Satisfied at the retrieval of the shield, you start to counter with your own strikes. Only, reaching the shield has taken too much time, enough time for the barbarians to surround you. You defend as many blows as you can, but ultimately your life is surrendered to their countless, zealous strikes.

Your instructions were very clear from K’rell. Don’t break rank for any reason. You trust in the man’s expertise. Besides, you’re stronger as a single unit. The “champion” is obviously used to his position out front. That was clearly shown through the friendliness of the banter. It doesn’t feel right, but you remain in rank. The formation relies on it. The squadleader notices the surrounding barbarians and commands the unit forward.

The champion weaves his spear in an attempt to keep his opponents at bay, stopping them from closing in. He thrusts forward, then quickly angles to the right, narrowly avoiding an incoming axe swing. He turns, throwing his shoulder into a nearby barbarian, the one who almost took his head with the axe, pushing the man back a few steps. The champion’s spear finds his off-balanced flesh.

More close in. The lone man whips around facing towards the squad, back turned towards the hills. His spear stabs forward, planting itself in another barbarian. Instead of pulling it out, he drives it deeper, pushing the man backward into several other tribesmen. The champion continues pushing, using the man impaled by his spear as a battering ram to reach back to the V formation. Along the way, he ducks down, sliding his buckler to a strap on his back, protecting himself like the shell of a turtle. Finally, he arrives back to the formation, a line cut through the barbarians, several cuts and glancing blows displayed on his body. Nothing too serious, though.

The barbarians’ eyes on the lone man, they don’t notice Pralthar’s command. You do your best to follow the shift, although the instructions are nothing you’ve heard before. The champion’s mad scramble had brought the barbarians into a trap, putting himself as the bait. The snare snaps shut. On one angle of the V, the tribesmen don’t see the other side closing in. The tip as a hinge, the far side of the V swings around, pincering the barbarians in from both sides. Steadily, methodically, you continue the attack, blocking first with your shield then stabbing forward with your spear. Soon, between a pile of dead tribesmen, you’re face-to-face with the otherside of the pincer. The day is won.

The remaining barbarians, still outnumbering the squad, flee towards the hills. Strange. You assumed they would fight until none remained. That’s the way of their god, if you remember your studies correctly. Perhaps they noticed not a single Helswith man had fallen. Perhaps they knew they were outmatched. Still, the behavior strikes you as strange. It doesn’t seem to bother the others.

You follow the others back to the camp. The rest of the Reapers start to remove and clean their armor.
