Caius, the small-framed man handing out spears, creates a fire, running back and forth between the makeshift storeroom, a pile of boxes under tarp, and fire pit, gathering ingredients for the night’s meal.

K’rell places a bedroll and canvas in your arms. “All the bunks are taken,” he says, motioning towards the barracks, then towards the lone man sitting cross-legged under a nearby latus tree. “At least the champion has company now.”

Curious. Not only does the man fight alone, he sleeps alone, in the traditional sense of the word. You stride to the latus, noticing its jagged branches are empty of any flower, fruit, or leaves. On the surface it seems dead. Deep, though, are its roots. Your former mentor used to call them “icebergs of the desert.” Funny, that statement.

“You have an interesting battle tactic,” you speak, taking a seat under the latus tree. “I’m surprised it hasn’t gotten you killed yet.”

“You saw them today. Our run-ins with the tribesmen haven’t been with their best warriors,” the man answers, resting his head against the trunk. Many cuts lie on his arms, a few on his face. Unlike the others, he hasn’t removed his armor. You haven’t either.

“That’s not a great reason. What if they had sent their best warriors?”

“Then I’d be resting with the Eternal Father, not this tree.”

“You’ve made your peace then,” you comment.

The man turns, weary eyes turning sharp, vibrant. “I’m not done with this life yet. Don’t mistake my acceptance of finality as lack of desire. There is still plenty for me. I need to…” he cuts off, perhaps sharing more than he would have liked. He sighs, eyes turning weary again. “We’re all expendable on the front. I’d be willing to bet it wasn’t accolade that brought you here. We’re the first line of defense, minor headwinds meant to slow down the horde. Nothing more. The sooner you accept that, the better off you’ll be.”

“I don’t accept that,” you say. “I’m not here to merely slow down the horde. I’m here to stop it. I’m going to kill the Great Warlord.”

Your statement seems to entertain the man, obviously thinking it absurd. “Ha! I wish you all the best. You may meet the Eternal Father before me then. Unless the Great Warlord himself marches on this very position, you might find it hard to reach him. Even if he does, you’ll find it just as hard -- moreso, with every available warrior of his battle-ready.”

“Still, the statement remains.”

“Best of luck then. I’m Paxson.”

The hulking man, K’rell, sits on a sizable boulder, just outside of the barracks. His armor is removed and lies on the ground next to him. Instead, he wears a leather vest and trousers that travel 3/4s down the length of his legs. The point of his spear is rested against his thigh, holding it steady for the whetstone in his left hand.

“You did well out there, newcomer. I was afraid you would break rank to help Paxson. You have that look about you. Those of us who’ve been on the front awhile know when a man doesn’t need help when it comes to killin’.”

He looks up momentarily to see the words absorbed, then continues sharpening his spear.

“What’s the deal with him anyway?” you ask. “He’s not one of you?”

K’rell stops his work with the whetstone, sighing. “Where to begin? That man has earned the trust of every man within the Reapers. He may lack a soldier's refinement, but that man was born for battle.”

“But still he fights alone.”

“Not alone,” K’rell corrects. “We all support him. Hell, the squadleader only fires his greatbow in defense of Paxson. The tribesmen flock to him, being distracted long enough for the V formation to cut through their line.”

“Seems to work well...as long as Paxson can survive long enough.”

“Listen, did you come here to discuss battle tactics? It’s unconventional, and I certainly wouldn’t want to be the one standing on my own, but it’s worked for countless skirmishes now. We couldn’t throw slaves into our formation, armed, and expect them to have our backs. They’d most likely plant their knives there.”

Realizing you may have overstepped, you answer. “That was not my intention. From my perspective, there’s an obvious rift between one man and the rest of the Reapers, the former taking on more risk than the latter while not having a bunk to his name.”

“No one said it’s fair,” K’rell replies. “It’s effective and he’s treated as well as a slave can be. Works for both sides if you ask me.”

A slave. That explains it.

The thin man, Caius, is stoking the fire when you approach. He’s older than the rest of the men and wears the experience well. Like the rest of the Reapers, he’s removed his armor and wears a leather vest and trousers. He squats down, poking and prodding the lumber used for the fire, seeking to reposition some of the logs for more heat.

“Need help?” you ask.

Caius rises from his squat, eyeing you up. “You ever cooked before?”

“Only for myself.”

“I’m afraid that doesn’t help me then. Taste aside, there is a fine window to hit when it comes to quantity. I can’t short the portion or the boys go hungry, and making too much goes to waste -- we only have limited rations.”

A passing member of the Reapers calls out with a chuckle, “Let him help, Caius. Your broth was basically water last night.”

The comment causes frown to fall over Caius’ face. He watches the man until he’s out of listening range, head turning with his eyes like watching a ship sail past. Then, a smirk replaces the frown. “Heh, the broth was water last night. Ran out of bones to create a proper one. Ended up using poorly-filtered water for a darker color and spiced the hell out of it.”

“I get it,” you say. “‘Improvination and adaptation are a necessity for a soldier.’”

One of Caius’ eyes peers at you. “Been reading Count Otto and the Ways of Being? You must be the first enscriptee to show up quoting literature.”

“I’ve had no small amount of lessons as a kid. I’ve forgotten most of it by now, just bits and pieces that stuck throughout the years. Ways of Being, though, is somewhat of a recent read.”

“Ahh, yes. I know of your origin -- and why you’ve been ‘promoted’ to the front. It’s no easy thing, giving up wealth and inheritance.”

“How would you know that? I’ve only just arrived.”

“Pralthar is a wise squadleader. He knows to listen to those more experienced for advice. I may not have the raw strength of K’rell, but here,” Caius points to his head. “is where true strength lies. Besides, I always pester the messenger boys for the latest gossip. I’m sure they draw straws to see who delivers here. Let’s just say I have a tendency to make them uncomfortable.”

“In my experience, there’s no substitute for raw strength. That skull of yours won’t protect a tribesman’s axe.”

Caius’ face shifts into a satisfied look. “There, my noble comrade, is where you’re wrong. Have you heard of helmets? I don’t think they were created with raw strength.”

He does make a good point.

Caius’ cooking completed, the Reapers gather around the fire, passing by Caius with their bowls out. Single file, one-by-one, their discipline extends to the way meals are received. After filling their bowl, seating around the fire is taken in a similar manner. The first with their food travels to the farthest seat and the second next to him and so on.

The sun, hanging low in the sky, showers the western front in its heavenly glow, dyeing dry grass and dead branches with its golden light. The soup isn’t great. Everyone knows it, even Caius, but the High Lord’s army prioritizes utility over showmanship...at least when it comes to the front.

You’re learning the expendable nature of the border wasn’t originally tied to the position. It used to be a thing of honor. Slowly, though, death by death, the frontsmen learned the truth of their reality. They wouldn’t admit it, but that type of thing stresses a bond of loyalty.

“...and I thought he was going to run off on his own, but he stayed in rank. I can’t remember the last time someone was dumped on us that actually listens to orders.”

K’rells distinctive voice brings you from your thoughts, as you gather he can only be talking about you.

“Except for Paxson, you mean,” the man next to him, Gibraltar, a clean-cut man of sizable size, answers. Sizable, next to anyone other than K’rell that is.

“That goes without saying,” K’rell replies.

“Speaking of those two,” Pralthar speaks from across the fire. Even though he holds his own tent, separate from the barracks, he seems to spend more time with the squad than alone in his privacy. The men only respect him more for it. “It’s time you discover your similarities and if need be, hash them out. Better confront it now, before you share the same battlefield.”

“What similarities? I hardly know the newcomer,” Paxson’s voice carries from your left.

“Likewise,” you find yourself saying.

Pralthar stands up, so all can get a full view as he speaks. “It is not normal for the High Lord to reinforce his strength with...other means. By the number who’ve fallen on the plains, mere bodies to distract the tribesmen’s axes, I can see why it’s highly unconventional. It only speaks to the severity of the situation and the importance of our position. Paxson, you’ve proven yourself as one of us. If it were me, I’d use your service as justification for your freedom. Alas, I cannot. Newcomer, of the Nameless: that is not your first title. The councilor’s report told me much more. A family house deserted, inheritance thrown away. Sound about right, Young Master Scholhart?”

As the final word hangs in the air, the former name that accompanied yours, you sense Paxson staring in your direction.

You answer. “Whatever point you’re trying to prove falls short. That name means nothing to me. A past long forgotten.”

“You do look like him. Your father, my master,” Paxson’s voice rings out, the statement made void of emotion, simply the facts.

Similar origin indeed. Pralthar was right. Curse that house. You turn to your left. “Whatever you hold against Arroden is misplaced if directed towards me. Taking it out on me would be doing my father a favor.”

Paxson scoffs. “You’re just like him. Assuming everything’s about you. I know my place, Nameless. I know the consequences of disobedience. You have nothing to fear from me.”

“That settles it then,” Squadleader Pralthar concludes. “I better not hear of any infighting, otherwise--”

His sentence is cut-off by a man, a boy really, running into the camp. A messenger from the High Lord’s main force. His clothes are ruffled and stained with sweat. Dirt marks his face as if he tripped and fell along the way.

“Where is Squadleader Pralthar?” the messenger asks, voice of a similar maturity with his age.

Pralthar steps forward, examining the boy. “I am him. Speak, boy.”

The messenger unfolds a parchment from his inner pocket, smoothing the edges to clearly read it. “By High Lord Ursa’s decree, all squads along the western border are to cease holding their defensive positions and march on the barbarian’s plains. The High Lord wants you to target villages and cargo routes. The savages will be left in chaos and vulnerable to a major attack by the High Lord’s main force. Your efforts will bring glory to Helswith and High Lord Ursa.”

Pralthar’s hand rests on the boy’s shoulder. He speaks calmly, like a father would to his child. “Grab some water, then kindly remove yourself from my camp.” The severity of his words, and the implied “or else” causes the boy’s eyes to widen. The boy stands still for a moment, then jumps to grab a ladle from the water stores.

“Well, you heard him. Tomorrow we march into the plains,” Squadleader Pralthar addresses the men around the fire.

She barely escaped the camp alive. It took every part of her training, but she managed. Projecting illusions took all of Morgen’s strength. There was nothing she could do to save him. She had to leave. She would come back for him, though. Just as soon as the mission is complete. She had a score to settle.

According to the councilor, Joren was held by Helswithian guards, however Morgan was in no condition to head straight for him...despite her burning desire to. Instead, she fled to the plains, sneaking past one of the High Lord’s western front squads. It was easier than it should have been. Then again, they weren’t really concerned with people sneaking into the plains.
Morgan found shelter underneath a stony overhang. Rock, halfway buried into the rolling hills, stuck out, providing a canopy of stone. The burned remains of a fire pit was telling that Morgan wasn’t the first person to find this particular place. It’s been dead awhile, ash mostly, so she felt safe enough to stay for the night. Still, her hand didn’t move from the hilt at her side.

Rest, recover, then sneak back into the camp for Joren. It’s a sound plan.

---

She awoke to the sound of men’s voices and footsteps dangerously near. Gods, she must have really spent her energy to not have been alerted sooner. Morgan sits up, listening for more movement. Dry grass at her feet, covered by in shadow from her night’s refuge, Morgan patiently waits for the approaching soldiers. There’s no use in running. Where would she go? She shouldn’t have used so much of her power. It’s her own fault.

Two men eventually find her. They’re dressed in leather armor, painted with the High Lord’s colors. Funny. All the soldiers she saw in the warcamp had their armor embroidered. These must be low level soldiers, or western frontsmen.

“That’s when I told her, there’s no going back. Either you commit now, otherwise the ship’s sailed… Hey who’s this?” One of the soldiers finishes his story, finding Morgan at the end. Both men are quickly approaching middle-age, a slowed metabolism showing by the way their leather armor juts out, not unlike the rolling hills of the plains.

“A woman lost on the plains? She doesn’t look like a savage,” the other man peers at Morgan, his brow furrowing in thought. “Hey wasn’t there a woman who escaped from the warcamp?”

“There was,” Morgan answers. “And you better forget you ever saw her.”

“Not sure I like being talked to that way,” the first soldier speaks to his fellow.

“You should be used to it by now,” the other replies. Back towards Morgan, he adds, “Sorry, lady. Orders are orders. ‘The capture of this woman will net the honorable man fifteen marks and a granted leave of absence of one month.’”

“Your ‘orders’ sound more like a bounty. Surely, honorable men such as yourselves are above such distasteful actions.”

They look at one another. One shrugs to the other. “Sorry, miss…”

Morgan sighs. As they draw closer, she holds up her hands, palms facing them as if in surrender. Then, when they’re in range, Morgan’s open palms curl into fists. One finds a jaw, and the other finds a temple. Both men collapse to the ground, like saddlebags slipping from a sprinting horse.

“Hmm. I suppose that’s as much a challenge as I expected,” Morgan comments.

Rest, recover, then sneak back into camp. The first two are taken care of. As Morgan walks out from underneath the stone, she surveys the scene before her. The High Lord’s army, in full force, is marching directly toward her. Countless soldiers, like stones on the rocky beaches of the Helswith, heading her way. Infantry march in small clusters, backed by archers behind them. The famed chariots of High Lord Ursa are behind, ready to gallop at a moment’s notice. Slower moving siege machines, ballistae and light trebuchet follow behind the calvary, although their arrival at a destination would be far delayed.

“And here I thought it would be simple. Gods, nothing is ever easy,” Morgan mutters under her breath, examining the two unconscious soldiers at her feet, searching for supplies. Satisfied by a few rations, she takes off, west, away from the approaching army and travels deeper into the barbarian plains. Things never go as planned.

It was time. Damn savages have threatened his borders long enough. For years, he put up with their constant buzzing, minor annoyances to bring him glory. Now, though, somehow they’ve banded, uniting the western tribes under a single banner. Like the stories of old, a “Great Warlord” is leading their people. Damn savages. He’ll run each one down with his chariots.

Ursa, the High Lord, leans over a table, hands bearing most of his weight against the structure. Atop, a map of the plains sits, cutting off a few miles into the Helswith to the east. Ursa runs a hand through his dark hair. Despite his namesake, his face is clean-shaven, proper, as a High Lord’s should be. His wavy hair reaches his shoulders, braided with a few ceremonial beads at the back, a few loose strands falling in front of his face. It seems no matter how tightly woven the beads are, the same strands fall loose. He’s grown rather fond of them. So has his latest concubine. She’s asleep now, though, giving him time to study the upcoming battle plans. The sweet thing breathes softly behind him, auburn hair spread around her like leaves on a willow tree, bed covers barely exposing the top of her nipple.

Outnumbered 20-1, the High Lord thinks to himself. But still they haven’t marched in force yet. Why haven’t they marched in force?

His eyes glued to the map, the High Lord imagines through the possibilities of the upcoming battle’s outcome.

“The plains aren’t as plain-like as one would think. They’re rocky. Rarely does one discover a hill unmarked by stones. The flatlands themselves are another challenge. High grass, hiding rock beneath their strands, fills the plains, causing disruption where one would move quickly through.”

The words of Ursa’s advisors ring in his head as his gaze remains fixed on the map. The environment may be less than ideal for his famed chariots, but he’s confident in his might. Not a single frontier squad had allowed a barbarian raid to reach the main camp. Heavy losses were incurred with the slaves and non-soldiers he recruited, but still, with their numbers, the tribesmen should have at least punched through a single squad. Perhaps they’re as ill-trained as his reports say. Overconfidence was the mark of his father, the previous High Lord Ursang. Ursa would be different. He had to be different.

Hands appear at his lower stomach, slipping inside of the sheer silk robe around Ursa’s shoulders. A sly woman, this one. Cold hands feel his tanned skin, its dark texture made warm by the finest wine in Helswith. A woman’s cheek plants against his upper back, pressing herself closer into the Helswith leader.

“You’re always so serious when you look at that thing.” Her voice is soft, high-pitched. Just as you’d expect from someone who possesses such beauty.

“I bear the burden of my father and my father’s father,” Ursa answers, placing his hands on the backs of the woman’s. Gods, they’re soft. Tender.

“You will cut down the savages?” the woman asks, knowing full-well the answer. She had, after all, been in Ursa’s bed when the idea came to his mind.

Ursa nods, sending the loose strands in front of his face dancing. “Yes. They’ve grown too bold. Allowing them to live, to band together like this was a mistake of my father’s. One that I will soon correct.”

“Do you know why they have allied themselves now? Did you do something against them?”

“Not at all, my dear. One cannot understand the ways of the savages. They sacrifice their fellows to their god. As far as our former diplomats reported, they have no written word. They are mere beasts, superstitious in nature, allowed to roam at our approval. It’s gone on far too long, and they will soon learn why threatening Helswith is not in their best interest.”

The High Lord sips at the goblet resting on the table top and continues. “Their ‘Great Warlord’ is simply a man clinging to the past, using an ancient title to further his own pursuit. He will soon learn the danger in threatening a true leader, a nation strengthened with military might. This will be my greatest glory, my dear. I hope you count yourself lucky to share it with me.”

“Share? I take what I want,” the woman answers, sending her hands lower. The High Lord doesn’t stop her.

Those two soldiers, who surprisingly managed to sneak up on Morgan -- due to her exhaustion -- weren’t the only ones she ran into. More accurately, ran through. The plains offer little shelter for someone trying to go unnoticed. The plain’s tall grass and rocky hills help, sure, but those are more temporary solutions. They work well for sneaking around a few soldiers, but there’s a whole goddamn army at her back.

Tonight, however, she’s seeking them. Her target is an officer, one that will possess knowledge of a certain prisoner in their camp or at the very least be able to share what happens to prisoners once the army mobilizes.

It’s dark. Small fires burn safely within the camp’s interior, protected by both patrolling and stationary guards. Tiny movement appears near the flame. It may be late, but not everyone is asleep within the camp. Something to take into account. Tall grass as her cover, Morgan glides forward, silent, like a lion stalking prey.

The first line of defense doesn’t notice her. Neither does the second.

Morgan finds herself in rows of tents, lined up like buildings in a city. She pauses a moment in an “alley,” taking refuge in its shadow. Heavy boots draw near, then fade past. A group of men finally retiring to their makeshift barracks, if Morgan had to guest. They don’t notice the woman crouched between canvas structures.

There. Her prey must be inside. A tent, largest from what Morgan’s seen, lies ahead. Several spearmen are posted outside as sentries. Where exactly does one hide their secrets? Behind lock and key, in this case, armored soldiers. Morgan waits, listening for movement, then darts across the street towards the next row of tents, hiding between each. She repeats the action three more times before arriving at her destination.

The tent is of red canvas. Soft light shines from within, illuminating small gaps between the canvas and dirt in a line of light. Four soldiers at the door, another four patrolling the perimeter. Her prey must really be paranoid. For good reason. After assessing the patrol’s movement, their cadence, their pattern, Morgan breaks for the tent, aiming for the light peering through the canvas floor. She slides, well more of a roll so as to not disrupt the dirt, scooping the bottom of the tent up, pulling it just high enough for her body to slip under. As quickly as it’s raised, it drops back to its original position. One of the patrolling guards strolls past, oblivious to the quick motion that just took place.

The interior looks familiar. Red silk pillows, arranged in a circle, lie in the center of the tent, its backdrop a desk in the foreground of several bookcases. It’s a little different, but there’s no mistaking the councilor’s furniture. Strange. The soldiers outside were normal, not the armored elites that separated Morgan from her partner. Still, Morgan keeps an air of caution. She definitely did not want to run into them again, especially alone. She’s about to discover how formidable the councilor is without his elite guard. Not very, is Morgan’s guess.

His back is turned, hands searching for a particular book on the shelves. Gods, it must be difficult to travel with so many leather-bounds. A little easier, though, when you have free labor chained at the wrists. He doesn’t notice her presence until Morgan’s hand clamps around his mouth, dagger pressing into his lower back.

Morgan brings her lips close to the councilor’s ear, allowing him to feel her breath as she whispers. “Hello again, your eminence. Our last conversation was so rudely interrupted. I assure you, that won’t be the case this time around.”

“You...you…” the councilor tries to speak, words failing him at Morgan’s sudden appearance.

“Yes, me,” Morgan answers with a little laugh, one that would get a man’s blood hot in an aleroom setting. “You know who I seek. Where is he?”

“We released him,” the councilor manages to say.

“You what? For what purpose?”

The councilor answers, gaining back his resolve. “Tracking purposes. The High Lord is marching straight for the horde’s leader, and we, uh, don’t exactly know his location. The prisoner was obviously aligned with the ‘Great Warlord,’ and he’ll take us straight to him.”

“Fools. Why not simply interrogate him?”

“We did. Not even our thickest needles could bring a response. So I had an unfortunate ‘servant’ bring the prisoner’s meal, giving him instructions that would...present a certain opportunity for the prisoner. He’ll lead us right to the horde’s position where High Lord Ursa will cut them down.”

“And where exactly is his last known location?”

The councilor replies by pointing to a scroll on one of his shelves. Morgan guides them both over, where the councilor grabs and unrolls the parchment, allowing them both to read its contents. It’s a simple map of the plains, marked with coordinates, dates, and times. Whoever is tracking Joren is sending back current updates of their location as the most recent date is yesterday’s.

“This will do,” Morgan comments, shoving her dagger into the councilor’s back. His cry, mixed with a gurgle, is muted by her palm against his mouth. Morgan carefully guides the councilor, again, this time to the floor as not to alert the sentries. The floor at his bookshelves start to match the red silk pillows in the center of the tent.

Morgan folds the parchment into a small square and places it inside of her pocket. She had some ground to cover. First Joren, then her Nameless partner. Lady give her strength.

The man’s face is a mixture of surprise and bewilderment at your sudden arrival. The battlefield is a chaotic place, one-on-one duels have no place here. Whatever “honor” comes from testing yourself against another is lost, a false romantic notion brought by poets and scholars. True war is unfair. Rules don’t apply, save for one. Survive.

Your blade finds his exposed back, his axe swing already blocked by Paxson’s buckler. Paxson, no stranger to unfair circumstances, learned that lesson quickly in the arena, a lesson that he brought with him to the western plains. Gladiatorial matches are often stacked on one side, especially with lesser known names. It’s all about the enjoyment of the people, rather than an even fight. It was just one of Paxson’s many challenges along the way to reuniting with her.

Your current battlefield is a dirt road, not wide enough for two wagons side-by-side, along the northern coast of the plains. The Reapers were sent deeper west and then north to the coastline with orders to stop supply lines from reaching the horde. With resource shortages, the tribes are bound to turn on one another.

Your mission would be a lot easier with naval support from King Tristrand, a simple blockage would result in the same outcome of all your hard-fought efforts, but the islands to the east lie silent. It’s a mystery to Helswith, as Tristrand relies on importing goods to survive. You’re sure there will be a sizable tax added to Helswith goods after the war ends for their unresponsiveness and seemingly unwillingness to aid.

Four wagons, single file, are hit hard by the Reapers. Battles were won outnumbered by the tribesmen. These supply raids could hardly be considered as such. Often they were poorly defended, their position made worse by the terrain. It only adds to the Reapers’ chance at success.

Paxson blocks a spear, redirecting the weapon away from his body. He steps forward, coming into sword range -- a place where spearmen lie exposed -- and finishes the man with one swing of his short sword. Three more stand in front of him, one after another due to the narrow road. On the open plains, they’d surround him. Here, they aren’t afforded that luxury.

Glancing to Paxson, you duck underneath the wagon, rolling to the opposite side. There, you’re met with an axehead, barely missing your ducking head. Still in motion, you kick a foot out, tripping your opponent, a man with unkempt hair and beard like a mane, swinging your sword up, catching his throat on the way down. Hurdling the body, you make for the back of the wagon, meaning to flank the three barbarians closing in on Paxson. You arrive to find Paxson planting his sword in a fallen opponent, the last of the three.

He shrugs. “Sometimes the direct approach is best.”

You eye the small wounds accumulated on his forearms. His left leg is dyed red from an unseen cut, the blood staining his trouser leg from within, not from his handiwork. Then, you look down at your own body. Not a single mark is on your body. “Sure, if you want to single-handedly keep the surgeon in business.”

Paxson laughs. “Minor scrapes, nothing more. You fight well for one raised in silk sheets, despite your aversion for dirtying yourself.”

“I have no problem with that,” you answer. “These barbarians simply offer me no threat. The gap between our skill level is too wide, although by your ‘scrapes,’ I can tell the gap is lesser.”

Squadleader Pralthar approaches, bow in hand. His left side of his face is bathed in grime and sweat. Obviously, he had engagement well-within melee range. “Report casualties.”

You glance around, seeing Caius and K’rell alive and well, the other two from your initial strike force on the wagons. Pralthar and the rest of the Reapers followed up in the chaos you ensued.

“None, sir,” you answer, jumping on top of the nearest wagon. You rip back the canvas covering its contents. “This one’s holding dried meat. Looks like some fruit as well.”

“Dried too, I hope?” Pralthar asks.

“Yes, sir,” you reply. “Much easier to deal with than fresh.”

“Take the reins. We’ll escort these back to the cave,” the squadleader commands. After searching the tribesmen’s bodies and not finding much, you pack up the captured supplies and travel back to the cave, your temporary base of operations.

The “cave” is more of an inlet, a place on the cliffside where sea level digs into the bluffs. A winding road leads down to the beach, where the overhang of rock sits a few hundred paces. From the plains, it’s hidden. From the sea is a different story, but the barbarians aren’t ones to travel by boat. Their sea activity is kept solely to supplies.

For the time being, you’re content to stay in the Reapers and the authority of Pralthar. You haven’t forgotten your mission. It’s burned in your memory, and the tattoo on your arm is a constant reminder. As the Lady’s herald, your goal of confronting the Great Warlord has remained unchanged. The task will be easier once you weaken his forces, and with Pralthar in charge, you’re doing exactly that. Only a fool would charge directly in, placing their strength directly against the Warlord’s. Funny, that’s likely what Paxson would do in your position. You’ve learned patience. A hunter requires the trait to strike at the proper moment. With the Reapers, you chip away at the Warlord’s defenses, seeking to land the killing blow once he’s vulnerable.

By the time you finish unloading, the sun is nearly set. The cave’s floor is sand, so the Reapers have taken to creating makeshift wooden floorboards, built with planks and various pieces of lumber picked up in raids. Each man, even Paxson, has their own island, a floorboard of wood with a personal tent built on top. Most, however, don’t take advantage of the canvas privacy, seeking companionship over solitude. The air is warm enough that a fire isn’t needed, and the dried food on the latest recovery takes out the other use for a fire.

“Get some rest, men. Tomorrow we’ll continue along the coast. It’s best not to stay in one place too long,” Pralthar speaks from his island.

You gladly follow the command, feeling the strain of battle now that adrenaline’s worn off. Slowly, you feel your endurance being built up, a result of prolonged battle. While you have been well-trained, the grind, the grueling consistency of battle wore heavy on your body. Now, you feel in a place where your body is conditioned for it, like there’s no longer a liability in that regard.

Your eyes begin to soften, drawing heavy, then closing completely. Bright light! The suddenness causes you to sit up suddenly. Around you, everyone’s asleep. Already? It’s only been a few seconds. It’s completely dark, no sign of the sun is present. Perhaps, it was longer than a few seconds after all.

The sudden light subsided, you glance around sensing for the Lady. Where is she? The woman flocked by crows. You long to view her timeless face, one that’s unmarked by flaws, her golden hair floating just above her bare shoulders. She’s been absent of late. Somehow that brings a feeling of loneliness, like the empty side of a widow’s bed. She said she would appear when you need her. She should be present all the time then.

Your arm burns for a moment as if a stray ember fell on top of it. You look down. The tattoo on your inner arm, a crow mid-flight, glows softly on one side. The left wing. As you draw your arm closer for a better look, the light subtly moves to another section of the bird, although the glow itself remains stationary. It’s pointing in a specific direction, like guiding stars for sea voyage. It’s dark. No one else is awake.

Your last interaction with the Lady left an impression in your mind. Besides drawing you closer to her, deeping your bond, it was the first time you learned of her. She fights an unseen battle. She’s charged with stopping the return of Uralan. She chose you as her herald. If this is her only way to warn you of danger, a brief moment between battle, you will gladly adhere to her warning. Your trust is fully in the Lady, and you’ll follow her signs.

You rise without a sound, meaning to follow the glow without waking the others. Despite the repertoire that you’ve steadily built up over skirmishes, it doesn’t look good if you sneak away from camp. You’re still, after all, an “add-on,” a soldier that is conscripted into service rather than joining of his own accord. That fact alone will always stain your reputation with a linger of doubt, especially this early on.

Sand is easy enough to move silently through. Its sound is non-existent with your light footsteps, and there aren’t obstacles on the ground to give away your position, such as dry leaves or small twigs. It’s sand, rocks, and some shells, which you take great care to avoid. The light takes you further down the beach, away from the winding path to reach the cave.

Your vision is dyed with blue light from the moon, shining visibly, sparkling a deep navy, on the ocean water before you. Minutes later, you look down at your arm for direction. It’s dark, the glow no longer appearing. What is the Lady trying to show you? There, on the water. Ships. Shadowy, masts rising like scarred trees. They float at the coastline, sails folded up in an anchored position.

Anchored position… The cave! You turn around, ready to warn the others of the sudden ships and come face-to-face with Paxson. He stands, hands on his hips, eyeing you.

“Tristrand,” he spits. Seeing your surprise, he continues. “Heard you getting up. Thought you might be up to something. One does not sleep easily in a gladiator school.”

“Tristrand. What’s he doing here?” you ponder aloud. “We need to get back--”

That’s when you notice the countless rowboats on the shore. Dark figures stand on the beach, standing above the Reapers, like an executioner over a kneeling man. Desperately, you rush forward, intending to sprint back to the cave. Paxson stops you with an arm.

“Did you know,” he asks, not as a question. “Did you know they were coming. Is that why you fled at the exact moment of their arrival?”

He peers at you like a father searching for dishonesty in his son’s eye. “Of course I didn’t know. We need to get back. We need to help them.”

You attempt to push past him, but he holds you in front. “Bullshit. It’s too late anyway. You had something to do with this. I’m sure of it.”

Angered by his accusation, you shove Paxson with both hands, sending him stumbling a few steps back. “Damn you. I had nothing to do with this. We need to get back. We need to help them.”

An anger, similar to yours, folds his face into a scowl, although he does not strike back. He does keep you from advancing though, stretching both arms out like a net capturing fish in the sea. “I’m afraid it’s no use. There are too many of them. How is it that you left at the exact moment they showed up?”

The repetition of his question and the implication associated with it causes you to fire a right fist into Paxson’s face. He stumbles, clutching where your blow landed, but then returns to his standing position, arms stretched out, stoicism filling his face rather than the anger displayed a moment ago. His demeanor only ignites you. You throw another right hand, then a left, finishing by grabbing the back of Paxson’s head and sending your knee into his nose. He stumbles, again, then returns to his position, blood pouring from a broken nose.

“Will that be all, Master Scholhart?” he speaks.

Master Scholhart. Your father, his owner. The bond shared by battle is not enough to erase the scars left by servitude. The very thing you’ve spent your life avoiding has become your reality. A curse haunting your blood. The sins of a father passed down to his firstborn. Master Scholhart, a title you replaced with Nameless, still rears its ugly head. Broken, pieced together by an attempt at redemption, you collapse to your knees. Paxson still stands.

Pure disgust fills your mouth, like biting into a piece of spoiled meat. After a few heaves, your body hurls bits of dry meat and fruit from your mouth. As you wipe the corner of your mouth, movement appears in front of you. A hand outstretched, a symbol of aid, friendship. You look up to see Paxson offering a hand to help you to your feet. Humbled, you allow this man, a slave owned by your father, a man forced into combat same as you, a man marked by similar tragedy, to pull you up.

The newly arrived sailors slaughter your friends on the beach. There’s nothing you can do about it.

You watched them all night. There was no sleep for either you or Paxson. You found a spot on the bluffs and watched the sailors in the moonlight, now in the creeping light of the rising sun. With the sunlight, you’re able to see the colors in which they fly. Royal blue. King Tristrand. So that’s why he’s been unresponsive to the High Lord’s messengers. He must be taking the conflict between Helswith and the tribesmen to further his own pursuits. Coward.

Surprisingly, the soldiers in blue don’t row back to their ship. They gather the Reapers’ supplies, most of which were a result from their raids, and pack up the captured carts. From your view, it looks like they are traveling deeper into the plains, using the very carts you won the day before.

As the soldiers move, you tail from a distance, the two of you. Since your skillset, as it comes to stealth, is far past Paxson’s, you take the lead, guiding him along the way. You thought maybe taking the lead would highlight your confrontation from last night, although Paxson seems to be past that. What’s done is done, and you have a joint vengeance to seek.

For days, they travel due south, heading straight for the heartland of the plains. Soon, the view of the ocean is replaced with nothing but grass, the bluffs a place you grew to enjoy, is left far behind you. Tracking them soon becomes difficult, not because they’re nimble, but due to the openness of the plains. As you traverse the rolling hills, you’re forced to wait until the soldiers reach the next peak before moving forward. Each time they pass from view, you grow a little nervous to lose them. You’re reminded, though, that a number such as theirs doesn’t simply disappear. Even if you got to the next peak and discovered they’d vanished, there would be clues leading in their direction. The thought is a bit comfortable, although it doesn’t entirely bring you to ease.

Cresting the next hill causes you to duck for cover. Sheltered by a boulder, you peer down the hillside. Like the way a forest hides the ground with its trees, the horde’s army is sitting at the bottom of the hill, a basin, flatlands large enough to hold the entire mob. Tristrand’s soldiers have brought you to the very doorsteps of the Great Warlord. The camp is built in a circular shape, all surrounding a tent that must be the size of a small building.

“Is that what I think it is?” Paxson whispers next to you.

“The Great Warlord,” you answer.

You notice the soldiers, Tristrand’s men, greet some of the sentries, then begin to set up camp just outside the horde’s. Seems despite their apparent partnership, they aren’t allowed fully into the warcamp. As you continue to watch, you realize your initial thought was a little off. While Tristrand’s men are on the outskirts of camp, several of them enter the horde, probably looking for a way to blow off steam. You’re sure the horde has plenty of strong drinks and willing women. Distractions, meant to stave off the burden of a soldier’s responsibility for a moment. Works well for the common soldier, at little expense to their leaders.

“Uh oh. I’m not sure I like that look,” Paxson comments, noticing your brow furled in thought.

Despite his light-hearted comment, you don’t reflect the same. “I told you once I would kill their leader. Tonight may be the night.”

“I’m all for taking the fight to them, but there are tens of thousands,” Paxson replies. “We didn’t even come across any Helswith soldiers along the way here. We’re deep in enemy territory without support.”

“I have enough support,” you answer, thinking of the Lady. She promised. She would aid you when you need her. This is the moment. You would need her to accomplish this task.

Paxson, thinking you meant him, says, “I’ll do what I can, but this is a one-way mission. I don’t possess your crafitness. I’m but a dull hammer meant to bash my enemies into submission.”

“‘Sometimes the direct approach is the best way,’” you quote Paxson.

“Gods. Sometimes it’s not.”

While the “direct approach” for Paxson may be lowering his shoulder and running through a door, your version of the statement is more subtle. An idea forms in your mind, but you remain in your position, watching the horde for a while longer. The soldiers in blue, Tristrand’s naval members, are able to walk freely within the camp. You see three of them make their way past several plainsmen who guard the perimeter. Gods. From here, they look out of their element, like a fish out of water.

If you’re going to make it two steps within the horde of barbarians, you’re going to need a disguise. Two royal blue uniforms should do the trick. Now, there’s just a matter of waiting for some of the naval members to isolate themselves enough to catch them unawares. You wait, patiently. Beside the three who initially entered the camp, the rest stick together, never straying too far from their position. That’s certainly going to make things more difficult. The day steadily transitions to evening, the sun lowering from its position directly above you. Huh. Sometimes all it takes is a change is perspective. Focusing too hard on one outcome can blind you from another, a simpler resolution.

Single lane dirt paths wind through the horde’s location, leading in different directions, ensuring the Great Warlord’s location is the center hub of the plains. King Tristrand’s soldiers, who’ve never visited the plains before, took a straight path to arrive, hiking over hills, most likely working from a compass direction rather than actual map. After spending some time in the plains, you’re not even sure a map would help. The roads themselves are hardly straightforward, each twisting and winding around stone and overgrown grass, crossing over one another like snakes in a bucket. You explain your idea to Paxson, who agrees, and follows you from your vantage point back to the nearest road.

---

It doesn’t take too long, not even an entire hour, before dust appears on the horizon. Someone’s coming your way. With this many warriors brought together, ones that are used to roaming freely on the plains, it’s no wonder tribesmen come and go almost constantly. They don’t travel in rows; they’re scattered on the road like patrons in a crowded alehouse.

“Scouts?” you whisper to Paxson. He’s crouched next to you. You’ve found a sizable boulder to hide behind, the overgrown grass surrounding you as a sanctuary. Between strands of grass, you can barely see through. Better a limited view than an exposed position.

“I don’t think so,” he whispers back. “Look.” Now that they’re closer, you notice two of them carry a twine of rabbit slung over their shoulders. Not a scouting party. Hunters.

You wait until they reach you, just barely passing by as to hit their flank. Again, your version of the “direct approach” bends the meaning of “direct.” Up close now, you count seven of them, each wearing light hide armor. Their armor wouldn’t do much good against a spearpoint, but it’d do the trick against a stray slash of the axe.

Realization falls over you. The tribesmen, at least these ones, aren’t equipped for a full-on clash with Helswith. Is that why they haven’t marched on the desert? They’re equipment is suited towards minor disputes, in-fighting, between tribes. Redirecting their combined focus on Helswith doesn’t change the fact that they are severely out engineered, despite their overwhelming numbers.

Using your training, you move swiftly and quietly behind the hunters, sticking low underneath their eye line. Your weight is dispersed through the balls of your feet, limiting the total amount of foot surface that touches the road; the less of your foot that physically touches the ground, the less likely an unwanted noise will appear. Muscles in your legs flex, absorbing the impact of your steps.

Your breath is intentionally slowed, and you creep forward at a steady pace, not allowing sudden movements to alert the hunters of your presence. Your dagger is already drawn. Too many would-be assassins make the mistake of drawing their weapon too close to their target, like people don’t notice the sound of a blade being pulled from its sheath. Your first victim is but ten feet away...six...three…

Paxon’s feet scuffle the ground. Seven pairs of eyes quickly turn around, eight when you look back to flash him a look of disapproval.

He doesn’t acknowledge your stare, rushing past you before you even turn back around towards the hunters. When you do, you see Paxson in the air, propelled higher by his charge. He lands on the first hunter, like a lion pouncing on its prey. Simultaneously, his short sword slashes the hunters neck, who, fallen prone, is unable to muster any sort of defense. Six remaining.

After getting past the initial surprise of the attack, the hunters gather, throwing down their catch to avenge their fellow man. All are focused on Paxson as he willingly threw himself into the group of hunters. Something wizzes past your ear, like an angry hornet after its nest is disturbed. All, minus one, are focused on Paxson, a tribesman nocking another arrow seems to have taken interest in you.

You throw your dagger at the archer, and unlike his attempt, your projectile lands, collapsing the man to his knees, briefly clutching the wound at his neck before falling face-first into the dirt. Then, you join Paxson’s engagement with the other five, flanking them from the side. The closest doesn’t react to your presence until it’s too late. Four. Paxson blocks an axe, sending the crown of his head into the man’s nose, stunning him, then stabbing him through the stomach. Three.

An axe swings at your torso, which you easily dodge by stepping out of range, gliding back in before the tribesman can recover. Your blade slashes through his chest in the exact place you avoided being fatally cut. Two. Paxson blocks a blow with his buckler, simultaneously stabbing in the opposite direction, burying the point of his short sword into a hunter trying to catch him unawares. One. Paxson bashes his shield forward, dazing the remaining man, then kicks his legs out from under him. His short short quickly follows up. Zero.

After, you and Paxson drag the bodies into the surrounding grass, doing your best to hide pooling blood from the dirt path. The result isn’t perfect, but the red sections of the dirt would easily be overlooked unless someone’s staring directly at them. Dressed now in the hunter’s garb, their catch of rabbit slung over your shoulders, you’re ready to infiltrate the horde. You’re ready to kill the Great Warlord. Uralan’s return must be stopped.

The next day, as you draw closer to the horde, you slowly begin to see that their camp is more like a small city, rather than a traditional war camp. The contrast between the Great Warlord’s and High Lord Ursa’s is easily seen. The horde has women and children running through the “streets,” marching with the warriors, making sure the men are fed and tended to. The more you think about it, the more it makes sense. The western tribes are used to fighting one another. Now, allied, they still don’t seem to trust one another, as they’re obviously unwilling to leave their families undefended. Or perhaps they’re worried about a Helswithian attack. Probably the former.

Just like you’d expect, nothing matches. The horde is like a quilt, pieced together with varying pieces not meant to be sewn together. The result, while functional in its designed purpose, quite frankly isn’t a pretty sight. Unlike the Helswithian matching silver and gold, the horde wears simple padded leather, allowing their hair and beards to grow long. There are no symbols displaying rank, no insignias, differing weapons and armor, just, a horde. Likewise, with such a high number of warriors, you’re able to slip into the camp unnoticed dressed as one of them.

The ground beneath you has been stamped to dirt. There may have been long grass here, in the basin, at one point, but not now. Not with hundreds of thousands of feet stomping on it daily. Dirt beneath your feet, surrounded mostly by warriors in leather armor, the horde’s camp is very...brown, and that’s not to mention the waste excreted by the large number either.

As far as you can tell, there’s no design to the horde’s layout. It seems like a mob of tents piled near one another. It’s easy to see where one tribe ends and another begins, though. Small walls built from stone, barely waist high, separate each tribe. The wall wouldn’t deter anyone from entering, but it definitely would point out who belongs or not. From what you’ve heard, crime -- at least thievery -- is almost non-existent with the horde. Removing limbs for petty theft will have that effect.

Only a few minutes into infiltrating the horde, and you realize the tribesmen are gathering in one direction, like a school of fish heading downstream. The quickest way to show you don’t belong is to continue in your direction, so you turn to follow the assembly. You end up in a large open area, unobstructed by equipment. The horde spans out before you, countless tribesmen lined up in no apparent order. If this were Helswith, they would be neatly placed in rank. Far off in the distance, across several thousand heads, is a wooden platform. A stage. On it, stands a man, hands clasped behind him, watching the horde assemble. His posture is forthright, displaying confidence at the number before him. The Great Warlord.

There are far better places to assassinate an army’s leader. Patience calls for you to wait for the proper moment. An attempt in front of his entire army isn’t the place. There will be a better opportunity, and you’ll be sure to find it.

The Great Warlord’s voice rings over the crowd, the horde of barbarians gathered at his beckening. His voice projects over a great distance, magically enhanced so that the horde could hear him speak. His vocal tone surprises you, though. It’s not ragged. It’s not rough. Rather, it’s smooth, his words flowing like a proper instructor or politician, both of which are skills required for his position.

“...the people of Helswith have lived high and mighty for too long. Comfort has crept into their veins, poisoning the host. They rest on fine silk and speak poorly of the laborman, the very men who make their society possible. No, they must not be allowed to continue, not while spitting in our direction.”

A voice from the horde answers the Warlord, softer in volume. The Warlord seems to be the only one with magic aiding his speech. “Then why have we been sitting here? We should have marched months ago!”

The Great Warlord answers with far more understanding than you expected. “It was not the right moment to strike. The spirit being was building his strength within me. Striking without his aid would be folly.”

“And now is?”

“Yes. The signs are before us! The spirit being speaks to me in my dreams. His power is made manifest through me, and subsequently, you. And who should share in our glory? My long lost high priest has returned, a holy man who is instrumental in our cause.”

A man steps next to the Great Warlord. Even at this distance, details barely visible, there’s not mistaking his identity. Joren. The Warlord motions, again, to Joren. “Step forward, priest. Your return is a sign from the spirit being. Victory will be ours. At long last, we march on Helswith and the privileged Ursa. Your travels have taken you through the desert, priest. Do you have any insight to share with us?”

As Joren prepares to speak, suddenly a man rushes onto the stage behind the Warlord. He whispers something in the Warlord’s ear, the urgency of the moment causing him to rest a hand on the Warlord’s shoulder, something that you’re sure would be punished with a quick severing in any other circumstance.

The Great Warlord turns back to the horde. “Seems we won’t have to march far. Ursa and his pretend soldiers are on their way here. Prepare yourselves, burn an offering to the spirit being. War is upon us! Their chariots mean nothing in the rocky plains. The foolish ‘High Lord’ is giving away his advantage -- a direct cause of our patience and obedience to the spirit being. Gather yourselves, men. Tomorrow, we feast on Helswith blood and bone.”

If the horde wasn’t a frenzied, chaotic mess, it certainly is now. Each tribe scrambles to reunite with their own, getting in the way of others. Small fights, nothing major, break out, causing a few drops of blood, but nothing too serious. You see only one path to take. Shadow the Warlord. Joren at his side, Uralan’s return tied with him, all of your enemies have grouped together nicely for you. How very kind of them. You will be sure to reward them for their efforts.

The horde, a chaotic mess, you keep your eyes on the Warlord as he’s ushered from the staging platform. Thousands upon thousands of tribesmen lie between you and him. The task, the duty the Lady herself gave you spurs you into action. Everything is so close to completion. Motioning to Paxson, who quickly understands your meaning, you attempt to push your way past the rushing tribesmen to get closer to Joren and the Warlord.

From the stage area, your prey is surrounded by a wall of soldiers, elites by the look of them -- every prominent leader has their own. Within the safety of their white and black shields, your targets move east along the war camp, members of the horde doing their best to get out of the way.

Like cavalry charging through a line of infantrymen, the elite cluster moves through the horde with ease. You and Paxson on the other hand, do your best to swim upstream. Each body, each barbarian that you “politely” move out of the way are replaced by several others. The camp is in uproar. Rushing bodies, men shouting, the stench of war is in the air. Off in the distance, you eye their destination. How could it be elsewhere?

Instead of a tower, gazing over the army, providing a vantage and symbol over their troops, the Warlord’s destination appears to be dug directly into the earth, tomb-like, a labyrinth for the dead. A small set of stone steps lead into an equally simple structure, one that protrudes from the ground like a shark fin in the water. The entryway is an open black space. Several more white and black elite soldiers stand guard outside, waving their arms to allow the Warlord through and underground.

“How do you suppose we’ll follow them in there?” Paxson whispers, wondering aloud.

“The direct approach?” you answer, rhetorically.

Shaking his head, but not disagreeing, Paxson answers. “Gods. I wish I never said that.”

“Hasn’t failed you…or me yet,” you reply. “Stay close. The time for subterfuge is nearing an end.”

You approach the structure. The Warlord and Joren inside, most of the ushering elite soldiers remain outside. A small burn, more surprising than painful, ignites at your inner arm. Your tattoo, the mark of the Lady, glows softly not unlike it did on the night of Tristrand’s navy arriving. The Lady is with you, invigorating, guiding your steps. You cannot fail now.

The guards outside, numbering almost twenty, feel the Lady’s vengeance. You make them feel it.

Power surges through your sword arm, cutting through the guards’ defenses easily and efficiently. Their parries, blocks, and attempts to dodge are sluggish, like a great deal of wine was consumed beforehand. Openings, once never found, appear to you. You must be made to see.

Paxson, next to you, does his best to engage with the elites. His skills were unmatched in the arena as well as the western front. However, these soldiers are on another level. Two keep him engaged, causing him to react more defensively than normal. Still, that’s two less than fighting them alone. After making quick work of the nearest soldier, your sword slashing the back of his leg then meeting his neck, you move to flank those engaged with Paxson. Another two quick slashes and they drop, never noticing your approach. Death follows you, child.

Empty, inviting, the entrance stands before you. A square of black housed by stone. You silently pray death will continue to follow.

“Hold a moment,” you say. “This is it. After we enter, either us or the Warlord will walk out. There’s no telling how many soldiers or what exactly lies within that will greet us.”

“I’ve faced the dangers of underground fighting pits before. This is hardly any different,” Paxson answers.

“This is entirely different. You’ve no chains at your wrist. No whip at your back. And yet you willingly throw yourself back into them.”

“I wouldn’t say ‘willingly,’” Paxson says, pulling a well-crafted dagger from one of the fallen bodies around you. “But also not reluctantly.”

“Go on. Make it quick, though,” you reply, doing a quick sweep with your eyes to ensure no one’s noticed you. The other tribesmen seem too concerned with their rush.

“True, I’m not being forced against my will. I had every right to travel back across the plains to the Helswith camp and report Tristrand’s arrival. As much scrutiny as would be upon me, a slave being the lone survivor, High Lord Ursa isn’t known for being unfair. After a few days locked up, he’d likely send me back to my master as ‘reward.’”

“Speaking of which,” you begin. “Freedom is within your grasp. You could escape, southwest of the plains, into Orem’s land. He’s no ally of the Helswith.”

“No, but he will honor a writ from the Helswith. Master Arroden knows that is my homeland. It’s the first place he’d send bounty hunters to. And, there’s a small matter of my wife. Your father is on the verge of locating and sending for her.”

Damn your father. It’s a story you’ve heard many times. Often, slaves have families before arriving at your father’s school. It’s been somewhat of a reused tactic by Arroden; he was using it when you were there. As far as you know, a reunion has never taken place. Seems it’s still in place. No, now’s not the time to disclose such information. Knowledge of illusionary bonds can be distracting before battle. You pray that your delayed honesty will be taken in good faith.

“After we end the Warlord’s life, I vow to aid your search. Personally. We’ll find her, Paxson.”

“You’re a good man, Nameless.”

The words in the current context stings, especially after your confrontation the night of Tristrand’s navy arriving. That night, you witnessed yourself change into someone you’ve tried your entire life to avoid. Hopefully, here, ending the Warlord’s life and reuniting Paxson with his wife will right that wrong.

You enter the blackness. Stepping through the opening is like the shades of a window being closed suddenly; the light from outside instantly vanishes, causing your eyes to blink repeatedly in order to adjust. There’s a small staging area initially in the structure. No guards are here, as they would have heard your skirmish outside and joined in to protect the entrance. A staircase leads down further underground, back and forth like switchbacks on a mountain trail. Along the way, soft light is posted, torches placed strategically on the walls for vision, like small fireflies on a moonless night.

“Take care to pace yourself,” Paxson whispers. “Don’t need to exhaust our legs on the way down.”

“Agreed,” you whisper back.

The two of you start the climb down, finding a good speed that finds the balance between speed and exertion. The journey doesn’t take too long. Not ten minutes later you find yourselves nearing the bottom. The final section of the staircase leads into a large cavernous room, which looks to be formed naturally. However, the Great Warlord must have built directly into the natural rock.

Rocky, dusty ground has been replaced with smooth white stone blocks, the walls and ceiling mirroring. There’s still enough of the cavern to tell its original shape, but it looks like the inside of a cathedral placed underground. Varying sections of the sanctuary have jagged rock poking through the white stone, like icicles built from pure rock, giving the otherwise holy place of worship a dark feel to it, sinister, unseen dangers of the void peering through the veil. Across the sanctuary, framed by two large statues of past warriors holding battleaxes, the Warlord sits casually on the floor, back facing you, an elite soldier on either side.

Above him, strung into the air like a fly caught in a web, is Joren suspended between the two statues, rope binding each of his four limbs stretching them out in a starlike shape. The Warlord sets a golden cup down on the floor, echoing throughout the chamber, and you realize noise travels exceptionally far in the stone enclosure. You take great care to move silently, still pressing forward to reach your target, while also listening to hear the words spoken from his mouth.

“Now what am I to do with the likes of you,” the Warlord wonders aloud. “A treacherous high priest is no small matter. You will be made an example of, of course.”

As you draw closer, using jagged sections of natural rock for cover, you notice a wound at the Warlord’s side. Looks to be made from a small dagger if you had to guess. Joren turned on his leader? The man seems to have a pattern of attacking those closest to him. Finally, he’s been caught in the act.

“My travels have shown me that tyranny cannot stand. Freedom is each man’s right. I’ve been bound, traded as a slave, but I finally recognize you for what you are: a tyrant using our own religion and tradition for your gain. At least my slave masters had the common decency to tell me what I was, not feigning free will and twisting our religion for their gain.”

After speaking, Joren attempts to call on his holy fire, blue flame, the wake of destruction you followed several territories. Nothing.

“Ha, you think I would string you up with normal rope? You give me far too less credit, priest. The spirit being’s power is almost within my grasp. Perhaps a sacrifice will grant additional favor and manifest his power in me completely. I’m sure it will, considering your betrayal to that whore, the false god who delayed his return so many years ago.”

Does he mean the Lady? Is Joren following her ways? No, he killed Killian and burned the temple on the island. There’s no way he’s on the same path as you. Still, the Warlord’s words bring you to pause a moment. So Uralan isn’t fully manifested in the Warlord yet. Good. You need to end things before it is. You’re close to the Warlord now, so close that a minor scuffle on the ground would alert him of your presence. You motion to Paxson, telling him to stay put. The direct approach has gotten you this far; your training on the island would have to carry you the rest of the way.

Silently, sneaking in a crouched position, you do as Morgan taught you so long ago on the island, limiting the surface area of your feet on the ground, light in your step, using the strength of your legs to absorb the impact of your steps. You breathe a sigh of relief, figuratively as not to alert the Warlord, that you didn’t rush down the long staircase to get here. Blade drawn already, you move forward. Amateurs don’t draw until the last moment. That’s why they’ll forever be known as such. Draw your blade early. Even the smoothest of sheathes give a slight sound when pulling weapon from a resting position.

Up close, the Warlord is a brute of a man, far from the eloquent speaker you heard speaking to the horde. Well, perhaps, he’s both, but the ruggedized man before you looks anything but eloquent. His head is bald, highlighting a bull-like neck, thick and muscular. He doesn’t appear to be wearing armor. A black cloak hangs from his shoulders, and a chiseled arm extends from beneath it. The Warlord still sits, one knee in the air, leaning on an arm while the other holds a golden cup. His two guards are stoic, silent, ever watchful.

A few more steps now. Blade raised. Neck exposed. Your path takes you from cover. Joren, noticing, the only one facing you, does his best to hide his surprise. Still, though, it shines through. Something’s off. The Warlord senses it. He turns just as you plunge your blade directly into his neck. Surprise, then anger flashes on his face, one that’s hairless save for a thin moustache.The world starts to spin, fading in and out of existence. Like heavy eyelids before a night of sleep, your vision slowly turns to black.

The Lady stands in front of you dressed in her simple ceremonial robes, hair floating weightlessly just above her shoulders. Her eyes, two black orbs, stare directly ahead past you. You turn, finally noticing your surroundings, the Lady taking the bulk of your attention until now. You’re back in the chamber, one that holds a small stone altar, flowers at its base. It’s the place you first met the Lady, the place where she first bestowed her mark upon you.

The coffin that you’re used to seeing is gone. Instead, the Great Warlord lays on the altar. Blood pours from his two wounds, one at his side and another in his neck. Strength rapidly lost from his limbs, he’s at the Lady’s mercy, something that she’s not known for. Mercy doesn’t come easy for the spirit of vengeance.

Four flames, candles lit on each of the altar’s corners rise in luminosity as the Lady floats closer. Her bare feet travel mere inches above the steps leading to the Warlord. Next to her, you float, watching the scene unfold before you. As she draws closer, the candles burst with light, like a forest fire spreading in the night. Flames dancing, your eyes travel to the Warlord’s shadow.

Unlike its human origin, the Great Warlord’s shadow is not reflective of humanity. A beast, clawed, with a snout-like nose appears in black behind the Warlord’s body. Two sharp tusks extend from its mouth, a great and terrible beast: the form of Uralan. The shadow rises high, reaching far higher and lengthier than the Warlord, like the long shadow cast from the setting sun. Trapped, laid on the Lady’s altar, Uralan’s shadow howls. Piercing noise emanates from the Warlord’s mouth, primal, enraged, otherworldly. The Lady doesn’t react. A blank expression coupled with firm eyes watch the man in front of her. It’s the look of vengeance, a dutiful approach to the word.

Your return will not happen this day, fiend, she speaks. My herald has stopped you. Face it, you’ve been beaten again.

The Great Warlord’s body thrashes on the altar, seizing like a man possessed.

ALL THIS HAS HAPPENED--

And will happen again, the Lady finishes.

YOU HAVE NOT BEATEN ME, MERELY DELAYED MY PLANS. YOU ARE NOTHING. A FALSE GOD. AN OUTSIDER WELCOMED IN BY MY WEAK BROTHER. A WHORE THAT HE WANTS TO FUCK. HE’LL TOSS YOU ASIDE ONCE HE’S DONE WITH YOU, LIKE HE DID TO ME.

You betrayed the Eternal Father, not the other way around. Your attempts to overthrow him have brought chaos in the mortal realm. I was once one of them, transformed with the Eternal Father’s power. You do not know the strength that lies within them, the steadfast willpower mankind is capable of. True, they are destroyed easily; their bodies naturally decay on their own. But still, they resist you. Still, they will not be pushed aside. Their lives may be scarred with tragedy, but still they press on, undeterred of the future and their likely demise. The Eternal Father knows this. We can learn from them. Their doomed nature brings promise and hope. Ours, on the other hand, is a perpetual state of existence, blank, meaningless, unchanging.

THIS CHANGES NOTHING. EVEN NOW, MY FOLLOWERS ATTEMPT TO BRING ME BACK. MY POWER WILL MEET HUMANITY, DARKENING THEIR BLOOD, BESTOWING MY POWER UPON THEM. A NEW BLOODLINE WILL BE ESTABLISHED. MY CHILDREN WILL RULE ALL NATIONS. A DYNASTY WILL RISE, AN EMPIRE GUIDED BY MY POWER. THEIR RULE WILL BE ABSOLUTE, THEIR LINEAGE, UNBROKEN.

Enough. I tire of your empty threats. Herald, step forward.

You do as the Lady commands.

End it.

Your blade pierces the Great Warlord’s heart. The shadow of the beast cast from the Warlord’s body, disappears for a moment, then surges into the air, fading from view, extinguishing the candles along with it. Smoke in the air, warmth overcomes your body. The Lady’s hand turns your head to face towards her. She remains silent, your gaze falling over her flawless features. A nose perfectly shaped, skin unblemished, sparking eyes black as onyx, womanly curves filling the edges of her ceremonial dress. Her face draws closer, hands cupping your jawline. Her eyes shut, lips meeting yours. Similarly to Uralan’s shadow, the Lady fades into nonexistence, her touch a small spark still upon your skin. She’s gone.

Bodies surround you as you wake. Joren’s lies in the air, still suspended with rope in the middle of two ancient statues, ones that disallow his holy power to shine forth. His throat is slashed, a red line across is skin in which a waterfall of blood pours down. The sanctuary, with its acoustics, echoes softly each time a drop pours from Joren’s body to the white stone floor, a pool forming beneath him.

Closer, the Great Warlord’s body is absent of life, his two elite guards the same. Their deaths, however, show more signs of struggle. Several wounds line their limbs, blood from several areas spilled on the ground, scattered, unlike the neat pools displayed by Joren and the Warlord. Paxson sits in between both, nursing his own damage, although his doesn’t appear to be fatal. Paxson, always victorious with scars to prove it.

You rush over to him, consciousness back in your body, to examine the damage sustained. As you draw closer, his wounds look much more serious than at first glance, partially because he’s hidden them underneath his wooden shield. It’s bad. A deep gouge lines his side, the contents of his torso barely visible through the opening.

“Can’t you learn to use that buckler of yours?” you ask, trying to lighten the moment.

“You know I can only take the direct approach,” he answers, wincing at the pain. A wince, most men in that position would be revealing much more. “Did you mean it?” he adds on.

“Mean what?”

“That you’d help me find my wife after...after this.”

“Of course I meant it.”

“She no longer lives.” The voice appears from above you. Morgan, dropping down from an overhanging section of rock, lands next to you. She holds a dagger in her hand, still wet with blood. Joren’s, if you had to guess.

“Morgan! (Liliana!)” both you and Paxson speak simultaneously, then quickly eye one another at using a different name, surprised at each other’s recognition.

“Morgan,” she answers, confident as always. Stern, like a schoolmaster addressing students. “Liliana is no more. Her death is the reason why I breathe.”

“I don’t understand…” Paxson begins, before entering a fit of coughing. He spits a large amount of blood from his mouth to the white floor, far too much for your liking. His eyes turn glassy, like they are unable to focus on a single target, blurry, fading.

“Liliana was weak. Liliana was vulnerable. Liliana got taken advantage of,” Morgan says, striding up to Paxson’s body. She eyes his wounds, knowing full-well it’s only a matter of time. “She could no longer be allowed to live. Her sacrifice means my survival.” Morgan gently grabs behind Paxson’s head, forcing his focus to be on her, something that he’s lost the ability to do himself. “She loved you until the very end. Even now, from behind the veil, she loves you, despite the choices of her stupid husband.”

Paxson opens his mouth to speak, but no words come out. His vision, distant. Slowly, you see the strength exit his body. The power he possessed, gone. A man unhindered by wounds, setbacks, obstacles has finally met one he can’t overcome. His grit, the drive that kept him going for so long. His honor, brings him to this moment. A man marked by, bound by his word tighter than any shackles, breathes his last breath. A man not soon forgotten. Morgan kisses his forehead and rests his head against the stone floor, shutting Paxson’s eyelids.

“So, you and him…” you trail off, realizing this is not the time or place for such discussion.

“Once upon a time,” is Morgan’s reply.

You join Morgan next to Paxson, crouching next to her. He looks at rest, his reunion complete. Your arm wraps around Morgan’s shoulders, pulling her closer to you. Despite her typical emotionless, blank demeanor, you notice a single tear fall down her cheek. Liliana may not be as dead as she previously stated. Paxson, far too honorable for your father’s house, lies dead, his time spent in servitude believing the lies of your father, Arroden Scholhart. The wrong man lies dead. It’s time to return home, Morgan bound to join you. The spirit of vengeance lives on.


The End

Now is your chance. The Great Warlord is exposed. You’ll likely not have a chance like this again. The Lady said she’d be there when you need her, perhaps she orchestrated things behind the scene to set up the Warlord’s vulnerability. One thing’s for certain, you’re not going to let this opportunity slip through your fingers. Paxson following, you start to make your way to the front of the assembly, getting a few angry looks from several tribesmen along the way.

Along the way, the Warlord’s voice rings out over the crowd, somehow projecting a great distance. Magically enhanced. It’s not what you were expecting from the man. You expected it to be more...rough, animalistic, but it’s smooth, the words spoken with an eloquence that rivals a master orator.

“...the people of Helswith have lived high and mighty for too long. Comfort has crept into their veins, poisoning the host. They rest on fine silk and speak poorly of the laborman, the very men who make their society possible. No, they must not be allowed to continue, not while spitting in our direction.”

You draw closer. Still, a fair distance away. Barely audible, especially compared to the Warlord’s voice, another rings out. Seems their assembly is a two-way road. Progressive, for savages.

“Then why have we been sitting here? We should have marched months ago!”

“It was not the right moment to strike. The spirit being was building his strength within me. Striking without his aid would be folly,” the Great Warlord answers.

“But now it is?”

The Warlord smiles, a curved thing like the edge of a scimitar. “Yes.”

Closer and closer you get, meeting more barbarians who don’t take kindly to you pushing past them. A few even give you a shove, which only angers others since it takes you into the back of another barbarian. It takes a little while, and by the time you get a clear view of the Great Warlord, you can tell the assembly is almost concluded.

Unlike the men at his command, the Warlord is clean-shaven minus a thin black mustache that looks as if it was the result of a thin paintbrush. His head is bald, highlighting bull-like thick neck muscles. Surprisingly, he doesn't wear armor. Instead, he wears normal trousers, far too normal for his position, and a sleeveless vest, stitched with red, revealing arms that Helswithian sculptors could only imagine. He’s also paler than you imagined. The western barbarians are typically darker skinned, since they spend most of their time outdoors.The Warlord looks as if he’s spent most of his time indoors.

“The signs are before us! The spirit being speaks to me in my dreams. His power is made manifest through me, and subsequently, you. And who should share in our glory? My long lost high priest has returned, a holy man who is instrumental in our cause.”

You’re almost within striking distance. Below the stage, a line of more equipped barbarians stand guard, shields and spears at the ready, their colors black and white. Unlike their fellow tribesmen, these don chain and steel helms. Every leader has an elite guard, and these must be the Warlord’s.The Great Warlord motions behind him, and a man steps up next to him. You recognize him instantly. Curly brown hair, hazel eyes. Joren.

He’s here. Finally within your grasp. The man that you’ve chased over several nations stands before you, unaware of your presence. You feel a small pang of regret that Morgan isn’t here to share in your vengeance, in her vengeance, but it must be done. Joren first, then the Warlord.

A hand rests on your shoulders. Paxson’s. “I have a bad feeling about this,” he whispers. “Whatever you’re about to do, this is a one-way journey. I hope you know that.”

“We’ll see about that,” you whisper back. The black and white shields lie before you, a cliffside meant to stave off the most powerful of waves. Behind them, two men to kill. The eyes of the elite guard scan the horde, searching for signs of danger, seeking disruptive behavior. You take off in a dead sprint directly toward them.

The sudden movement draws all attention to you, the few assembly members in front of you part, retracting like the receding of a wave. You murmur a soft prayer to the Lady, pumping your arms and legs, propelling yourself forward at full-speed. Despite being surrounded by a hundred thousand men, all seems quiet. The only sounds registering in your mind is your breath and footsteps. A wall of shields raise against your charge. You leap.

Flight. Wind rushes past you like howling gales. The hairs on your arm rise, partly because of fear, partly because of adrenaline. You acknowledge both within a thought and press onward. Your flight is only a matter of seconds, maybe less, but it feels as if an eternity. The world slows down around you, allowing you to see. You must be made to see.

The eyes of the elite guard are steadfast, confident with their shield wall. As your leap takes you higher, they shift. Realization falls across them, surprise at your flight path. The whites of their eyes, behind steel helms, follow your body upward, momentarily frozen.
