Before they can recover, your foot lands on one of the shields, propelling yourself higher, sending you directly onto the stage in front of your victim. Joren.

“Hello, old friend. Been awhile,” you say, throwing your dagger at Joren. Whirling, it flashes through the air towards the exposed neck of your prey. It lands within Joren’s neck with a soft thud. A small gurgle escapes his lips simultaneously. Behind you, Paxson engages the Warlord’s guards, a single man surrounded by well-armed and well-trained soldiers. In an instant, you know how it will end. It would likely have the same outcome even with Pralthar’s greatbow at his support. You feel a pang of guilt, but do your best attempts to suppress it. There’ll be time for that later.

The thick neck muscles of the Warlord bulge, his body posturing for combat. His eyes draw down to your arm, where the tattoo of the crow lies. “You!” he speaks. He charges forward, a mad bull stampeding. At the last moment, when he’s almost upon you, your feet shift drawing you away from his charge. Surprisingly quick, too quick for a man of that size, he adjusts, slamming his massive shoulder into your gut. It’s like being hit with a solid rowing oar. The impact shoves you back, taking a flight path in the air opposite of the one you just took. Your body collapses near the edge of the stage, almost falling over completely.

Crumpled, dazed, you eye the approaching Warlord, his heavy boots resounding on the wooden stage with each step, like thunder within a storm cloud. In the circle of soldiers, Paxson’s success is on par with yours. Several cuts line his arms and legs. Blood pours down one side of his face from an unseen wound, only worsening his vision for what’s to come. Still, he holds a defensive posture, unwilling to accept defeat while he possesses strength. Like you, he knows what the outcome will be. The longer he distracts the soldiers, the greater your own chance of ending the Great Warlord.

Your hand grips tighter around your sword. You’re not done yet. You spin to the left, avoiding the Warlord and arc your blade downward. The edge strikes the side of the Warlord’s leg, pausing him for a moment, but then he closely follows your movement, meaning to catch you before you can rise to standing.

You must be made to see. Rather than meeting his advance with sword, you extend a palm forward drawing upon the Lady’s power. A familiar tingle is felt through your fingers, transitioning up your arm. Your vision starts to darken, like a pair of heavy eyelids before sleep. Twisting, whirling, the world around you suddenly fades from view.

Lightless you float, becoming more used to flying in the air during your time spent in visions. Stone blocks line the floor, walls, and ceiling. It looks as if the same stone from your initial meeting with the Lady, the place where the coffin lies. Warmth falls over you, like waking up with the morning sun across your face. She’s here.

You will yourself forward, traveling down the torch-lined hallway. You pass each torch, an orange streak of light, growing quicker and quicker. Soon, the light of each torch molds into one, a single beam of warmth on either side of you. Wind greets your face and your stomach turns as if falling from a great height. Perhaps you were overconfident in your abilities in this realm, wherever “this” is. Then, like running into a thick brush, you’re stopped, trapped, suspended into the air. The torchlight around you extinguishes as one, sending wisps of smoke in the air with the final breath of light.

Through the darkness, a green glow appears, a pale face emerges. The woman flocked by crows. The vengeful spirit. She approaches her herald. Her youthful face is unmarked, flawless. In contrast with you, it makes her even more beautiful, a broken man in the presence of a goddess.

“You promised to appear when I need you most,” you say, filling the hallway with your voice.

Yes.

“And here you are. I desperately need you now.”

I know.

“He’s strong. Stronger than I imagined.”

Uralan is slowly feeding him. He cannot pour himself into the man completely, otherwise the vessel would be destroyed. However, he’s close. Very close.

“Can you do the same for me? Pour your strength into me?”

The Lady turns away from you, head seemingly buried in thought, tilted slightly.

I am not like Uralan. He was born of this realm. I was brought into it. He can siphon off strength to others. For me, that would be crippling. The power that keeps me in this realm would dissolve with the transition. I would be cut from the other deities.

“Then my actions have doomed us,” you answer softly. “I should have waited, not charged the man in front of his entire army.” Your body floats down to the stone floor. Somehow, you’re able to command yourself to stand normally, feeling the solid ground beneath you. The Lady follows.

You continue, bowing your head. “I ruined our chance. Paxson will die because of me -- the Reapers already have. Morgan is lost. At least the vengeance of your destroyed temple is complete. I set off from the island to end Joren’s life. That was accomplished. I’m sorry that I could not complete the rest.”

Her feet land on the floor next to yours, the first time you’ve seen her have any physical contact. Even her own hair seems to float just above her shoulders, never touching completely. Now, however, it falls heavy. Her hand touches your chin, drawing your gaze to meet hers. The Lady’s eyes are black, yet inviting. Somehow, comforting despite possessing endless darkness.

I chose you because I knew you could make it this far. Your strength lies not in your physical body, but in your willpower. You have made it this far. Allow me to carry you to the end.

You fully understand the meaning behind her words. Her strength, though able to pour into your body, would remove her from her place next to the Eternal Father. She would no longer live with the gods. Her sacrifice would end her life. All because of you.

“No, don’t do this,” you utter.

What’s done is done, she answers, drawing closer. Her face comes mere inches from yours, examining, contemplating. Her lips rise to meet yours, passing through as if an empty cloud. Then, she’s gone. You’re alone. Still, with your feet firmly planted on the ground, you stride forward, not sure what else to do. Usually, the visions are ended for you. This time, it’s sustained. Your journey takes you to a single doorway. As you approach, the door swings open inviting you inside.

You’re met with a familiar room. Simple stone steps leading to an altar. A coffin lies on top. In each of the four corners of the altar, candles are lit, shining their warm light on a row of colorful flowers placed near the coffin. Once more, you approach the coffin. Its lid, formerly firmly in place, rests on the floor next to the altar, allowing you to view the body inside.

The Lady rests inside, flawless features absent of life. Her dark eyes lie closed, forever. Two small hands cross at her waist, resting softly on her simple ceremonial robes. The Lady, the one flocked by crows, lies dead because of your choices. Her loyalty to her herald has brought her the ultimate end. Your head lands on her chest, sorrow taking over. Tears start to flow down your face. She remains quiet.

A curved blade swipes towards your neck. Clarity fills your vision, allowing you to focus on tiny details, rather than needing your mind to fill those in. The edge travels towards you. Your own blade rises to meet it, deflecting the attack off course. Strength pours into your limbs like you’ve never felt before. The sudden rush is like splashing fresh water onto your face after a hard day at work, refreshing, invigorating. The Warlord notices it.

“No… this cannot be. Not now. Not after all I’ve done,” the Warlord utters. Then his face darkens. “She's here. A mistake on her end.”

Heavy boots stomping on the stage platform, he commits to a series of aggressive strikes, long powerful swings and slices, not the disciplined quick thrusting of a Helswith soldier. Sheer brutality and ferocity are his allies, and they’ve seemed to carry him this far. Speed, strength, perception, yours are enhanced beyond human limitations. With the Lady’s power, it’s like a seasoned soldier play-fighting with a child.

Behind you, Paxson lets out a shout. You turn just as a tribesman pulls a spear back from his thrust, one that caught Paxson cleanly through the shoulder. Blood. More blood splashes onto the ground, most of which is Paxson’s. Glancing back, you know what you must do. The Lady sacrificed herself for you. Many have died because of you. Death follows you, child. Her words echo in your mind. You will not allow Paxson’s name to be added to the list.

You will yourself forward, in the same way as your visions. In an instant, your body transforms into a flock of crows, squawking, flapping their wings at deafening levels, each with eyes black as the Lady’s. Not a second later, you arrive at Paxon’s side, turning back into your body. Paxson’s gaze meets yours, hand still clutching his fresh shoulder wound, one of many that line his body. Not a word is shared. Like you’ve done many times before, you engage the tribesmen together.

You move as a blur, avoiding each axe, spear, and sword, finding openings with each swing of your sword. Part of you wonders how long you can sustain such movement. So far, you haven’t shown any signs of slowing down, so you push the thought from your mind. Every barbarian you fell is replaced by another, sometimes two others. Paxson holds his own, using a defensive posture, simply aiming to survive and distract as long as possible, while you take the offensive. You need to move. And fast, looking at Paxson’s accumulated wounds.

“Surround the assassins! I want them alive!” the Great Warlord’s voice rings out over the horde.

While already surrounded, the tribesmen cluster closer together. Instead of solely attacking from all angles, they become a tight-knit force, meaning to enclose you from all sides. They draw closer and closer, prodding, poking, jabbing with their weapons. Paxson, delirious from blood loss, stumbles, his vision blurring, instincts taking over conscious actions.

“They will make a worthy sacrifice to the spirit being. The spirit will bless our attack -- urghh!”

The Great Warlord’s words are cut short. The point of a sword sticks out from the front of his thick neck, flashing in the sunlight. His mouth freezes open in surprise, a trail of blood leaking from within.

All stands still for a moment.

The surrounding tribesmen stop their assault, hundreds of thousands of eyes fixated on one point. With a thunderous crash, the Great Warlord falls dead, face-first, on the stage. A small woman stands in his place, originally covered from view by the Warlord’s massive frame. Unnaturally black hair, emerald eyes. Morgan. Her head motions to one side, signaling to run. You don’t need to be told twice.

Paxson, losing strength, can hardly stand. You scoop him up over one shoulder and will yourself to the stage, to Morgan. Black wings flap in the air, taking you to your desired location. Emerald eyes greet you upon arrival. Your other hand, the one not holding Paxson in place, wraps around Morgan’s waist, pulling her close. You will yourself forward.

You travel far. A flock of crows fly over the western plains. Your vision is a blur of passing grassy hills, occasionally passing by jagged trees, void of leaves or life. Inside the flock, you’re able to see perfectly through the crows, although you’re sure no one on the outside can look within. Your journey takes you all the way to the coastline, relatively near where the Reapers made their camp, though miles away in case more of Tristrand’s ships arrive.

Eventually, you land on the bluffs overlooking the sea. Three sets of feet stand on the ground, one pair badly bloodied. Morgan eyes Paxson, taking far more of an interest than you would have expected, especially after revealing your newly found ability. His body, drained of energy, lies prone on the ground, resting in recovery, his heavy breath indicating sleep. You’ve bandaged his wounds best you can, and are confident in time he will heal back to full. There isn’t a more durable man you know.

Morgan doesn’t speak at first. Perhaps for the first time, around you at least, lost for words. It’s oddly silent, save for waves crashing against the shore. A soft breeze blows in the air, causing her to tuck her loose strands of black hair behind an ear.

“She chose you,” Morgan finally breaks the silence.

You nod.

“I thought she would choose me.”

“I thought she would too,” you answer. “How did you find me?”

Morgan sighs. “In all honesty, I was after Joren. But you beat me to it. You seemed to be making quite a mess of things, so I had to clean up like always.”

Despite her light-hearted comment, you answer solemnly. “She’s dead. The Lady sacrificed herself for me. She foretold her own death. She would still be alive if not for my actions. She should have chosen you.”

Absent of emotion, a blank expression falls over Morgan’s face, like a mask hiding the true feelings underneath. It’s a look you’ve seen many times at the island, one that is accompanied with lesson teaching.

“I’ll not have you disrespect her like that. The Lady made her decision, and questioning that decision is questioning her judgement. I’ll not allow such blasphemy, especially from you. She lives on through her herald, just as the ancient texts speak. I’ve...we’ve trusted her this far, and have we been given a reason against that? No. Things rarely play out as we imagine. Just ask my former husband there. You and I have plenty of work to do. First starting with building a new temple and reestablishing the order. You will lead us, Herald. May the Lady’s vengeance continue through you.”

Morgan finishes by dropping to one knee, bowing her head before you. Well, that’s strange. The woman who you’ve known only to discipline and reprimand you -- wait, did she just say husband?

Paxson continues to breathe deeply, eyes shut. Peacefully dreaming of other times. His face is caked with dried blood. Smaller wounds not large enough to need wrapping, have since stopped bleeding, showing early signs of scabbing. The man who stayed loyal by your side, despite your father’s ownership, despite countless wounds and blows on the battlefield, rests softly. His past, deeply aligned with your own. If you and Morgan are to reestablish the order, you can think of no better member to include. Besides, a little refinement around the edges would be good for him, although you imagine he’ll still prefer the direct approach.

“Stop that,” you say, pulling Morgan up by her arm. Her words resonate with you. She’s right. Both she and Paxson have demonstrated that you can’t wallow in the past, fixating on past mistakes. You share a burden, a responsibility to continue the Lady’s work. Your mind draws back to her words. All this has happened and will happen again. Victory is yours for the time being, but it will not always be so. You need to prepare for the future. You can start with building a temple and training new members.

“There is a place,” you speak. “deep in the Mountains of the Nameless, hidden from most travelers. The sun rises each morning between twin peaks, shining its light down evergreen-filled mountainside. There sits a rocky slope, a jettison in the mountain as if the top was cut cleanly off. I spent time there after escaping my father’s house. No one’s settled there. It is a perfect place to rebuild.”

“As you wish, Herald,” Morgan answers with a smile.

Next to you, Paxson rests silently. His chest rises and falls with each breath. Finally, he looks at peace. Finally, he’s free. The coastline wind blows, sending nearby dry grass leaning eastward. Sunlight, shining from the ocean, sparkles brightly with the ocean’s movement. You take in the moment, knowing that soon you’ll be back in the comforting caress of the mountains, back home. Strange how the arc of one’s life can come full circle. All this has happened and will happen again. Asleep, Paxson dreams of better times. A life of violence, separation, pain, the only solace comes during sleep, during dreams of her. Past glories mean nothing. Future glories are simply stepping stones on his journey back to her embrace. When he wakes, he’ll find her.

The End

He’s on top of you as soon as you finish the roll. Armed now with a curved blade, he brings it down in a powerful overhead swing, sending splinters flying from the stage as it narrowly misses. You bring your own sword to counter. It meets the Warlord’s cloak, bouncing off harmlessly, not making a mark. It has the same effect as a small dagger trying to slash through plate. On his next assault, you attempt to kick out his legs from under him. The Warlord hardly notices, absorbing the blow, and returning his own, which sends you sprawling across the stage again.

“This is the strength of her herald?” the Great Warlord comments, drawing closer to your fallen body.

You try to cut his injured leg, but he easily avoids the attempt, slapping your sword from your hand. You try to hold on to the blade, but it feels as if it was torn from your hands, like the rigging in stormy sea water.

A man cries out behind you, followed closely by laughter. Paxson. You turn to see his prone body, pierced with several spear wounds. He moves, barely. Not for long, though. Not until the tribesmen have their fun. The Warlord’s fist smashes into your nose, bouncing the back of your head on the stage. The heel of his boot stomps on your knee with a sickening crack, like a tree branch being snapped into two pieces. Pain. Searing pain shoots up your leg distracting you from your surroundings. There’s only one focus on your mind. Pain. Searing pain.

“Can’t have you escaping now, can we?” he speaks again. “You’ve made it this far, only to fail now. I suppose that’s expected considering the Eternal Father tasked that whore to stop me.”

The insult towards the Lady distracts you from the pain, briefly. You try another desperate attack, but get shut down instantly. The Warlord’s boot meets your already broken nose, crushing it further. Your face a bloodied mess, you speak. “The Lady will have her vengeance. She’s stopped you before, and she’ll stop you again.”

“Face it, Herald. You’re beaten. Your death will serve no purpose other than to further the spirit being’s return. His power made manifest through me. In killing the whore’s herald, I will severe her ties to this world. Face it, Herald. You’ve lost.”

The Great Warlord lifts his curved blade up, ready to end your life in a single strike. Here, it all ends. You’ve made it far, falling short near the finish line. In an instant, you find yourself full of sorrow, not because your life is ending, but because you’ve failed the Lady. You’ve failed to accomplish her task, one that she placed her faith in you for.

This is it. You close your eyes wanting it to get it over with. A sudden flash. Movement occurs. Sunlight fades for a moment, caused by a shadow passing over you. A woman stands above you, her back turned towards you. She engages the Warlord in a fury of strikes, like a swarm of hornets being disrupted in their hive. She’s quick, too quick for the Warlord. But still, he holds a sizable edge due to sheer strength and size. Her swarm may be frenzied, spurred by vengeance, but she’s ultimately outmatched in a direct confrontation.

Several minor cuts appear on the Warlord’s arms, but they are but a small nuisance. The guards and the horde stand at the ready, willing to come to their leader’s rescue. The Warlord waves them back, preferring to handle the would-be assassins on his own. He creates a spectacle of it, a show for their benefit. This is not a leader standing idly back while others fight. He’ll settle things on his own terms. He’ll get his own hands dirty. He’ll smother the Lady’s vengeance.

A woman falls next to you, blood pouring from her face, just as you. Morgan.

Shackles. Once again, they find themselves around your wrists. Your back is pressed against a large wooden column, hands bound behind and around the pillar. Similar chains are clasped to your ankles, connecting to the base of the pillar like a dog leashed to its master. Thousands upon thousands of faces surround you, cheering, voicing animalistic sounds at your demise. The horde.

It’s late in the day now. The sun is much lower in the sky than it was when confronting the Great Warlord. The strength sapped from your body, you must have laid unconscious for several hours. Morgan! Where is she? You twist your body the best that you can manage to see if she’s near. She’s not. You’re alone, tied to the pillar. However, to your right, you discover Paxson’s remains, a series of five pikes in the mud arranged in a star-like pattern, each impaled with one of his limbs, the fifth being his severed head.

Paxson, an unlikely friend, loyal until the end, unwilling to stand by, idly, while you took a desperate attempt on the Warlord’s life. He knew the outcome and still gave you support, trading his life so that you could have a greater chance at success. And still, you failed.

Bodies begin to part in front of you, creating a pathway for two figures to walk through. Like you, she’s chained, led by the Warlord holding the leash. He pulls on it suddenly, cruelly pulling her forward, stumbling to the ground. Her clothes are tattered, torn in several places exposing the skin beneath, at least not directly where places are meant to be covered. Close, though. Very close. Black hair, unnaturally black, frames her face. Two emerald eyes peer through the curtain, absent of the brightness they once possessed. You recognize the look. Hopelessness.

The Warlord walks her up in front of you, tossing her once again to the ground. Morgan. The two of you have shared so much. It’s oddly fitting that you find yourself here, sharing in the defeat as well. Her eyes meet yours, hands and knees still on the ground. She’s void of the sharpness that once inhabited. The zeal that possessed her is gone, replaced with a sense of nothingness, a shell of her former self. Morgan’s head turns slightly, catching sight of Paxson’s severed body. For a moment, the light is back. Inner fire that burns away all else. As quickly as it appears, it dissipates, doused by the present setting. Was that recognition or simply a reaction to the cruelty?

“I had my men break her in for me,” the Warlord speaks to you. “She’s as passionate as they come. Eventually, though. They all break.”

You attempt, unsuccessfully, to break from your chains. It’s futile, but you have to try.

“I think I’ll keep her around a while. But first, you must be dealt with.”

The Great Warlord motions to nearby tribesmen. They nod at his command, stacking pieces of wood around you and lighting torches. So this is how it all ends. Your life, once from the comfort of a prominent house, to the Mountains of the Nameless, to here, in the horde, is about to end.

The man you tracked across many nations is dead. That much was accomplished. But seeing Morgan in her position, in the vulnerable form you never expected to see her in, is heartbreaking. The man you chased, Joren, left a wake of flame in his path. His life ended, and yours about to be by the very burning tracks he left behind.

Symmetry. The cyclical nature of your journey is not lost on you. Here, at the end, you find yourself where you once began. Shackled, your life in the hands of another. From a family that owned slaves, to becoming one yourself. The woman flocked by crows, stampeded, mistreated, shamed through a barbarian horde, Morgan following in her footsteps. Symmetry. You were born into this world screaming, crying. As they light the fire underneath you, you leave the world in the same way.

The End

The Lady tasked you with ending the Great Warlord, the return of Uralan. Joren may be the reason that brought you this far, but you’ll not abandon the task that is set before you. She chose you as her herald, and you cannot betray her like that...even if it’s in justice’s name for the destruction of her temple. He’s here in front of you. Exposed, thinking he’s safe behind a wall of guards. His life is yours for the taking. You step forward, ready to end it here. Suddenly, a hand rests on your shoulder, stopping you. Paxson’s.

“I have a bad feeling about this,” he whispers. “Whatever you’re about to do, this is a one-way journey. I hope you know that.”

“We’ll see…” you answer, taking a second glance at the situation before you. A wall of black and white shields, a raised platform with two dangerous men, a horde unlike any other around you. Perhaps patience is the best avenue. As the Lady’s herald, you must be willing to listen to others.

The Warlord motions, again, to Joren. “Step forward, priest. Your return is a sign from the spirit being. Victory will be ours. At long last, we march on Helswith and the privileged Ursa. Your travels have taken you through the desert, priest. Do you have any insight to share with us?”

Joren’s hazel eyes scan the horde before him. Most would be fearful in that position, speaking to thousands upon thousands of warriors. Leaders know how to inspire. They put their men’s interest above their own, willing to place themselves in risky situations for the good of the company. Ever confident, like he knows a secret you don’t, Joren takes a deep breath before speaking.

“My travels have resulted in many things learned, Warlord.” Confidence, even at not addressing the Great Warlord’s full title in front of the horde. “There are those in Helswith that slander your name. They mock the tribes’ gathering based on the inability to punch through the Helswith frontier line. Now, as we speak, High Lord Ursa is marching on our very position. He’s taken the offensive. Something that many here would say we should have done.”

The statement, and the obvious slander, brings a displeased look to the Warlord’s face. Murmuring starts among the horde. Joren yells over them.

“I’ve been but a mere slave, chained, beaten, treated as but a wild animal. My bonds have taught me much about the way the world should be.” Joren’s hands blaze alive with holy flame, radiating blue light on his face. “Tyranny is everywhere, enforcing unfair rules, bending others to their will. The only way to live is through freedom. True freedom. A man is his own being. Anyone who says otherwise is a tyrant, a dictator, a WARLORD!”

Both hands suddenly grip the Great Warlord’s face, searing his skin with blue fire. The Warlord screams, frenzied, flailing his arms out meaning to catch Joren with his fists. The horde erupts in chaos. Tribe against tribe, savage against savage. Like a loose thread holding a pile of sticks together, they snap, the loose bond holding them, uniting them, broken. Through the chaos, you see the elite guard marching upon Joren’s position. The bond between their master may be broken, but their honor will continue to be lost unless they can avenge their fallen leader.

Paxson jumps to Joren’s rescue, unaware of your history with the man. All he sees is someone ending the Great Warlord’s life, an unlikely ally found in a horde of savages. Never one to passively wait for an outcome, he charges the platform where Joren stands. Reluctantly, you follow. Luckily, Joren is the main focus of the elite guard, allowing you to end a few, unaware, from their flank.

Pulling your blade from the back of a guard, dropping him, brings you face to face with Joren. “You,” he utters, with a more surprised look than the Warlord just displayed at Joren’s betrayal. “You just don’t quit, do you?”

Paxson drops a guard next to you. “You know each other? Now’s not the time for petty disputes.”

You parry a blow, stepping back as another tries to catch you preoccupied. “Agreed. Why don’t you make yourself useful and give us some cover?”

Joren, understanding, nods, sending blue flame extending from his palms. The entire platform soon is covered in flame, black smoke rising into the air. In the smoke, you feel at home, drawing upon your training received on the island. Such smokescreens were part of what Morgan taught you, causing you to depend on other senses rather than sight alone. Joren, in the same situation, follows suit, both of you guiding a non-accustomed Paxson through the smoke cover, letting the chaos of the horde give you additional cover, and distraction, to leave the war camp.

You flee, far from the war camp. The sun, originally high in the sky, slowly creeps towards the horizon. But still, you flee, putting as much distance between yourselves and the horde as you can. It may be in disarray, it may be chaotic, but it’s still thousands upon thousands of warriors. For all you know, another leader could rise, bonding them together in their betrayal, uniting them for a sole purpose: to find and kill Joren. In your temporary position next to Joren, you hope that’s not the case. It’s still a very real possibility though.

How is it that the man you chased several nations to kill became an ally, aligning his goal with your own? Yes, Joren is the reason for traveling this far, but the Lady’s will directed you towards the Great Warlord instead. Confused at the outcome, questioning her decision to even task you with the assassination, you suppress the thoughts, meaning to focus on escape. You’ll have plenty of time to answer those questions later.

Cool evening air washes against your face. The three of you, running on foot, finally rest, finding a large grouping of stones as cover. Each of you drop, planting your backs against a stone for support. The rock itself is cold, a result of being exposed to the air, while not receiving direct sunlight.

“Just couldn’t get enough of me, huh?” Joren breaks the silence, hazel eyes meeting yours. His brown curls have grown considerably longer than they were at the island.

“Something like that,” you answer.

“We’re still even, though. I could have escaped there by myself. Didn’t need you and ‘Scowly’ over here to rescue me. If anything, I saved you with that smokescreen.”

“Who are you calling ‘Scowly,’ Mop Head,” Paxson answers. “I don’t care about your past. You ended the Great Warlord’s life, which puts you as a friend in my book.”

You sigh, exhausted. You find yourself here, so might as well make the most of it. “Why? Why did you do it?”

“Do what?” Joren answers. Seeing your frown, he continues. “Ok, ok. Speaking plainly then. The one they worship is real. The woman flocked by crows, vengeful spirit. All that. She’s real. I’ve seen her.”

“No way,” you reply, directed towards the fact that Joren’s spoken with the Lady. As far as you know, you’re the only one she appears to. Morgan didn’t even claim direct communication with her.

“It’s true. She came to me on the island. How much do you know of Killian? He was a false prophet, leading the order astray. He’s actually part of the Dreamwalkers. The leader of the Lady’s order was grooming up members to be taken by the Dreamwalkers for experimentation.”

“But...but you’re a high priest for the Warlord, the direct enemy of the Lady,” you respond.

“I was a high priest for the Great Warlord. All those things I said on the stage are true. The Warlord was a tyrant. He’s just as those who put us in shackles, worse even as he feigns freedom for his followers. They’re bound, and they don’t even know it. Their chains follow them no matter how far they travel.”

Seeing your skepticism, he continues.

“I serve the divine, in all forms he takes. Once I thought that was the Warlord. Even after the island, I thought that. My journey told me otherwise. The Lady told me otherwise. Though I was once aligned to the western tribes, my only duty is to the divine. You are her herald. She told me as such. The herald must have a priest in accompaniment. One to fulfill her will, and the other to cultivate it. You know it must be this way. You and I are bonded, destined, to do the Lady’s work. Together. ”

“I find that hard to believe.”

The voice comes not from you, not even from Paxson, but from your left. Morgan stands between two sizable boulders, arm resting nonchalantly on them. Two emerald eyes framed by hair of unnaturally black hair.

“Liliana?” Paxson utters, wide-eyed.

“Morgan,” she answers, stepping forward. Something flashes in her eyes. Recognition? Whatever it is, it appears for only a moment, now suppressed. Morgan dons her blank, expressionless face, the one that accompanied many lessons on the island.

“Ah, Morgan,” Joren begins. “Fitting you should be here as well. We’ll need your--”

Subtle movement on the rock above where Joren leans against. Neither Paxson, Joren, and apparently, Morgan notice. Something’s wrong. Then, realization hits you, like a strong wind current running into full mast sails. “Morgan” is an illusion, a projection. She stands where the sunlight barely hits the rock formation. No shadow. Her body isn’t casting a shadow. The subtle movement occurs again. You’re too late to stop it.

The real Morgan drops from above, blade ready, flashing, a silvery streak as she flies down. All eyes are focused on the woman in front of them, on “Morgan.” Her boots land directly on Joren’s shoulders, one on each, the sudden blow dazing him. Morgan’s free hand grabs a handful of curly hair, pulling Joren’s head up to expose his neck. She eyes him for a split-second, savoring the moment, ready to enact the Lady’s vengeance. Hazel eyes meet a pair of emeralds.

You must be made to see. Taking a deep breath, you draw on the power that the vengeful spirit instilled in you. Your arm starts to tingle, like static energy is in the air, small hairs starting to rise on themselves. Dizziness takes over, the world spinning into a blur of color and images, pouring in on itself like a swirl of clouds taking the red-orange light from a sunset. Blackness appears at the edge of your vision, growing large, finally tunneling your vision into a single point of light.

A woman appears, emerald eyes within a curtain of blonde hair. Dressed in simple brown work clothes, her hair is a mess, loosely tied behind her head. She struggles to carry a bucket of feed, slop for the farm animals. She grips the bucket in front of her, both hands on the U-shaped handle. The bucket is dumped in entirety with each pen she crosses, causing the woman to journey back to refill its contents. You count six pens in total, a sizable amount for a family, let alone, a lone woman.

The farm is surrounded by trees, much too many to be in the Helswith or the western plains. The land mass itself is far too large to be one of Tristrand’s islands. Wherever you are, it’s a place you’ve never been. Southwest of the barbarian plains maybe? As the woman finally finishes feeding the animals, several figures emerge from the treeline. They’re dressed in red tunics with bright chainmail underneath. Orem’s soldiers. The laws say she’s to provide food and shelter for those in support of their king. The same law took her husband away from her, off to war with mere weeks of service left. That was three years ago. Their reason for arrival obvious, the woman, Liliana, sighs and begins meal prepping.

An hour or so later, she places four plates of food on the table for the hungry soldiers, recognizing only one of them, though Liliana doesn’t recall his name. Roast pork with a side of stew and bread, a specialty of hers. It always was well-received by Orem’s men. The fact that the warm stew and its heaviness made the soldiers sleepy is simply a bonus.

Those who escaped the war, or at least had a break from it, liked to indulge in their ale, and Liliana didn’t want to put up with their rowdy behavior. At first she chalked it up to blowing off steam, but then she slowly realized it was much more: it’s the action of scavengers, men who take all that they can, dressed in Orem’s red. The burden of responsibility, of attending to one’s duty is absent. Instead, it’s men forced into service, those who seek escape above all else. A tankard of ale is a temporary escape, but it does the trick for the time being.

After the soldiers finish, Liliana takes their plates from the table for cleaning. Unlike some, these ones actually thank her for the food. Others assume it’s her duty to serve them. Whether actual gratitude or simply being polite, either one is fine with Liliana.

“Lodgings, Miss?” their sergeant asks, a balding man with scruff appearing at his jaw.

“No extra rooms. Sorry,” Liliana answers. “There’s soft hay in the barn to use. It’s not much, but I’m sure it’s better than being out on the road.” After thanking her, the four soldiers leave, full and drowsy, to rest for the night in the barn. So Liliana thought. She wakes up. Darkness. Heavy footsteps. Floorboards creaking. Powerful arms hold her down. She struggles. Pain.

They’re gone the next morning. Memories echo within Liliana’s mind, recurring events from the previous night. Her helplessness. A strong grip around her. Breath. Gods, that fucking awful breath. Pain. It lingers, a constant reminder, one that will not be easily shaken from her mind. Liliana goes through her daily routine as if everything’s normal. First the squawking chickens, then the swine.

She pours herself into the work, feeling the strain, sweat, and exhaustion set in. The animals here are grateful for her food. They don’t...no, strike it from memory. Keep to the day. Don’t let them take anything more than they have already. She almost forgets about it, the day’s work thankfully filling her thoughts with pressing tasks that need completing. Until evening rolls around, and four figures, again, emerge at the treeline. Orem’s law. She has to give them a place of rest. The law, however, does not cover...what they did. What they continue to do. Another four meals. Another night of pain.

They don’t even acknowledge their wrongdoing. They simply pretend it never happened, like the light of day washes all evil from the night before. She doesn’t forget, though. How can she forget? Still, the soldiers put up their polite facade, giving them deniability with each as a witness for one another. Maybe they don’t even know. Maybe it’s only one of them, sneaking into the night, hurting her. No, they must know. They have to know.

Nightfall. Creaking floorboards. Footsteps heading for her door. Staggering steps, affected by the ale. She gave them a generous amount, hoping it would lay them to sleep for the night. Not enough. Heavy hands holding her down. She anticipates the pain.

A flash of light, followed closely by a burst of red. The thin point of a blade appears in the dark, reflecting moonlight shining through the bedroom window, like a guiding star in the night, one that Liliana instantly promised to follow. The dark shape atop her falls to the side. Standing behind, blade in hand, is a man with hair like snow. Pure white. He gazes at Liliana, concern in his face as if the loving look of a father.

“Will the lady extend her vengeance to the others?” the man speaks, a soft whisper in the night air.

Liliana nods, a loose strand of blonde hair falling in front of her face. Blonde hair, like a young girl innocent of the world of men. No more. She would have to change that, and she knows just the color. Black, like the night, to remind her of her helplessness. Black, to signify the hearts of men. First, the others must be attended to. Then her transformation would be complete.

---

A fist crashes into your nose, sending you sprawling to the ground. Paxson stands over you, visibly angered. Behind him, rests the dead body of Joren, countless stab wounds pouring blood from his chest, Morgan holding the dagger. Joren’s blood is splattered across Morgan’s face and clothes, a large pool starting to form underneath his body.

“What did you do to her?” Paxson demands, still towering over you.

“Me? Nothing. It was Orem’s soldiers…” you answer.

Anger washes from Paxson’s face, fragmented memories pieced together like a puzzle. He knows the laws of his homeland. Recognition, then horror, replaces his anger. His departure, her pain.

Morgan, trance-like, wipes the blood from her blade. Any trace of emotion has since left her voice. “What’s done is done. The lady’s vengeance is complete.” She turns to leave, her steps mirroring the emotionless tone of her voice, mechanical, like limbs tied to strings pulled by a puppet master.

She leaves you and Paxson alone, the mutilated body of Joren opposite the two of you. Paxson slumps down next to you, his threats all but vanished. He sighs, the burden placed upon him audibly heard. It’s a temporary relief, but the weight returns with the next breath.

“I’m going after her,” Paxson comments.

You turn, meeting his gaze.

“We’ll both go.”

The End

You do not intervene. How could you deny Morgan her revenge? You’ve spent many months chasing the man before you. A man lies dead, several in the following wake. A temple, a holy place, peaceful, lies burned and destroyed. All at this man’s hands. All at Joren’s hands. No, he may have ended the Great Warlord’s life, but that does not pardon him for past crimes. You’ve followed the Lady’s will this far, you’ll continue to follow it without Joren.

Morgan’s blade sinks into Joren’s throat.

Joren’s, now lifeless body, slinks to the side, Morgan standing over it.

“How could you?” she speaks. “How could you ally yourself with this murderer?”

“He’s no ally of mine,” you start. Paxson cuts you off.

“This man killed the Warlord. He ended a war before it could expand beyond border skirmishes. Is that really you, Lil?”

Her eyes narrow. “Morgan. Liliana is no more.” Directing towards you, she adds, “We’ve traveled far, through Tristrand’s waters, across the Helswith Desert, into the western plains. Yet I find you in the very company of the man we hunt. Why?”

You momentarily glance at Paxson, whose face has darkened. He’s quieted down for now, working through the sudden appearance of “Liliana.” You reply.

“He claims to have spoken to the Lady. And that it was at her direction that Killian was killed.”

“Bullshit,” Morgan answers. “I heard his story, the same as you. Joren no more served the Lady than I serve Uralan. It’s clear that your judgement is clouded. I’ll not have your confusion get in the way of the rebuilding of the order. You are hereby dismissed. Should you seek us out, I’ll have no choice but to…” She trails off at the end, but a slight gesture towards Joren’s body solidifies the threat. “I thought it would be the both of us rebuilding after vengeance was fulfilled. Seems it will just be me.”

Morgan turns, stepping over Joren’s body, and strides towards the break in the stones, traveling alone. As she reaches the edge, the place where the natural trail veers from sight, she stops and speaks over her shoulder.

“Well, are you coming?”

Thankful she’s come to her senses, you start to rise from your seat against one of the stones.

“No, not you,” she speaks. Paxson, still in a trance-like state, stands and rushes to join Morgan, as if taking too much time would cause her to leave without him.

“You have to understand, Nameless. I--”

You cut him off by raising a hand, palm stretched out facing him. “No need. Go to her. I’ll see to it that no collectors search for you, not that they’d have much luck in finding you with her. It’s about time the lost son of Arroden returns home.”

Paxson suddenly stops, turning back to meet you one final time. His arm stretches out. Yours meets it, clasping palm against inner forearm. No additional words are shared. None are necessary. The man with a past deeply aligned to your own takes your position next to Morgan. It’s not how you expected things to end.

Somehow, though, your lives have come full circle. Symmetry. Your part played in the story, a feeling of completion washes over you. You would have some questions for the Lady upon her next appearance. This chapter’s over, but another is beginning. It’s time to head home.

The End

Captain Rotha didn’t like his new assignment one bit. First of all, it’s on land. He much prefers the soothing creaking of The Seaspell, the comforting sway of the ocean. The plains are firm. Marching on solid ground isn’t something he’s used to. It’s not something any of them are used to. Their home is the sea, but Rotha, along with his crew, are loyal to King Tristrand, and they will follow his every command...even if it brings them on solid land.

He’s well aware of the importance of his mission. It’s on him to breach the gap between barbarian and his king. A new agreement will be set into motion by his hand, acting as proxy for Tristrand. It would mean great things for their nation. It would free up a major portion of the king’s spending to build up their defenses and promote other arts within their waters. The people of the Helswith were taking advantage of them. They assumed King Tristrand had no other option but to deal with them as if their king was limited by their greed. Still, it was a little unsettling to deal with these...savages. Guess you truly get what you pay for.

Worse yet, his men, a crew of King Tristrand are forced to camp on the outskirts of the barbarian horde. When Rotha invites an important guest aboard The Seaspell, he always offers them the finest quarters. It’s about respect. Then again, these may be the finest “quarters” the horde can offer. On second thought, being the centerfold of the camp makes Rotha more uneasy. True, he’s exposed being on the outskirts, but given a choice between here and surrounded by savages, he’d stick with what he’s got.

The captain sits outside his tent, leaning back in his chair using a stone in the ground as a footrest. His tricorn hat is placed on his knee, revealing his sandy hair tied in a loose knot at the nape of his neck, the loose strands tucked behind his ears. He has the luxury of privacy, something his crew can’t boast, but he needs to feel the open air. At least then he can pretend it’s the breeze of the sea.

“Captain Rotha, sir!”

Rotha turns to meet the voice. Three of his crew stand before him, matching royal uniforms, none of them high enough rank to wear breastplate. Young lads, them. Not five years older than when Rotha first joined the navy.

“What can I do for you boys?”

“Do we still have the freedom to enter the horde’s camp?”

Rotha peers an eye at the voice. “Yes, sailor, but I would refrain from using that term around them. Same goes for ‘savage’ and ‘barbarian.’ Use ‘warrior’ instead. Their leader, the Great Warlord, is extending full hospitality.”

The three of them glance at one another, obviously excited, although attempting to keep a stoic demeanor of a soldier.

“Might I remind you though,” Captain Rotha adds. “that you’re still on duty and partaking in acts unfit for a sailor will result in reprimanding.” Lowering his voice, he continues. “These may be our new allies, but that does not mean they are not a threat. Just because the blade isn’t brandished, doesn’t mean the hand still holds the hilt.”

“Yes, Captain Rotha, sir!” three voices reply in unison.

Rotha watches them leave, by far the most eager of his crew to be here. Unsurprisingly, the youngest too. Around him, the rest of the crew, his seasoned sailors, look to relax and recover from their hike. Rotha was glad they asked for permission, but according to ship’s rules, they have every right to indulge during their “prolonged landing,” usually in effect when a ship needs repairs. It’s not a bad thing for men to blow off steam when confined to a boat for large amounts of time. If their new partnership includes more prolonged landings, then he’ll have to do something about the rule. Captain Rotha breathes in the plain’s air, wishing it was the sea’s, and silently hopes his assignment doesn’t become a permanent position.

Whatever this is, it’s not the way the Lady normally appears to you. You decide to ignore the light. Often, her presence would come during moments of sleep. She appears in your dreams, never as a glowing light while you’re conscious. You roll over to hide the tattoo with your body and drift off to sleep, fully expecting to find yourself face-to-face with the Lady.

Instead, you find yourself face-to-face with a pike, illuminated by the blue glow of the moon. Behind it, a soldier dressed in royal blue, standing next to countless others. Royal blue, the colors of King Tristrand. Rowboats lie scattered on the beach, the reason why no one heard their approach. Next to you, each man of the Reapers is awoken with a similar treatment. K’rell is clutching a wound at his side, apparently didn’t take too kindly, or passively, to the soldier’s presence.

With the Reapers contained, a man strides through Tristrand’s soldiers wearing a tricorn hat, hands clasped behind him. His uniform is more distinct, embroidered with a more intricate weave. Must be the captain. Pralthar has the same thought and addresses him.

“What is the meaning of this? We’re under the High Lord’s protection. Remove your weapons and go your own way. I just may forget this little incident ever took place.”

The captain, a man with appearing wrinkles at his face presses his lips into a content smirk. “Ahh, you must be the leader of this...bunch. I heard there was a Helswithian squad in this area causing a ruckus. Seems I’ve found them.”

“Found them and testing their patience,” Pralthar answers. “The High Lord will not be pleased in Tristrand’s interference.”

“That’s King Tristrand,” the captain replies. A nod of his head brings a blow across Pralthar’s face from the nearest soldier in blue. “Helswith and Ursa have grown too confident for their own good, treating my lord as if a common trader. Each year, prices on Helswithian goods increase and increase, attempting to bleed my king dry. You Helswithians are all the same. You expect the world to grovel at your feet.”

“The prices rise with material shortage!” Caius shouts, interjecting himself into the conversation. He’s given a similar treatment across the face.

“My king has entered into a new agreement. One that is much more beneficial to his waters and coffers. He has his people to think about, you know. I know that’s hard for you to wrap your head around, thinking about someone other than yourselves. It seems your services are no longer needed, soldier.”

With another nod, soldiers dressed in royal blue thrust their pikes forward, impaling members of the Reapers on their makeshift islands, a fitting place to die at the hands of their executioners. Those of you with quick reflexes fight back, even felling a few of Tristrand’s men, but there are too many of them. You, Paxson, and the Reapers die to several stab wounds, bleeding out on the sand, sand which is not born of your homeland, the Helswith Desert.

Morgan exits the small inn room, leaving Sea Breeze without as much as a nod towards the owner. The main room of the inn is empty, something tells her that’s its natural state. There are far better places to stay in this city, ones that are similarly priced too. With discretion prioritized over fine ale and room service, Sea Breeze is the perfect place for the two of them to stay.

Soft glows of red-orange peer over the horizon, brighter than a normal sunset due to the reflective ocean spread out in front of the city. In the distance, crews work to secure their ships for the night. From Morgan’s vantage point, they look like little ants working in unison. A breeze of cold air rushes past Morgan, touching the exposed parts of her skin, signaling night is quickly approaching. The inn is aptly named. Briefly admiring the sunset, Morgan heads down the windy road.

She spotted it when first arriving in the city. The temple, built on the tip of the crescent-moon city, rises high, overlooking the water. Its construction is simple. It’s long and rectangular, four pillars standing above the rest of the structure like an upside down bedframe. Light stone blocks, obviously imported, create stability and strength, both symbolically and physically. No religious symbols or insignias are displayed out front. All are welcome here. Two double-doors lead inside the temple, reinforced with metal at the base and top. The doors are propped open, allowing citizens to come and go as they please.

Morgan strides inside. The interior is candlelit. Rows of pews fill the back of the sanctuary, where the doors are, stopping halfway down the room. Two men, sitting in the pews, silent in prayer, don’t even acknowledge her presence. From there, mats and pillows take over, leading to an unmarked altar. Without decor, or anything signifying a specific religion, the altar, instead, looks like a stone coffin. Morgan walks the length of the sanctuary and sits on the mat closest to the altar.

She takes a deep breath of air, softening her eyes, feeling the rush through her nose, the expansion of her chest, the slowing down of time. She lets the breath leave slowly, deliberately, drawing the exhale into a lengthy maneuver. Morgan then notices her hands are tightly balled into two fists, her fingers clenched tightly together. She relaxes, feeling the tension release, similarly to her breathing pattern.

Lady, have I failed you? she silently prays. A temple to no god stands, while yours lies charred, broken, and crumbling. How is it that everything can change in an instant? In one moment, strength lies within our grasp, and the next it’s fleeting through our fingers like sand spilling through an hourglass. May your spirit, its vengeance guide me. Allow me to correct this wrong. Give me the strength, the willpower to defeat your enemies. By tradition, I know I’m to assume the role of teacher.

Morgan hesitates to continue, but does so anyway.

I don’t know if I can lead. I’ve always been better at caring for myself. But now? I’m to take the responsibility of the man marked by your very hand? I pray for wisdom in the endeavour. Only by your protection will this order survive. Appear to me, give me a sign, and I will follow your will.

Silence. It’s always silent after her prayers. Once upon a time she expected a sign or vision to guide her, to appear after her prayers, but it’s always quiet, a one-way affair. Unless the man paired with her now is--

”What’s a pretty woman like you doing alone? It’s dangerous to be out during the night.”

Morgan turns to find the two men, first in the pews, standing behind her. So that’s why the temple is sparsely populated. Darkness lies outside, seems the sun had finally disappeared completely during her prayer.

“Were you kicked by a horse? What does it look like I’m doing?” Morgan sharply answers.

Her response earns a chuckle from the one on the right. “Heh, heh. She’s got spirit, this one.” He takes a step toward Morgan. “I like a little spirit.” His hand grips Morgan’s arm. She lets him grab her.

The other man steps forward. Close up, his nose is crooked, likely the result of a bad break, literally and figuratively. The back of his palm trace down Morgan’s face. “We’ll be quick, don’t worry. You’ll be free to go after we have a little ‘fun.’”

“You don’t strike me as a couple of marathoners,” Morgan answers, still held by the arm. “I imagine it’s a quick sprint to the finish line.”

The back of the man’s palm removes itself from her face, drawing back in the air, stopping for a brief moment, then catapults itself towards Morgan’s cheek. She sees it coming. Her instincts scream at her to move, almost taking over completely, but she wills it to silence. Silent, like her prayer. The blow strikes true, snapping Morgan’s head back, which would have caused her to fall to the floor if not held by the other man. The blow, the resonating sound of skin on skin seems to excite the men. Satisfied at her inability to escape, the man holding Morgan’s arm tosses her to the floor, on the mat where she just prayed.

Both of them, at once, jump on top of her, one holding her arms, while the other her legs. She throws a haphazard kick, unsuccessfully, which only spurs the men on with greater zeal. Fingers grab at her body, meaty things, touching parts of her meant only for a lover, grabbing forcefully, slapping, pinching.

The woman flocked by crows, the vengeful spirit. Her beauty drew the attention of men such as these two. She spent years suffering as the Great Warlord’s plaything, shamefully providing her body to every desire of the man, no matter how painful, no matter how wrong it felt. If this is the cost of drawing close to the Lady, to understanding her greater, Morgan will gladly pay it. She trusts the Lady’s will. The man at her legs starts to pull down her trousers.

No.

Morgan explodes into movement, sending her heel into the man’s groin and using the back of her head to smash into the other man’s nose, by the sound of it, causing another break. Planting her palms on the floor next to her ears, Morgan swings her legs over her head in a backward handspring, landing on her feet.

She grabs the man clutching his nose, pulling him by the back of his shirt, dragging him towards the altar. Struggling, his feet kick out, not able to find a solid footing on the floor. Morgan’s hand tenderly appears at his cheek, and she flashes a smile towards the man. The tenderness disappears, transitioning into a vice-like grip. She smacks the other side of his face into the stone altar, leaving behind a crack and spot of red. Again. The crack deepens, more red appears. Again. Again. Again.

“You’re...you’re a madwoman!” the remaining man shouts, starting to scramble towards the open doorway. His foot slips on one of the floor mats, sending him sprawling on the ground.

“Well, perhaps the Lady is looking after me,” Morgan comments to herself. At the mention of her god, the lighthearted comment is replaced with somber mood. I failed. I couldn’t put myself through a fraction of the torment you endured, Lady. I promise I’ll be stronger. Morgan makes for the double-doors, shutting them closed, then approaches the man.

“You’ll be free to go after we have a little ‘fun,’” she says, a smirk coming to her lips. She continues walking towards the man, one side of her face, splattered with red streaks as if barbarian war paint.

“Although I can’t promise this will be quick.”

They ridiculed him upon arrival. A slave? Here, in High Lord Ursa’s army? It’s laughable. The Helswith Desert held some of the most prominent warriors in any territory. And now a slave joins them? The High Lord must really need every able body. While a slave in the army is laughable, the threat before them is not. The barbarian horde gathers, sweeping through land dangerously close to the Helswith. It’s not yet reached the borders of Ursa’s land, but they’re close. Damn close.

The journey took several weeks. Paxson, carted by a single man, finally arrived at the military camp. The trip was not enjoyable. After all, he spent the entire time locked in the cage sitting behind the cart driver. The Helswith Desert sun beat on the open cage, bathing Paxson in constant heat, while the driver sat comfortably in shade, the cart sporting an overhang for the driver.

The nights were worse. Once the sun fell below the horizon, a wave of cold overswept the desert. Paxson, in the exposed cage, had a single blanket in defense against the environment. The driver, able to move beyond the cart, built a fire each night, always holding his open palms against the heat, occasionally rubbing his hands together for even more warmth, all in view of the cage as if mocking Paxson. Small interactions with the man told Paxson it was nothing personal, just a job, but still, being witness to an abundance of warmth, but being outside it’s range, made the cold desert nights feel somehow even colder.

Finally, though, Paxson reached the western military camp. Finally, he can warm himself with the heat of combat. He wasn’t the only slave to arrive. He wasn’t even the only gladiator to arrive. The offer presented to Arroden Scholhart was given to each man of prominence. Many took the offer, just as Arroden had. Not only was the man awarded with immediate revenue, willingness to support High Lord Ursa was equally as important.

Paxson was assigned to the Reapers, an infantry unit in the High Lord’s army. There, he learned the ridicule given to him wasn’t due to his gladiatorial stature. The soldiers ridiculed anyone who they felt wasn’t deserving of their station. Despite their aggression, Paxson understands their notion. They’re citizens of the High Lord. Serving alongside “property” dragged their own worth down, so they made verbal comments to put themselves higher. Paxson, no stranger to the tactic, accepted each without retaliation. He might even do the same in their shoes.

No contact had been made with the horde yet, but that was about to change…

“I’ll gather what we need,” you say. “Speaking of which, what will we need?”

Another smirk shines from Morgan. She wipes away a strand of black hair from her eye. “Oh, not much. A few vials for smoke. I packed the ingredients, but vials -- well, glass, is hard to carry without shattering. New blades would help as well. Just in case the king’s men decide they don’t want us reading through their logs.”

So that’s what her plan is.

Morgan continues. “Some extra throwing knives couldn’t hurt. Grab me a shoulder sheath for them while you’re at it. Oh, and here’s some extra crowns for whatever you deem is necessary. I’ll find us a place to rest. We’ll meet back here in, oh, two hours?”

“Works for me,” you answer, grabbing the money from her palm. She pulls back, fully intending to whisk her hand away before you can reach the coins. Instead, your fingers catch her wrist, holding her hand, fist clenched, firmly in place. “I’ve learned to expect such things from you. Your training demanded it of me.”

The smirk instantly disappears from Morgan’s face. “Did I also instruct boasting at the aversion of humility?”

“Not orally, but perhaps I learned by example,” you reply.

“Two hours,” Morgan says, and leaves you to gather the items. As she leaves, a smile begins to widen on your face. It’s not often you catch her flustered. If you were being honest, catching her arm was pure luck. Ok, maybe not pure luck, but it wasn’t intentional. An instinct took over, something uncontrollable and unintentional. How could you claim ownership of that? Removing such thoughts, you wander down the street looking for a vendor who has what you need.

Eventually, you discover a sign marked INS, OUTS, AND THINGS. The windows are dark, not allowing you to see within, so you stroll through the front door. The door opens and closes with a ringing from an attached bell. The inside looks like a junkyard. Various items, equipment, tools, weapons, armor, furniture, and knick-knacks line the shelves and walls. An old woman, short in stature, digging through a pile of goods (junk), peers up at your arrival.

“Hello, Dear. Welcome to my humble store,” she says, attempting a small bow. It’s clear she’s never mastered the act.

“I imagine I’ll need your help finding what I’m looking for,” you answer, sharing with the old woman the items listed by Morgan. Each thing listed, brings a widening to the woman’s eyes as she visibly remembers where each item rests. It’s like telling a child a fairy-tale the way she lights up.

She finishes finding exactly what you need, after barely digging through the piles of goods (junk). It’s clear to you that she knows where everything is, despite the apparent mess. “Anything else, Sweetheart?” she asks.

A longbow catches your eye, hanging in a glass case on the wall. As quick as you notice it, you shake the idea from your mind. You aren’t here to assassinate anyone from a distance. The weapon wouldn’t serve a purpose on whatever Morgan has in mind.

“No, ma’am,” you answer, counting out the crowns.

“No,” you refuse.

“What did you say?” Morgan peers down at you. “I urge you to reconsider your choice.”

“I’m sorry. But I have my own matters to attend to. I’ve spent the last few years as a slave. Now that I have my freedom, I’m not willing to trade it for a mad quest of revenge.”

“You’re a disgrace, and you shouldn’t bear that mark,” Morgan answers. The heel of her boot finds your face, dazing you on the ground. Immediately, Morgan squats down forcefully grabbing your wrist, twisting your arm so the tattoo of the crow is exposed. With a flash, her knife appears in her other hand.

“Wait, no--” you start. Then pain rushes through your arm.

Like peeling the outer layer of a potato, Morgan’s knife cuts into your skin, meaning to remove the entire image of the crow. You struggle, but she holds your arm firmly in place. As you attempt to strike at her with your free hand, she swats away the blow and sends the hilt of her dagger into your nose with a sickening crunch. On the plus side, the pain from your now-broken nose is slightly distracting from your arm.

“Shh,” Morgan hushes you as cries of pain escape your lips. “It’ll be over soon. The more you struggle, the worse it gets.”

Pain. Sharp pain. Unavoidable pain fills your body. You try to focus on something else, to bring your mind to another place, but all you feel is pain. Then, it’s over. Morgan releases your arm, triumphantly holding up a thin piece of skin like a trophy earned. She tosses it to the ground next to you and squats down, again, to stare into your eyes.

“I’m going after that murderer. He’ll receive a lot more than you did just now. Perhaps there’s a small comfort in knowing it could be worse. In Killian’s memory I won’t end your life...but that doesn’t mean I have to let you off easy.”

Morgan’s dagger slams down into your thigh. Her face draws closer with her next statement.

“You’ve brought destruction along with you. I can only hope slowing you down will, too, slow down that which follows you. Think what you must, but this truly is a mercy.”

Morgan stands, leaving her dagger in your leg. “And a generosity. Look, I’m not leaving you unarmed.” A small laugh hangs in the air. Somehow, you imagine violence is the only thing to cause such an outward display of emotion from that woman.

She leaves you alone, bleeding in the dirt. The only equipment provided is the dagger in your leg.

action_results.action: Stay put and address the wound
action_results.result:
The pain continues. There’s no use in trying to escape the island without addressing your wounds first. Morgan gone, you crawl in the grass, dragging your leg behind you, to a nearby boulder. Using it as a backrest, you examine the damage dealt. It’s not good. Your nose makes a wheezing sound with each breath, and you can’t put pressure on your leg. For the time being, you keep the dagger firmly planted in your leg. Until you find a way to stop the bleeding, it’s better to leave it in.

Darkness sets in for a moment. Panic sets in. You’ve lost a lot of blood. You’re going to need to address your wounds quickly. Time is racing against you. Around you, there’s plenty of scrapwood, remains from the destruction caused by Joren. Doing your best to ignore the pain, unsuccessfully, you crawl over to the pieces of wood. At the base of the temple, among the ruins, soft warm glowing shines through the rubble. Small embers still burn, a result of the fire Joren lit. With your newly found wood scraps, you coax the embers into a sizable flame.

Now, the hard part.

Taking a few quick huffs of breath in preparation, you grab the dagger’s handle and pull out the blade in one smooth motion. Blood pools out immediately, running down your leg dying your trousers dark crimson. White hot pain shoots through your body, your vision becoming faint. Got to act quickly. You place the dagger in the fire, blade among the flames. There’s nothing to disinfect the wound -- what you would give for a strong drink right about now, for both your leg and your senses.

Confident in the blade’s temperature, you draw it from the fire. Your vision fades for a moment, again, blood loss starting to affect you more severely. It has to be done if you have any chance of survival. You press the flat side of the dagger against your wound. Your vision, fading black, lights up for a brief second in a burst of pain. You release a scream from your lips, anything to help numb the pain. It doesn’t help. It’s too much.

Your hand, losing its strength, drops the dagger from your palm. It lands on the grass next to you. The words from your dream echo in your mind. Death follows you, child. It didn’t take long to catch up.

The damage is bad. Real bad. You need to address the wound, quickly. The nearby jungle offers protection and resources. Here, in the middle of the burnt remains of a camp, you’re exposed and without supplies. Morgan said there were no others in the order. Still, the thought of someone else discovering the location, and your vulnerable state, isn’t a place you want to find yourself. No doubt there are ships searching for the one lost at sea. Others arriving here is a very real possibility. Best to keep moving.

First, address your leg wound. You rip your shirt, starting from the neckline all the way down to the bottom. Fashioning it into a tourniquet, you steady yourself for the hard part. Nearby, you see a broken tree branch, a little smaller than your wrist, and you crawl over to it. It’s a little wide, but it’ll serve its purpose. You bite down on the branch and pull the dagger from your leg. Blood immediately begins to flow from the wound, staining your trousers red in a burst of fluid.

Screaming, you bite down harder on the branch, attempting to channel the pain through clenched jaw and screams. Before too much blood is lost, you tie your makeshift tourniquet around your leg and wait for the initial shock to pass. Minutes you sit, trying to take your mind off the pain, unsuccessfully. Eventually, you reach a point where the pain persists, but it’s manageable enough to stand. You have to keep moving.

You half limp, half hop to the treeline, meaning to find a safe shelter and pathway to the beach in the case a ship arrives looking for the one lost at sea. The jungle floor is hard to get through. Twisting vines and roots lie in your path, causing movement to be slowed even further. You press on, however, and--

come face to face with a man. He looks as if a beggar, beard and hair both unkempt, dirt marking his face and body.

“Well hi there, fellow traveler,” the man says with a grin. Eyeing your leg, he continues. “That doesn’t look good. No it doesn’t. Oh dear you’re losing too much blood.”

“My ship...crashed,” you reply, feeling the effects of blood loss and exertion.

“That it did. And I imagine Killian took you into his ranks?”

The mention of the snow-haired man momentarily distracts you from the pain.

“Of course he did,” the beggar says, pointing to your arm and the missing skin displayed. “I have a good idea what used to be there.”

“Help…” you utter, the effects of your wound reappearing. “Need to stitch this up.”

The beggar, again, answers with a smile. “Of course I’m going to help you. Doesn’t do much good to study a dead specimen. Well, not as much good.”

“What do you…”

“Oh, hush. Killian mentioned the war, didn’t he? You, my formerly tattooed friend, just found yourself on the wrong side of it. We haven’t had a live one for years now. The others will be happy. I’m afraid you’ll be just a nuisance, traveling with a leg like that.”

Whistling the man, bends down looking at the ground, moving dirt and twigs with his palms searching for something. “Ah, this will do,” he speaks to himself. Standing back up, you see a small rock is resting in the palm of his hand. “This will go a lot smoother if you don’t struggle. The same goes for when we’re back at the facility.”

Not that you can offer much of a struggle in your current state, you completely ignore his words, throwing a labored punch in his direction as he approaches. The beggar easily ducks under and smashes the side of your head with the rock. It doesn’t knock you out at first, but two more blows do the trick. The horrors that you will awaken to, that have become your reality, are best not thought about. The beggar is right, however, struggling doesn’t do much good.
